game-hours: 420.3
review: I feel reluctant to give a yes or no recommendation for this game. In fact I started writing this with a "yes" but eventually felt compelled to change it to a "no". The reason is that I love so much about the gameplay and the concept. There is so much potential in the idea and existing framework, it could be truly great, but it has no reward to its RPG-esque item grind. It exists for its own sake. If - like me - you actually don't mind laborious 'farming' to reach a goal (which in this case is always to purchase a new weapon or 'Frame, i,e, class), then even the grinding for materials is not really a bad thing. The real problem with Warframe is that - when the combat gameplay is no longer sufficient as its own reward - the 'grind' that is central & the only other motivation to play... has absolutely no point. As another review aptly described, it is at its core a 'monotonous circular treadmill'. Not just a treadmill, a circular one. In other 'treadmill' games you at least clear 'hurdles' during one, 'jumping to the next treadmill' so to speak ... but this one is like a circular treadmill in that you are never anywhere different in terms of progression than the day you start. Sure you will accumulate a warchest of a crapload of weapons and modifications and 'classes' ... but you only ever use one of each in a mission, so the more you accumulate, the smaller % of what you 'earned' you are using. What good is having a thousand options of marginal variation for one thing? You can accomplish that 'thing' with just one option, you dont need anything more, but that is the only progression there is. The missions are quite repetitive and quickly consumed content, after which your only gameplay is to repeat the missions to acquire loot. Then use that loot to purchase/craft tools that you will just use to continue grinding loot. The grind actually remains reasonable fun as you play around with cool weapons and powers... but inevitably you hit 'the wall' where you realize you are essentially just farming for the ability to farm some more - just with a shiny new weapon. Grind grind grind. Get a new weapon. Rinse, repeat. No competitive system, no long term goals, no real sense of accomplishment. It's a shame because the devs work quite hard and provide quite substantial updates on a rapid schedule... yet refuse to break away from a business plan of simply adding more things to farm. I've actually spoken at length with multiple devs of the game - who are very active in its community & open to feedback - vehemently voicing this concern ... but for some reason it has never become a priority for them to create any new macro progression. Just more of the same. I really hope one day this changes so I can return to the game I spent quite a bit of time playing (and even quite a bit of cash as I dont mind rushing a few things I really want or supporting development), but without a new 'purpose' to playing I will not... and continue to regret every penny spent.
game-hours: 94.5
review: At first, warframe appears to be something new and origional, with it's spectacular art style and graphics, and it's entire presentation is a feast for the eyes. However, after a few hours of gameplay grinding the same spots for the blueprients and materials to create the warframe or weapon you wanted, you will wonder to yourself "what now"? Do you grind for more gear? Get some more fancy augments? But what's the point when all your fancy warframes and weapons only make you more efficient at grinding for more stuff? Now I know what you're saying "Isn't that the basis of any MMO?" Sort off... If you boil it down any MMO is one big quest for loot, but what makes it good is how fun it is to play all the dungeons and missions to recieve these rewards, and Warframe fails it it terribly. This game becomes far too repetitive, you only have a handful of scenarios to play through on missions and the difference between them is barely remarkable. You're still fighting baddies through the same spaceship hallways, just rearranged each time. The warframes themselves are also fundamentally flawed. Each warframe has a unique set of abilities (which three are avaliable from the start, and the last only ebing avaliable when your WF is upgraded with an item that is conveniently found in the cash shop), sure, but you also have a rather limited pool of energy that you expend to use said abilities, and said pool can only be replenished by scarce pickups. So really yuor 'style' is more defined by what wepaons you have painstakenly constructed by grinding for the materials to make... and if you don't like them you're  out of luck. Not to mention the fact that there is little to no emphasis on teamwork on a multiplayer game... I mean they try to do something by making each warframe's abilities varied enough to try and do so, but if you're not sprinting down a hallway and killing things fast then you end up being more of a burden t the team. Same thing applies to pvp, nothing matters but outright damage, and you better built the right warframe for it or it's back to more grinding for you. Then there is the cash shop... while every weapon and frame can be built from materials and blueprints dropped in missions (which takes AGES of grinding) you can instantly buy them in the cash shop as well. This screams play to win in the most blatant way, but since grinding for your equipment is half the game you'll probably come to the conclusion that this isn't worth the time faster if you spend a few bucks. So despite it's flashy looks and first impressions, Warframe is a huge dissapointment. Don't get me wrong, I wanted this game to be good so badly. It's an absolute delight to look at, and the setting alone is quite good, how could you not enjoy what is essentialy a story revolving around an ancient race of alien space ninja? But sadly, the core gameplay mechanics fall short in what is a flawed game. Everything is so polished I can see someone forgetting that they've been running through what is basically the same randomized space ship for hours to find the last few materials for their lazer katana that burns things that it slices through. If only art direction could float a game on it's own, but I suppose if you're going to grind through the same spots for a while they might as well look pretty.

game-hours: 43.6
review: So unless Im mistaken, this game was made by the same people who created UT and the original Bioshock, so, you really have to ignore their past work when playing this game. Warframe isnt "bad" per se, its just not really finished, even now. The recent changes in melee combat fix the games biggest problem (which was its  melee combat) but all the other issues are still there. Ill start with gameplay, because just about everything else in this review is going to be opinion: The gameplay is serviceable, but not well developed, and by that I mean "it plays like something stuck somewhere between an alpha and a beta". The movement is fast, but strangely influid, the jumping and free-running feel shoehorned in and are clunky at best, and the gunplay is efficient but lacks any bite or freedback. One major feature is that the levels are generated randomly from prefab rooms. This means that you can have large labyrinthian levels to run around in, but the the sparse nature of the prefab rooms, combined with the relativly low number of prefab enrivonments (Id say there are roughly 8-10 different rooms per level-type, including hallways and connective elements) means that this interesting idea really doesnt effect the gameplay at all, and can even be downright confusing as you pass through three copies of the exact same room. The enemies are similarly bland, sporting troops, heavy troops, melee troops, and the occasional shield drone. The bosses seem to have fallen into the same blackhole of creativity as well, as they are hardly ever more than meattanks. It is also worth mentioning that while tweaking your stats with mods is easy without paying money, doing literally anything else, from buying weapons to building new warframes (this is especially daunting) pretty much requires money to avoid a hideous amout of grinding. Moving away from the basic facts of the game; I just dont like the way it looks, and the way the world is layed out. There is pretense of a story, but it is wafer thin, the missions reenforces that shallowness by providing no real context for your actions. There is only one voiced character, a sort of operations assistant who tells you when the objective changes, and a few random soundbites from bosses. This total lack of story depth is what makes the second issue in the game's presentation even harder not to laugh at: the aesthetic choices. While Ill admit I like the idea of a living biomech ninja suit, and I do even like a handfull of the warframes, for the most part the aesthetics, especially those found in the enemies and level design, are misguided at best. If you've not played the game before, go look up a picture of a Grineer trooper (the name is just the worst, they should really beat whoever came up with it with a stick). The enemy designs dont convey anything about the enemies, be it their capabilities, their position or rank, or even any kind of information about the nature of their faction. On top of this lack of narrative functionality, they just look downright goofy, as do many of the warframes, as I previously mentioned. Even though Im not going to formally recommend this game, Id still say "go try it". Apparently some people like it enough to pay money for it, and, though I believe those people have a mental illness not yet characterized by science, maybe you, dear reader, do as well.

Some bugs even compromises the gameplay and can make you DIE, like when you have to be revived and you can just walk around, so that nobody can heal you. Third...this is a game which has been in beta for MONTHS, I've read in the reviews that somebody said that this game is in the middle way between an alpha and a beta...and I must say, I TOTALLY agree with him. A game should be in beta for months, just to give players power to try and stretch it to find as many bugs as possible, in this game users actually pay a lot to play a game which does not work, and after some weeks and many (frustrating) updates becomes boring as hell...even if you managed to build flamethrouwers and gu-guns...this is going to be a beta forever, as long as they earn money from people who pay for this buggy and boring game..the classes and the powers are kinda all the same, they just change visual effects.

game-hours: 520.9

game-hours: 13.0
review: Grind so you can get more equipment, to grind in level design that rivals Halo 1 in terms of most amount of copy-pasting. It's got better polish than your average F2P game. The content is pretty expensive and also subjectively Pay 2 Win. Because Path of Exile or Dota 2 could have done the same thing, PoE could have charged for uniques and Dota for Hero unlocks except they only charge for cosmetics. Path of Exile is a Co-op PvE game too. In Warframe you either cough up the cash or spend eternity grinding to grind some more. It's pretty much single player because there's no communication and most players tend to just hit the sprint + crouch button to reach the objective rather than collecting resources. You are forced to chase them as they reach the "ONLY CO-OP" feature of the game, where two players are need to hit a switch together to open a door. Here is a quick explaination of the gameplay: You have an overview of our solar system, you start at Mercury. Each Planet has a particular amount of missions before you proceed to the next planet. Planets also consist of resources, which drop from killed enemies or crates/storage. In a nutshell you do Co-op missions which are bland, grind items, credit and resources, purchase blueprints with the virtual credit. Each item requires certain resources. For the sake of this review let's say I want to craft a Rhino Warframe, it requires W, X, Y, Z resources. Refer to the solar system map and see which planet has those resources. Now Mercury will have "Z", Jupiter has "Y" and pluto has "W". You will have to play missions, even repeat them to aquire the neccessary resources. Once you DO GATHER THE resources, you have to wait 12-24 hours in real time for the foundry to craft the weapon. This is nothing more than a way to nudge you reminding you that the game is free to play with inconvienience. Free to play really is a tainted model unless it's Path of Exile and Dota 2 and Loadout, where it actually works. I rather cough up 29-49$ to play a full experience. All hostility aside, the game has potential, and Digital Extremes is a talented company considering they did UT1999, 03, 04 and Dark Sector. The controls and graphics are fantastic. Get rid of the buy to unlock model and look at Path of Exiles as a blue print. Also for those who are complaining about wasting money on this game to only be dissapointed 20-30 hours later, it's not the developers fault, it's the risk you take when you decide to invest in "Open Betas" and "F2P". Give this game a try, or try it's prequel single player "Dark Sector" which was an underrated game by Digital Extreme.
game-hours: 6.7

review: At first, warframe appears to be something new and origional, with it's spectacular art style and graphics, and it's entire presentation is a feast for the eyes. However, after a few hours of gameplay grinding the same spots for the blueprients and materials to create the warframe or weapon you wanted, you will wonder to yourself "what now"? Do you grind for more gear? Get some more fancy augments? But what's the point when all your fancy warframes and weapons only make you more efficient at grinding for more stuff? Now I know what you're saying "Isn't that the basis of any MMO?" Sort off... If you boil it down any MMO is one big quest for loot, but what makes it good is how fun it is to play all the dungeons and missions to recieve these rewards, and Warframe fails it it terribly. This game becomes far too repetitive, you only have a handful of scenarios to play through on missions and the difference between them is barely remarkable. You're still fighting baddies through the same spaceship hallways, just rearranged each time. The warframes themselves are also fundamentally flawed. Each warframe has a unique set of abilities (which three are avaliable from the start, and the last only ebing avaliable when your WF is upgraded with an item that is conveniently found in the cash shop), sure, but you also have a rather limited pool of energy that you expend to use said abilities, and said pool can only be replenished by scarce pickups. So really yuor 'style' is more defined by what wepaons you have painstakenly constructed by grinding for the materials to make... and if you don't like them you're  out of luck. Not to mention the fact that there is little to no emphasis on teamwork on a multiplayer game... I mean they try to do something by making each warframe's abilities varied enough to try and do so, but if you're not sprinting down a hallway and killing things fast then you end up being more of a burden t the team. Same thing applies to pvp, nothing matters but outright damage, and you better built the right warframe for it or it's back to more grinding for you. Then there is the cash shop... while every weapon and frame can be built from materials and blueprints dropped in missions (which takes AGES of grinding) you can instantly buy them in the cash shop as well. This screams play to win in the most blatant way, but since grinding for your equipment is half the game you'll probably come to the conclusion that this isn't worth the time faster if you spend a few bucks. So despite it's flashy looks and first impressions, Warframe is a huge dissapointment. Don't get me wrong, I wanted this game to be good so badly. It's an absolute delight to look at, and the setting alone is quite good, how could you not enjoy what is essentialy a story revolving around an ancient race of alien space ninja? But sadly, the core gameplay mechanics fall short in what is a flawed game. Everything is so polished I can see someone forgetting that they've been running through what is basically the same randomized space ship for hours to find the last few materials for their lazer katana that burns things that it slices through. If only art direction could float a game on it's own, but I suppose if you're going to grind through the same spots for a while they might as well look pretty.

game-hours: 43.6
review: So unless Im mistaken, this game was made by the same people who created UT and the original Bioshock, so, you really have to ignore their past work when playing this game. Warframe isnt "bad" per se, its just not really finished, even now. The recent changes in melee combat fix the games biggest problem (which was its  melee combat) but all the other issues are still there. Ill start with gameplay, because just about everything else in this review is going to be opinion: The gameplay is serviceable, but not well developed, and by that I mean "it plays like something stuck somewhere between an alpha and a beta". The movement is fast, but strangely influid, the jumping and free-running feel shoehorned in and are clunky at best, and the gunplay is efficient but lacks any bite or freedback. One major feature is that the levels are generated randomly from prefab rooms. This means that you can have large labyrinthian levels to run around in, but the the sparse nature of the prefab rooms, combined with the relativly low number of prefab enrivonments (Id say there are roughly 8-10 different rooms per level-type, including hallways and connective elements) means that this interesting idea really doesnt effect the gameplay at all, and can even be downright confusing as you pass through three copies of the exact same room. The enemies are similarly bland, sporting troops, heavy troops, melee troops, and the occasional shield drone. The bosses seem to have fallen into the same blackhole of creativity as well, as they are hardly ever more than meattanks. It is also worth mentioning that while tweaking your stats with mods is easy without paying money, doing literally anything else, from buying weapons to building new warframes (this is especially daunting) pretty much requires money to avoid a hideous amout of grinding. Moving away from the basic facts of the game; I just dont like the way it looks, and the way the world is layed out. There is pretense of a story, but it is wafer thin, the missions reenforces that shallowness by providing no real context for your actions. There is only one voiced character, a sort of operations assistant who tells you when the objective changes, and a few random soundbites from bosses. This total lack of story depth is what makes the second issue in the game's presentation even harder not to laugh at: the aesthetic choices. While Ill admit I like the idea of a living biomech ninja suit, and I do even like a handfull of the warframes, for the most part the aesthetics, especially those found in the enemies and level design, are misguided at best. If you've not played the game before, go look up a picture of a Grineer trooper (the name is just the worst, they should really beat whoever came up with it with a stick). The enemy designs dont convey anything about the enemies, be it their capabilities, their position or rank, or even any kind of information about the nature of their faction. On top of this lack of narrative functionality, they just look downright goofy, as do many of the warframes, as I previously mentioned. Even though Im not going to formally recommend this game, Id still say "go try it". Apparently some people like it enough to pay money for it, and, though I believe those people have a mental illness not yet characterized by science, maybe you, dear reader, do as well.

A game should be in beta for months, just to give players power to try and stretch it to find as many bugs as possible, in this game users actually pay a lot to play a game which does not work, and after some weeks and many (frustrating) updates becomes boring as hell...even if you managed to build flamethrouwers and gu-guns...this is going to be a beta forever, as long as they earn money from people who pay for this buggy and boring game..the classes and the powers are kinda all the same, they just change visual effects.

game-hours: 10.3
review: Sucks
game-hours: 45.4
review: DISCLAIMER: This review will focus more on the negative than comparing and contrasting the positives, well because there aren't many positives. Warframe is a double edged sword. While the game is very fun and addicting, the game requires you to be grinding 24/7, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. However, there is an alternative. Spending real money. The game isn't necessarily Pay2Win because Platinum (The microtransaction currency) is so overpriced you feel discouraged to spend it on something you really, really don't need. If you don't spend that platinum to get a foundation going, you'll be spending too many hours grinding to even get your build going and getting a correct Warframe that suits you. Another upside to the whole system is that you can trade more rare items for platinum, which more or less balances out the system. Today, a Prime Access pack came out (totally optional) that offers you discounted Platinum, and access to all the new things that came out in the update. Well, I had a friend refer me BACK into Warframe thinking that it would be something reasonable like $50 USD. While that's a lot of money, this game does have a $60 value. I figured it'd be totally okay to spend $50 more on the game added on to the $100 I spent on the founder pack a year or so ago. I go to the new Prime access page, and well, it was unacceptable. Utterly unacceptable. $50 for 1050 platinum (1000 for $50 normally, what a discount right?) and the two new weapons, $80 for the new Prime Warframe, the two weapons, 2625 Platinum (A sodding rediculous increase in Platinum to make you spend more money) and a couple PROFILE ICONS. That's not where it ends either. There's ANOTHER pack for $140 USD. Which gives 4000 Platinum, all the things included previously, and get this, some silly customizations for your Warframe, an affinity booster (XP boost) and a credit boost. That's completely unacceptable and you'd have to be drunk or have too much money to know what to do with it to actually buy one of these. And people actually support this? I can't resort to anything but thinking it's blind fanboyism. To wrap everything up, this game is good. It's a fun, MMOesque beatemup that's super addicting and super entertaining to play. However, their business practices are cancer brought upon the gaming community as a whole. Steer clear of this game if you expect anything but grinding and a terrible business model that may be the worst ever proposed in a video game.

game-hours: 1012.7
review: It's one of those neverending betas. Farming is the main concept of the game, and even if you enjoy the fantastic gameplay and the variety of weapons, it forces you to buy slots for them, and its very tedious, also there is nothing else to it, you finish every star system, some lame story arcs that serve the purpose of making you farm even more to unlock more features and that's it, The most outstanding feature of the game is the trading system, if you farm enough, you may get good stuff that you may sell for platinum (the currency you normally would have to pay for with real money) to buy the same stuff at a smaller price and resell it again, repeat this enough times and you will find yourself with enough platinum to buy a house. if you like this kind of game, go for it. i mean its not bad, its good, it feels good to kill stuff, it feels good to have friends killing stuff with you, it feels good to cut enemies, but i wouldn't recommend this game unless is just there to waste time.

game-hours: 67.4
review: PROS: Great PVE Fun Variaty of weapons and frames. mods to enhance gameplay not p2w (its not competative and you can unlock all but cosmetics through grinding) Graphics are amazing and are even better than most AAA titles. Combat is fluid, makes you feel like you are a true Space Ninja badass Lots of missions Consistant updates(Love the new update, I'm in a space ship!!) Addictive CONS: Is repetative because it is infact a PVE game so you will be killing things over and over again. Sometimes get massive lag spikes when playing online. PVP is kinda terrible in my opinion, that's just cause i get owned by people higher level than me. Don't be discouraged, PVP isn't where the fun is at. If you want pvp then play BF4 or something. The Parkour is kinda clunky IMO Don't expect a story unless you want to look it up and read the lore(Don't see why they couldn't of just tried harder for the story, seems like they halfassed it and then gaveup) Because there's no story you feel like you farming for items. Hard to make friends because 1/100 people you play with say hi back and then not respond when i suggest we play again:( May feel discouraged the amount of hours you have to grind for to get frames( but don't be, instead turn that into motivation to achieve your goal in gettting that new frame!) VERDICT: If you go in with the right mindset that this is a free to play game and you dont need to pay for anything to have fun and no one has an advantage over you, because it is PVE and you not competing with anyone, then you'll love it. However, thinking that it'll be easy and that the game will just hand it over to you on a plate is just being naive. This is one step below TF2 and Dota 2's Free to play model. So no other f2p game on steam is better than this one and since tf2 is pvp, and dota 2's a moba, this is the only free option that is a 3rd person PVE game. I have to say this is an excellent, both visually and in gameplay. You'll find this game fun if you motivate yourself to get better warframes and weapons. I just wished they did a better job at the story. Hopefully the updates will fix this. PS. I know I keep going on about the story, but if the game actually had a freakin story then It would be on par with AAA games. TL;DR You get to be a freaking Space Ninja and the game delivers beautifully. Just wish it had a story.

game-hours: 790.0
review: All free games have 2 types of currency, the kind you pay for with real money (Platinum), and the kind you get from playing the game and completing levels. This game is no exception, but there are some companies that take advantage of this and become Pay to Win (Basically, this means that if you don't pay real money, you can't compete with the people that do). Thankfully, this game has a healthy balance. It is possible to get everything (Except cosmetics) from playing the game, in fact, there are even things you can't buy from the market place using ANY kind of currency. All you need is patience. If you don't want to wait, then you can pay real money and get everything then. If you want the Prime Weapons, there are 2 ways to get them: 1) Buy them from other players (This means that there is no set price for any one item, all prices are based on supply and demand and/or the niceness of the seller/buyer) or 2) you can earn them from running missions in the void (The void being a node system that increases in difficulty and offers different rewards for different missions on different difficulties). Do I recommend this game? Heck yeah!!

review: I played this game a while back when it was still in beta. I have to say it was quite addictive and fun to play. If you enjoy the concept of space ninja's, FPS, along with having melee weapons as an option, then you will certainly find enjoyment here. Personally I love the art direction and style of this game, the Frames themselves are designed beautifully. On the flip side, if you are looking for an extensive storyline and/or plot, and character development, or PVP, then this will not be the game for you. Overall though, if you want a FUN game to play, then give it a shot, it is a lot of fun. game-hours: 133.9
review: I started this game back in version 7.0 and it was amazing. I spent enough time on it to make it worth spending cash on it, and it didn't disappoint. When update 10 came out I was a bit warry of the new UI and redone stamina system. But all in all it was still great. Then version 11 came out... They completely remade the damage system, ruining many people's builds, changing the weaknesses of the enemies, limiting your options dramatically. Melee weapons became almost useless, formerly amazing guns were now junk, and everything you spent money on was wasted. The time and effort people put into this game when they loved it, when it wasn't overcomplicated, was good. I loved the game. But change is always make-or-break for anything and in this case it broke me. I'll look back fondly on my time playing the game, but that was a different time. Pros: -Space Ninjas -Graphics -Audio Cons: -Cash items are overpriced -Takes forever to craft things -Takes even longer to get the parts to craft them -Don't even get me started on Neurodes... -Damage 2.0 made things far more involved -All the remakes of the maps are harder to navigate -It's now hard to distinguish enemies from friends, and those from the terrain -Boss changes that make no sense -Harder to navigate the menus than it used to be, your character even gets in the way now.

review: This game was good, but the devs routinely ruin entire characters and horribly nerf abilities JUST BECAUSE A FEW S FIGURED OUT HOW TO FARM A SINGLE LEVEL EFFECTIVELY. That's right. Instead of rewarding players who are intelligent enough to figure out a super powerful strategy, they PENALIZE ANYONE WHO USES THOSE CHARACTERS OR ABILITIES EVEN IF THEY HAVE NEVER IN THEIR LIFE POWER-LEVELED. So in other words, DE is ruining Trinity, Mag and Excalibur's best abilities simply because some people figured out how to power-level a mission called Viver, on Eris. This is bad game development. I am shocked at the poor choices DE has made recently - after such a good update like archwing they go and shoot themselves in the foot like this. PROTIP: IF YOU WANT TO BE A GOOD GAME DEVELOPER YOU SHOULD REWARD INTELLIGENT PLAYERS NOT PENALIZE THEM. You should also not PENALIZE PLAYERS WHO AREN'T EVEN AWARE OF THE VIVER "exploit". I am hesitant to call it an "exploit" because it takes a lot of mods, reactors catalysts and dedication to get a character to the point where they can be useful in a Viver farm. Not everyone even has the mods to be ABLE to do it. But _EVERYONE_ in the warframe community is going to have excal, mag and trinity get nerfed. Everyone suffers even if they've never even HEARD of viver farming. That is bad game development.

game-hours: 82.3
review: 11/10 would space ninja again.
game-hours: 112.6
review: I'm writing this in my first 68 hours and I don't think I'll change my review in the future. I am a gamer that still owns a potato-PC, and when I saw the graphics I was amazed that first of all, I could play it, adjust the settings to Low and run it flawlessly with just 2GB RAM. The storyline is awesome, even though it is divided in quests - which take some time to get them. The third-person view was something that I liked and gave a different look than all FPS games today. Even though in missions I seemed to forget it, there are many ways to parkour your way up a wall, or screw gravity and run on the wall to reach a higher ground, which I haven't seen in any other game. Many people say the game later on gets harder and requires more grinding. I agree, there is the grinding part in the game, but that's for every FreeToPlay game. If you, for example worked hard on a game and published it for free, wouldn't you like to earn some money out of your hard work - perhaps to keep the servers your gamers use? Back to the main point though, if any of you have played "Spiral Knights" - I WAS a big fan of it ONCE - you know that the Warframe's grinding is no match to the "Spiral Knights" one. No, I'm not trying to avoid the grinding matter by providing games with the same technique, but grinding in Warframe felt more rewarding for me, and sometimes even fun (in Defence or Survival missions, the Void. . .).

game-hours: 145.4
review: I have mixed feelings about this game. It's definitely a "pay-to-win" game. Although the action and design can be fun, all too often you come across punishing (not challenging) points of the game can be easily overcome by throwing money at it or will make you walk away annoyed. For some of us, that isn't a problem. For others, we prefer to earn our rewards and the cost financial cost of purchasing the win is often more than one can afford. The FAQ says, "nearly all content in Warframe can be earned over time for free." You can collect credits anywhere, but the only currency that actually matters is platinum and platinum is only purchasable. Multiple in-game currencies is a terrible concept. You can make it available for purchase, but being unable to earn platinum leaves out a good portion of your players. The community is absolutely full of judgemental s. Be prepared. In short, if you're 12 (or have the maturity level of a 12 year old), like gobs of violence in lieu of any form of story, and don't mind buying solutions to all your problems, this is the game for you.

game-hours: 6.1
review: I've recently wanted to play this game agin, because it looks cool and well made. I had the game before but it needed some serious updating (4 gigs worth). Lo and behold, what was I greeted with when i decided to just re-download the whole game? - Start Warframe - "Downloading Updates" - "Updating DirectX" - Checking for New Content (here is where the fun starts) At the point where the launcher searches for new patches, it would start downloading, briefly. Then an error message pops up (one of many probably), and the launcher crashes or forces you to restart Warframe. And here you will be stuck. Some people get the game working after having to re-validate their game folders and having to download everything again, but for a lot of potential players out there, there is no support. Searching the web finds you more unhappy people and unresolved problems than actual solutions. I was furious and disappointed because I actually played this a while back and enjoyed it, but I can just forget about it now, because the errors never stop, no matter what you do, and the solutions (which are quite varied) only apply to some, not all. If you get this game to actually run and SUCCESSFULLY update, Congratulations, but your friends might not be so lucky.

game-hours: 766.4
review: I can not recommend this game to anyone. Clunky mechanics, endless grind, and pay-for-convenience plague every aspect of it. What could have been a tactical, fast-paced co-op game about space ninjas devolves quickly into repetitive combat and boring, efficient farming against waves of grunts that practically run into your bullets. Once you have completed every mission type 10-15 times, you know what you are in for the rest of game. The developers, Digital Extremes, have no cohesive vision for the game's future. Content patches include needlessly redundant features, and uninspired weapons that work in uninspiring ways. They are also rife with new bugs, and poorly balanced. An example would be their much awaited Archwing updated, which introduces a new game-mode that is practically standalone from the rest of the game. There is a massive time gate for even the highest-level players, unless you pay real money, and then once built you must find and then level-up "mods" associated with it and nothing else. The Kubrow update worked the same way. What initially attracted me to the game was it's art direction and pace, but ultimately it's just not enough to keep me slogging through the same missions with almost zero context behind the effects of each one. Don't fall for the freemium trap, avoid this game.
game-hours: 290.0
review: Oh boy where do I even start with this game. The gameplay is focused around drops. That is an issue. Your survivability is focused on getting the right drops, in the form of mods that upgrade weapon damage, mods that increase health, mods that increase shield capacity and recharge rate, mods that increase ability power, duration, blah blah blah. This is all controlled by random number generation, meaning you can get these mods within a few hours or never get them for over two hundred. Oh but it gets better. The drops are then made more power by even more drops. Which fall from the exact same RNG table as the mods which help you out. But that RNG table is also diluted by mods which aren't actually all that helpful and should not be taking up the same slots as mods which are actually helpful yet take those slots anyways. But then you can't actually afford to use those fresh new drops to upgrade your mods. So what do you do? You grind. You grind over and over and over again. You grind for keys to new locations, which you then grind for credits, which you spend on upgrading your mods. But now you're out of things to use. What now? Grind more. This game is all grind. It's not satisfying grind either. The missions are samey, the guns are unsatisfying and unbalanced, melee is unviable and are essentially "Hold down E to be slightly useful" in most cases. The mod system I described above is broken and unsustainable. The company developing it refuses to take big steps to improve their game and when they do it's too little too late. The UI is a cluttered mess. The tutorial explains nothing. The game has sudden frame drops in areas where there should not be sudden frame drops. It also looks like an awful mess. There are very very few redeeming qualities to this game. Feel free to try it but god forbid you spend money on this awful mess developed by an awful company who doesn't understand how to make good games.
game-hours: 755.1
review: Grind, more grind, a bit more, lets not stop there, keep going. The game is mostly made of good ideas with bad executions, they keep trying to reinvent the wheel while still driving.

I think that you should spend your hard earn money on other stuff rather then spending on this game. This game's crafting takes a long time, when it finished, you might not like it, but you waste lot's of times just waiting for this to craft. Time is very expensive in some way. The game is free, but if you want to enjoy this game, only way is to spend money, so i think this game is not very good for you guys to play.
game-hours: 666.0
review: WARBROS #1 Warframe is free-to-play third-person shooter 'MMO' (it's not a legitimate MMO, deal /w it faglords) that has been in open beta for almost a year now. Despite being in "open beta" for close to a year now, much of the game still feels as if it were in early alpha, with many aspects of the game (even core mechanics) being subject to change fairly often. The devs love to refer to Warframe as a "space ninja game" but don't listen to them; they're idiots. (We'll elaborate on that later.) Warframe barely has anything to do with (stereotypical; pop-culture) ninja, and the aspects that do are either terrible or terribly implemented (sometimes both): Melee combat is very shallow and becomes useless late-game; wallrunning and parkour in general is glitchy and unresponsive at worst and gimmicky at best; stealth is a complete joke; and the general aesthetic is inconsistent and constantly slides away from the Japanese-inspired, futuristic bio-mechanical look they had originally tried to achieve. The biggest problem with Warframe is exactly that, though: Inconsistency. The game features strong (and dare I say, fun) core gameplay mechanics, buried under what can most accurately be described as piles and piles of . Warframe's fast and fluid gunplay, movement mechanics and interesting weapon designs are shrouded by, among other things, terrible enemy and level design, very lopsided stat scaling, heaps of grind (with RNG!) and acute lack of meaningful content. Warframe has, easily and by far, bar nothing I have ever played the worst enemy designs I have ever seen. Ever. And that's saying quite a lot, given that I've played games like DMC3, Metal Gear Rising and Ninja Gaiden. Whereas most games with  enemy design have either enemies that are wholly uninteresting and uninspired or enemies that are incredibly obnoxious and frustrating to fight, Warframe instead chooses to gather the worst from both aspects and combine them together into an ungodly -smoothie the likes of which no mortal man should ever taste. Warframe has three factions to fight: the Grineer, the Corpus and the Infested. Each are different, but horrible in their own ways. The common, lower-ranked mooks from each faction have mostly nothing noteworthy behind them (with some exceptions), and mostly shoot/take cover like any normal boring enemy in a shooter. The higher-ranked enemies in each faction are mostly horrendous abominations; I'd prefer being hit in the head with a hammer to fighting most of them. The Infested have a habit of staggering/knocking the player down frequently (the "getting up" animation is outrageously long), but their faction-specific gimmicks include being able to poison the player through their shields (wow nice way to stay consistent with gameplay mechanics there) and draining all of a player's energy and shields (energy doesn't recharge by itself, by the way). The Corpus are ostensibly the least frustrating race to fight, since they don't have ranged hitscan weapons, but they still get pretty ridiculous at high levels. MOAs, the second most common Corpus enemy type are very aggressive and can do extreme amounts of damage at close range, and Corpus Techs, the "miniboss" level enemy is able to rip apart 1000+ shield players in under a second at levels 50+. The Grineer are like everything bad about the Infested and Corpus wrapped up in one neat package, and turned up to 11. All Grineer units have extreme amounts of damage resistance and have very accurate hitscan weapons. They have an entire enemy type dedicated to being mostly invincible and knocking the player down, an entire enemy type dedicated to knocking the player down and then dragging them across the floor for a very long period of time, an entire enemy type dedicated to being very hard to hit and staggering the player (by TOUCHING them, no less), and a fairly common variant called Scorches that can do as much damage as Corpus Techs, but spawn about ten times as commonly. There are also Napalms, that apply a fire DoT to players on hits, despite the fact that no other fire damage in the source does damage over time. This game being consistent as always, I see. In general, enemy encounters in Warframe revolve primarily around disabling the player in a number of different ways and just generally  on them as hard and as unfairly as possible. To that extent, literally every type of enemy in the game has at least one ability that staggers, knocks down, or otherwise stunlocks players. Point being, the enemies are  and I hate them. Let's move on. Warframe has mild RPG aspects in the form of levels and mods. You gain Affinity (experience) for your weapons and Frames (characters/classes, basically) as you use them in gameplay. The primary advantage to leveling your gear is getting mod slots for them (1 slot per level, at a max of 30, doubled by adding a potato to it) which you then fill with mods (which are also made more powerful by fusing other mods into them, making them take up more slots). Although leveling your gear in and of itself is not difficult (nor does it take an enormous amount of time), this is obfuscated by the way that there is no dependable way to acquire anything in this game besides weapons. Mod and item drops are based entirely on random chance, which means that you could probably look for a specific drop for hundreds of hours without receiving it. The RNG in Warframe is the root (albeit not only reason) of the game's inconsistency, and also generates a large part of the game's grind. The developers of Warframe, Digital Extremes (DE) are also just as inconsistent as the game itself. I am not sure if DE are legitimately malicious and want to jew their customers or if they are simply incompetent buffoons, but the fact of the matter is that there is a LOT of potential in Warframe that will most likely not be tapped into by DE. It's disappointing, to say the least. The devs try to maintain windows of communication with the playerbase, but they're rather selective in what they choose to hear, and even more selective on what they choose to do about the things they hear. Progress is often slow, even on pressing issues (there are serious bugs within the game that have remained unfixed after a year) and the developers' priorities often appear askew. More often than not they choose to focus on entirely unnecessary aspects of the game, like adding in redundant melee weapons when melee combat itself is in shambles. Overall, I wouldn't recommend Warframe to anyone at the current. Not with it like this. But if you want to keep your hopes up, sometime in the future the game might live up to its potential and become truly great. Or it'll be dead in the water in a few months because of lack of improvement/further degradation of the game by the developers. This game isn't worth getting into, much less putting 600 hours of your time into. Please kill me.
game-hours: 197.4
review: The Good: Ninjas with every weapon from Bo Staffs to Grenade Launchers being used all at once. Gore-ridden melee combat. Shiny graphics. Customizeable Dojos / Clan meeting places. Fast-paced movement possibilities. Free-2-Play. ----------------------------------------- The Bad: Clumsy-as-hell movement when for example, trying to dash-spin-sword in the air or when simply trying to vault over or onto certain obstacles. Slows down pacing a LOT (even moreso if you have a fast warframe) and kills the mood. You can also get stuck by standing/landing ontop of enemies. Clumsy-as-hell melee. Want to finish an enemy that's knocked down? Good f*cking luck making your character perform a stab. Want to slice at an annoying drone that's two inches above your normal swing sword altitude?`Too bad. Can't jump-attack that thing either without EXACT precision. Clumsy-as-hell networking. Huge part of your players been experiencing devastating STRICT NAT and other critical networking issues even though their ports & firewalls & AV's are open since Beta? Screw that, let's port our broken game to the PS4 instead of fixing stuff. Stupid balance. Huge 500 pound hammer/sword that's intensively clumsy and heavy to the point of causing the entire map to shake, even for allies which ends up making everyone nauseus at every swing:: - 49 damage on one swing. // Small, nimble and far-reaching katana that can attack faster than the eye in clean, forward strokes:: - 85 damage on one swing. Stupid pay-2-win. Spend 200$ to buy everything you could ever want, save for a few exclusive items that are locked by XP.. Which you'll also be able to pay real cash for later Instead of earning them through playing the actual game. Stupid terrain/collission. Did you just slightly bruise up against that slightly bumpy terrain bit while blazing around in action? Good luck to you because you're now gonna be stuck for a good 3-5 seconds before figuring out the combination of spamming attack/crouch/jump to unstuck yourself as the infamous space-ninja that you are. Stupid progression. Everything is a gigantic gamble. Will you get that card drop? Will you get that one treasure room map when using a void key? Will you find blue-prints from that guy within 35 attempts? But no, really, the worst sinner here is the "Mastery Rank". Level up every conceivable weapon there is by killing thousands of enemies and doing dozens of survival/defend runs in order to get a couple of hundred points out of the required half million to make that one item you want. Stupid difficulty. Oh I'm sorry, did you want a line of actual new mobs that come with their own twists, turns and tricks for you to learn and overcome as you grow in strength, just like how you did with the previous enemies? Nope. F*ck that. Here's the old mobs with a 5000% boost in HP and damage while still having that annoying 100% bot aim. Maybe a palette swap or two If we are feeling generous. ----------------------------------------- End note? Fix your f*cking game before injecting it with more cash-cow potential, Digital Extremes.

game-hours: 22.0
review: Time to review a hyper-popular free-to-play on Steam, Warframe (referred as WF in the review). WF is a third person PvE shooter (the camera is over the shoulder), which means that the majority of the time you will team up with a group of friends, or strangers if you aren't as lucky, and blast off some AI controlled opponents. To jump ahead the review - Warframe is a GOOD game, however, some of it's flaws force me to give this game a negative rating. Well, let's begin from the start. WF is a free-to-play game, that uses the microtransaction system to let the developers get some money. Personally, I have absolutely no problems with micro-payments, when they are done correctly. Dota and League of Legends proved that a free game with well done microtransactions can easily bring much more profit than a full priced AAA title. Now, the question is, whether or not the micro-payments in WF are done good, is this game a pay-to-win or can you get all the necessary equipment yourself. The answer, however shocking, is yes. The real money system in this game is actually surprisingly decent. Almost any non-cosmetic items in the game can be attained without spending a dime. Although some may argue that Warframe and Weapon slots (about these later) are really necessary to the game and must be bought with Platinum (the curency attainable with real money), the developers Digital Extremes are unprecedently generous and give out over 25$ worth of Platinum for free to every player. So, basically, you can get any non-cosmetic item in the game for free, and the aferomentioned vanity items or slots can be bought with the free Platinum every player gets. And this brings us to the main problem of this game. Wait, what? Isn't the fact that you can get everything for free a good thing? It is, but the problem is with how FAST do you get anything. But enough about this, lets see how good of a GAME this is. WF runs Evolution Engine, used in Dark Sector and The Darkness II, to power up some of the best graphics in a free-to-play game yet. The game is visually stunning and the graphics really deserve the praise. Since the game is set in a futuristic sci-fi world, the world is free for the artists to explore and reveal incredibly beatiful environments. The missions set in open spaces, albeit theres only a few of them, look incredible. The enemy design isn't something super novel, but still not horrible to look at. The weapons and Warframes themselves look decent, the dark, gritty sci-fi mixed with anciet ninja feeling all over them. Some of the effects are a little bit overdone and you might feel your eyes moving away from the screen since there are so many brightly colored flashes, but they don't ruin the game experience a lot. The sound and music are alright, again, FUTURE screaming and written in all-caps. There are some catchy beats, but nothing too memorizing. Music changes acordingly to action and some of the best tones in the game are the combat music, which is filled with eastern culture inspired electro notes. The shooting itself is fine, not really revolutionizing the genre, but not ruining it either. The powers each Warframe (the costume your character resides in) are usually decently made, flashy and useful. Each player can choose the way they want to complete the missions: a stealthy approach might be better in spying mission, a run-and-gun in extermination and assassination while crowd control specializing "mage" archetypes - in infestation and defense. There is a HUGE variety of missions, each forcing the players to adapt to new rules. The variety isn't lacking in Warframes, there are 16 of them, each with four completely different abilities, so pretty much everyone is happy. But the thing that made my jaw drop was the amount of different weapons. There are so many of them it's beyond counting, and not the Borderlands type of "16 gajillion weapons" which differ only by name. Each weapon looks different, plays different and most importantly FEELS different. Whether it's a standart automatic rifle, a gun that shoots sawblades, dual western-style revolvers, an electro-chainsaw-giblet-whip thingy, a set of kunai knifes or A FRIKKIN' OLDSCHOOL BOW(!), WF got you covered. The weapon system is really worth applauding for, and I'm glad the developers took the attention into a feature most games overlook. Another thing I also want to give praise to the developers for is the randomization factor. Even though you might have to replay a lot of missions several times over it won't get too frustrating solely because the map will be slightly randomized. You might start the mission from the other end, or maybe the assassination target is on a different spot, the map changes slightly each time you play. The PvE aspect is also pretty well done. You can go into a group filled with strangers, queue up with buddies or go in solo (not recommended, as the enemies are pretty darn tough). A teammate guarding your back isn't just someone who adds in damage or works as a live meatshield, they also can revive you when you fall, incredibly similar to Borderlands system, where, if you've fallen, your teammate can get you up back on your feet. Since all loot is visible to everyone, and taking an item won't make it disappear to your teammates, this game won't ruin your friendships as well! So, what's the bad part, doc? Oh, it's bad alright. What made half on my online games unplayable was huge LAG. Now, don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with WF's servers. BECAUSE THERE ISN'T ANY! Yep, the game uses the ridiculous Call of Doody's hosting system, which means that if the game chooses a host who's internet has the speed equivalent of A DEAD SNAIL, the rest of the party is going to lag hard. And the game chooses a wrong host way too many times. But my biggest problem with this game is the one I briefly mentioned in the begining. The way you aquire items. Warframes and weapons are aquired through grinding. And I don't mean the League of Legend's type of grinding, where you play and play and play to get a champion. It isn't even the Korean free-to-play MMORPG type of grinding, where you have to get 10 wolf pelts and each wolf has a 0,7% chance to drop one. This is grinding in it's finest. Or worst. Probably the worst. Basically, while playing missions you will find various ingredients. All of them make no sense, but since this is the "future" I will let it slide. Those components are used for a huge variety of items, but most of the time, to craft new Warframes and weapons. So, you have the necessary ingredients for a Warframe, some of which took more than few runs of a mission, you can add some virtual currency and craft away? Nope, you need to buy an expensive blueprint from the store. Well, makes sense, we have the blueprint and the materials, can we get going? No, no we cannot. We must get blueprints for EACH INDIVIDUAL PART. Three extra blueprints. Alright, how do we get them, you might ask? By fighting overpowered (or underpowered, I've yet to see a decently difficult but not impossible) bosses. Okay, so we kill the boss three times (each taking from 15 to 30 minutes) and start crafting? Only if you're extra lucky. Most of the time, you will get DUPLICATE blueprints, meaning more runs. Usually, you're gonna have to beat the boss about six times to get all three unique blueprints. Alright, NOW CAN WE GET OUR HARD-EARNED WARFRAME? Nah, man, you gotta wait 72 hours. Wait, what? How much? SEVENTY TWO HOURS?? THAT'S THREE DAYS!! Oh and don't get me started on the more difficult blueprints. You have to craft up to six materials, all crafting 12 hours each, so you can craft the item you want. So, you craft ingredients, to add them to other ingredients and buy a blueprint to craft a blueprint to add to some other materials so you can wait seventy f*cking days for an item to craft? What is this, COOKING MAMA WITH NINJAS?! Continued in the comment section.
game-hours: 20.3
review: I'm somewhat amazed so many people enjoy this game so much, as I found it absolutely execrable. With the understanding that my opinion is apparently in the minority, I leave this review to provide counterpoints and warning for those people others call overly critical like me who might be annoyed by the same things I'm annoyed by. The following are my subjective opinions. They annoyed me, but clearly most people don't care. It's also worth noting that I didn't play for especially long, hardly at all compared to my buddy who binged on this game to point of being unhealthy, but to the accusation of me not playing enough and assertions that it gets better later, I would counter with 'if it takes me more than ten hours to start having fun, that's not a point in the game's favor. It can try harder'. So, annoyances: The aesthetic is messy and uncoordinated and often makes navigation difficult, as there's little to differentiate rooms from one another, or the different parts of a single room from other parts. This game made me feel like my dad, who once said of another action game "I go into one room and kill all the enemies, then I go into the second room and kill all the enemies, then I go into the third room and my son says Dad that's the first room". Environments are varied, but they're built from premade segments joined together in random arrangements. Often core level design incorporates unconscious attention attractors like lights and contrasting shapes, but the level design of Warframe can't do so because of the random assembly nature of level construction. In one mission you might be entering a room from one direction while in the next you enter from the opposite, so there are no elements for pointing the player in the right direction. All this makes it difficult to intuit where I've already been at a glance without resorting to the map and objective markers, sometimes in every room. Or I can just follow behind my friend because he's better at using the map than me. Though he's also like four times my level and tends to murder entire rooms before I catch up because he's bad at recognizing that this isn't any fun for me. Smallest quibble here, but I'll add it in the spirit of naming things that annoyed me and might annoy other people: The naming sense is wildly inconsistent. One of the things that made Lord of the Rings great was the attention to names and linguistics. Each name from each culture sounds like it came from a distinct language, but in Warframe every name is a mishmash of seemingly random syllables, which made it hard for me to take anything seriously. Also on design, The weapon and character design for the primary characters follow in the vein of Metal Gear Solid's Cyborg Ninja and the Eldar of Warhammer 40,000, busy and flashy porcelain things built to appeal to the sort of person who thinks scythes are the coolest weapon ever and refuses to accept that spears are one of the strongest killing implements ever invented never mind that nearly every civilization ever fielded them en masse. But whatever, "ninjas" right. Ninjas are all about doing implausible things like jumping on walls and whatnot. Except you can't really do that very well. It is basic game design (as in it is literally taught in design courses) to make the jump button cause the player character to jump higher the longer the button is held down. Warframe does not do this, and the result makes jumping and aerial navigation clunky and unintuitive. A great deal of mechanics have been made of attacking while moving, you can swing and shoot while running on walls and while jumping and while sliding and so on, but all of these actions require the use of the same action button and the result of pressing this button is context sensitive, so whenever I tried to use the movement system, I found myself doing things I didn't want to; often jumping away from walls or running along them horizontally when I wanted to run straight up them. In response to all this, I ended up just never bothering, and would run and gun or stick and move like any other third person action shooter, thus making one of the game's primary selling points moot. I didn't feel very ninja-like sitting on the ground just shooting things in the head like I usually do, but I didn't feel very ninja-like failing to run up a wall for the thirtieth time either. It can be fun to mow down waves of enemies, but it typically requires a firm context or narrative, and Warframe has none. Background is kept exclusively to optional codex entries that I never bothered to read because all the names were ridiculous, and the recently added tutorial only gave the barest glimpse of something actually happening. The narrative consists nearly entirely of 'You're a ninja, get to ninja-ing'. There are no characters to care about or factions to be invested in, there's only you and your ninja powers. There's also Lotus, your weird cyborg mom with a silly hat, but her character is as wildly inconsistent as the naming sense, flitting between cold robotic overseer lines and snappy idiom quips like "Lock and load" and "They don't suspect a thing", said with exactly the same dispassion. The new tutorial levels add some much needed Actual Plot, but it's short and doesn't explain anything, it's more of a template for a future plot than a reason to care in itself, and once it's over, it's back to Go Be A Ninja I Guess. I never understood the point of any of the things I destroyed or the enemies I slaughtered. Enemy design is Fine. Passable. Above average even, considering the average for action shooters is Dudes With Guns and More Dudes With Different Guns. Warframe can boast big fat dudes with guns, dudes with boxes on their heads and also guns, plus robots and alien mutants. AI, not so much. They have the downside of nearly none of them requiring any change in tactics, so they blur together in my head now trying to remember them. The only two seconds of real genuine fun I ever had in Warframe was when I ran towards a group of six guys twirling my bo staff and deflecting their bullets, which felt great, but it was too short and then it was back to mashing the attack button. To block with a melee weapon, you have to equip it, putting your ranged weapons away, which drastically slows the flow of combat. For comparison, in Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine, your ranged weapons and melee attacks are all bound to different buttons, allowing you to use either type of weapon without having to switch to it. This might be more complicated if attempted with a block function (as Space Marine doesn't have one) but it isn't an insurmountable problem. I'd go into ideas but I don't have enough space in a Steam review. Suffice to say, it wouldn't be very difficult to make the enemies more interesting to fight or weapons more interesting to use, but all Warframe has done is make groups of enemies that all do the same thing and aren't especially difficult to take down. I did not encounter any enemies that I couldn't shoot to death like I've done to a billion guys already in Gears of War. Except for the Tenno Hunters. The final straw that made me uninstall this game was when I was playing with my aforementioned buddy when a bunch of radio static happened and the lights went crazy and my buddy got scared. I thought something actually interesting was about to happen, maybe a real challenge I could use my skills to overcome, but then a giant boss appeared and I died instantly without any possible course of action on my part to prevent it. What fun. That was when I completely lost all faith in the developers and realized that at no point had I witnessed intelligent design choices. So that's what I thought of this game. Didn't have fun. Except that one time, those two seconds that I could not replicate afterwards. If anyone would like to dispute my interpretation of my own experience, feel free to leave a comment and I will not read it.

review: Warframe is a free to play over the shoulder mostly co-op shooter game. A basic set of missions and varying ways to upgrade your equipment give some validation for the time you spend playing. The controls generally work well, and there is some fun with the movement and powers. There are occasional hitches with ui changes or gameplay issues as the game still receives active support and developement as it is still an in production game. (Free to play beta). It has gone through it's release but it is still receiving developement to make a final product. Lately, I have fealt that some of the developer's choices are strangely completely off track from what any of the fans want. They seem to rubberband on some issues wildly and change some things so wildly that I just can't keep my confidence in them. The game is okay, and does give some good fun. But over the long term, the game is exactly the same from about two hours of play on to 500 hours of play. It just hasn't grown or given much reason to keep doing the same thing over and over.

Melee is shallow and nonviable, stealth (though for some reason encouraged) is not an option, there is an incredible lack of enemy variety, every single mission type feels the same, the grind-based progression in this game is some of the worst in any game I have ever played, the mod card system is unsustainable, and the developers are completely incapable of making the big changes that need to be made, opting instead to put a band-aid on the issue in the form of borderline-worthless mods. game-hours: 6.9
review: At first look a decent third person shooter/slasher with nice visuals, warframe in time proved boring and painful to me. While I haven't played since around 2 updates or so ago, these are some points about the game. (+) Ninjas, if that's your thing. (+) Katanas, if you like them (+) Clan Social Areas (guild halls) you can build and slam/jam in (+) Very acrobatic, sliding around while gunning down enemies is somehwat fun (+) Intresting variety of weapons and a nice weapon/armor upgrade system (-) VERY grindy if you want to get past the basic equipment and levels (-) Enemies are almost always bullet sponges, or go down too easy, little balanced difficulty. (-) Getting resources to make weapons requires running lots of missions. (-) Lens Flare (-) Boring, Buggy Boss fights (-) Very Linear Missions that throw the same piles of enemies at you each room (-) Buggy in general (though this is decreasing over time) (-) Even though the missions are cooperative, you rarely if ever work together becuase everyones goal is to deal as much damage as possible, though some suits may do healing, and support abilities, or a neutered form of tanking, all players almost always focus on damage. This is a shooter, not a stragetic MMO. (-) STAGGERSTAGGERSTAGGESTAGGERSTAGGER (-) Actaully disorienting on higher graphical settings. (-) No real plateu, or clear goals, just more missions, and more missions and gridning. After you beat the final bosses,and get your awesome loot, there isn't anything to do with it. I do admit that I haven't played extremely intensively, but I've done many missions with friends and a experienced a decent portion of the game. Since I have played some updates have been apllied, but these cannot affect the underlying reasosn why this game isn't really fun for me. It starts out fun, sliding around , shooting and stabing enemies, dashing around the room and jumping, but then after al ot of missions, the enmies start to get dull, the new weapons start to take way to much grinding to get, and once you actually get your shiny new weapon, it starts out as , and you have to 'train' theweapon to even get it BACK up to the level of your old weapon. The entire game feels directionless as a whole, but on the levels themselves, the surrondings are generic sci-fi that funnel you through waves of enmies that most of the time you simply run past to get to the boss, who after being grinded down (or just tossed off a cliff), gives you a small reward, then you dash to the exit, and repeat the entire process, many times over, again and again, until you get a new weapon. Congradulations! you get to do the ENTIRE THING AGAIN, but with a different gun this time. True, you can play this game without gridning and just stick with your default gear, slowly aqquiring new things naturally along the way, but then that implies that you are playing the game for the fun of its combat, which isn't really there. Fighting is often way too easy; with enemies blidnly running into your fields of fire, or walking around corners one by one to be shot. The rest of the time ,yuo can't even show your ace without losing all of your shields, and the enemies can simply stare at you as you feebly attmept tobeat them down. It's a shooter without the need for fast reflexes, strategic thinking against other players, knowledge of your terrain, or anything that usually makes a shooting game fun. A great many people do enjoy this game however, I can't for the life of me see why, it seems more like work than it does play. And this is coming from a guy who plays a lot of MMOs.

game-hours: 943.0
review: It was supposed to be more like a stealth game and now what? Another clone of something else? Maybe. I've played for 2 years (almost) spent countless money on it, but i have no hard feelings because it's freaking F2P they never force or ask you to buy anything. Seriously if you want to achive or become better than others in this game you will need to pay eventually. It's not a big deal, not at all. Only a few bucks? A few bucks will just begin your addction to buy and satisfy yourself and repeat. I've spent approximately thousands and owned a lot of "limited shetys". Noobies see it will freak out literally. For example the freaking Primed Chamber Mod. Developers never put a price tag on it but it got a ridiculous price. I created a clan, which was actually some good memories, that I made a lot of friends and it was fun. After so long this game became boring at some points. Buy the Prime Access, double everything, found the most badass weapon and go through certain best farming maps and call it a day. Seriously is this how games are or should be? I love the design of this game, but something went wrong. It was supposed to be a stealth game but now we are flying in a jetpack suits (some say it looks like Gundam) and gun blazing in the space. Stylish? At least it was because I remembered the title Ninja Plays Free, and I don't actually think the Ninjas fly in jetpacks. I haven't played for a long time but I waited a year to see some improvements on the game play, developers designed a lot of moving method: wall-run, wall-jump, climbing, doging backflip and frontflip. I no longer think thats necessary any more since a grenade luncher is capable to kill anythiing. I see Warframe got a pretty high rating maybe I'm looking at the down sides possibly played for to long and forgot about the joy or other aspects. No I still remembered what I loved, I loved the design, it is absolutly gorgeous and unique. I literally spent hours on costumization. What need to mention is that the colors you put on your frames have limited pallets so if you want some fancy colors you will have to reach to your wallets anyway, things like that push everything backward and annoy me. Pay to win, that's spirit of F2P titles, deny or not. You dont pay or you will have a hard time, and I assume you will reject me with your so promising mental endurance but who wants to play a game with unpleasant experience? So in the end, you go "screw that just 50 bucks" (or something like that) and start to rip your wallet pieces by pieces. For the people who are not wealthy enough to go crazy will end up finding other ways to squeeze some cash into it. In other words to illustrute this addiction, to pay and satisfy, is a drug-like experience, you get on it and you will have a hard time to quite. It was all about glory, and vanity. Obviously a cool dude with stunning color and limited edition sheyts looks awesome than a person merely spent a buck on it and probably looks horrible. There's no arguement with that, just watch when these two kind of players meet together and the cool dude will poke the sheyt out of the noob. Maybe the cool guy doesn't even have to talk, just simply stand beside a newbie and prove everything. If you are a costumer long time ago and still loving it, I admir you. If you are new to Warframe take me suggestion, but I won't force you from trying Warframe. Trust me F2P title is way too dangerous. Even a free phone-game with in game purchase will rip off your kidney no matter how confident you think you can control yourself because I failed too many times. So I believe I'm not the only person on earth who pay in F2P. The point is if you don't want to be sucked into it, don't even bother click that friendly looking "Free to Play Start the Game" button and that goes the beautiful nightmare. Here are my own opinions. Inbalanced Game Play: repetitive, only thing that keeps you come back to the game after you tried everything. The update events, similar to infinite expansion contents but only its free. Events all have the same goals, score to the highest tire get all the reward. Warframe has awesome costumizations, capble for occupy you all day long. Graphics surprisingly nice: interesting lighting effect, structures and vegatations are not bad but consider it as a free to play game they did put certain amounts of efforts to it. Design: unique and eye catching, I played this game in public and gathered people's eyes. Weapons are amazing, but if you got tired of farming you will have to buy it. Every weapons are unique and explorable with the Mod system. Mods provide different effects to both weapons and characters but mod all have potentials to be leveled up. Level a mod will be a pain in the , it is slow as hell and gets eveh slower when approaching the maximum level. Another item that appeared in game was Orokin reactors and orokin catalyst. Both frames and weapons are only capable for 30 mod capacity, which means possibly you can put approximately 4/8 mods on them. Using those two items will increase to 60, which gives you more capacity. It means weapons and frames will become stronger. They are not common, there'are random mission (alert missions) reward and provide as blueprints (aqquired materials, so farming again) , those missions appears more frequently when holidays or anniversaries. Another way to obtain is to buy. General: I had a long term relationship with Warframe, I have witness Warframe's grown, from a crapy game to a shiny title. Yes, I had fun, but I wish it wasn't a Free to Play.It seems a one-time payed game have average better qualities. Warframe is going off from it's original form (personal understanding). Stealth content is just a extra function but I was into more developments of stealth, but no, it's compeletly useless. There are no rewards for accomplish a mission with full stealth, and seems most people are not into it. Now, it's full gun blazing, and our ninjas are flying into the space. It's not my game, I don't make the call but I would rate 6/10, if you need a reference on rating. I'm sorry, I'm disappointed. NOT recommended. Fairwell Warframe ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I reviewed my crtique, honestly I am slightly ashamed of my tone. I should have approached with a more professional attitude but I was emotional, had too much to say. It is hardly a critique because overall it is too subjective. I hope I have provided a useful review necessarily, all information that I mentioned is from personaly experience. Do not be suspecious about any words seem to be insulting or sensitive, I promise the realiability. Thank you.
game-hours: 518.5
review: When I first started playing this game, I thought it was weird. The controls were all far removed from the standard - F to change guns? X to interact? But quickly the game grew on me. Alot. It was all I played for 6 months of my life from late 2013 to mid 2014. It was one of the best games I've ever played. But recently, this has no longer been the case. From the UI Changes, to annoying, impossible to sympathize with characters who completely fail to place as comedic inserts, to enemies that are hardly challenging but incredibly annoying, everything DE has added to this game for a long time has made me fall further and further from the love I once held for the game. Where many times I gave this game stellar recommendations to friends, I can't recommend it anymore. The grind that drew me in has become beyond unreasonable, and I never feel like I'm accomplishing anything anymore. I return to this game every so often looking for nostalgia, wanting to love this game again, but I can't anymore, and I can't recommend anyone play it.

game-hours: 1297.0
review: The game itself is decent, and it's addictive enough for some people to warrant the 900+ hours on record, but the game itself is quite flawed. Large amounts of old or unused content are still in the game, so if you don't load correctly into a map, you might be looking at an old or unused user interface and can't do anything about it. A lot of bugs go unpatched for extended periods of time, and when they are finally addressed, it sometimes feels more like a workaround than an actual fix. What's worse is when this happens to some things that impact the game design itself. I feel kind of bad giving this a negative review, since the developers clearly care about what they put out, but what they've put out thusfar feels almost more like a tech demo with project creep than a full game due to its lack of meaningful content. That said, the game is enjoyable, I just couldn't recommend it to my friends without a laundry list of caveats. Hopefully that list will shrink in the future.

The devs are focused on adding new gimmicks that are separate from the main game or highlight just how undercooked or even broken basic things are.
