game-hours: 309.4
review: This is a great game but the developers don't listen to, acknowledge or respond to their community. It's like they have taken a great concept, then focused on aggressively creating situations for players to pay as much money as possible. This is F2P tactics obviously, but Digital Extremes take it to the 'extremes'... :\ Generally F2P games have some level of balance, and a great example of this would be Planetside 2. This and PS2 arent "Pay2Win" games as people complain, but they are "Pay 4 Convenience". The issue is that DE focus on making this game as inconvenient as possible, and the only way to avoid any inconvenience is to pay money continuously and forever. The more you progress into this game, the more inconvenient it gets (you'd think the opposite). The aggressiveness of the push to spend money by DE is not really apparent until around the 100 hours mark of playing. I beleive the push to make you spend is becuase there is no end game. What you do at the start is the same at the end. If your only a casual player, then this game is a lot of fun and especially so with friends. If you get invested in games then this will likely become compulsion, rather than fun. It's such a shame, because its a great game. But the unethical business model and a clear lack of direction ruins it. In the end, this game punishes you for player more of it.

game-hours: 42.0
review: I have played this game on and off for a while and here is my thoughts on it. Pros: -Fun to play with with friends -free -alot of weapon types from guns to melee -Variety of Warframes -Can play this game to the whole Metal Gear Rising: Revengance soundtrack and make it more enjoyable -Crafting is simple enough to make everything as well as farming for stuff is fun to do. You will have to look up stuff on the warframe wiki as to where the blueprints for warframes parts are and probably have to work your way to said planet but it is all part of the grind. -Graphics are good despite the slight spikes of lag and texture loading -You can trade with other players mats for cash points (platinum) and credits or other materials or weapon blueprints mods or other stuff where you can play MMO Merchant Simulator 2014 to your hearts content. Cons: -As much as it doesnt seem like you need to spend money on this game, you will. I made three guns already and tried making two more until the game told me I need to spend 12 money points to buy two more equipment slots so you will have to do the same for warframes, guns, and melee weapons. You can sell the stuff you make but there are some weapons like the dual wields in which you have to make two of the same gun and then combine them meaning you will have to hock your well grinded guns that you might use later on or buy the points to do it. You can trade stuff but if you are just starting you will have to waste time grinding to get the materials and pray someone wants to buy them from you especially since you dont know how much it would be worth considering there isnt an official marketplace or a guide for net worth of materials. So in short either way you or someone has to pay money to get plat to buy things either for trade or for other things. -Before the major update (recent one) the game was pretty simple and the map navigation was great. Now its confusing for new players as well as returning players especially if you are returning and unlocked most of the map. You will have to unlock it again. -Community is pretty much this. Half against the evil ICE clan making alot of new players believe that this clan is the evil conglomerate in the Warframe universe and will form you against them like its a plot from one of your japaneese animes, Near half of people who played the game for long and only want to help those who are doing high level stuff that yields high rewards or farms, and a really small margin of people who actually help. So if you need help with unlocking other maps especially for defenses and survival maps you have to do to unlock it. -Countless bugs and problems. Next to the lag you will sometimes have, this game is riddled with DDOS attacks (which that large half will say that ICE is doing it) which will shut the servers down alot for you, alot of bugs on the maps that will trigger like doors not opening for you and keeping you from progressing, also if you like to have your computer black out alot this game will make it happen. This has been a major problem after the recent major update, But the worst is the crashes you will have. Finish a mission and you will crash not giving you the rewards and exp and even have the dreaded loading screen freeze. -After the major update matchmaking turned nearly to crap unless you finish the node on the planet. The main way to unlock nodes in this game is to beat the node linking the other ones in which you work your way to either all over the planet or work your way to the boss node to unlock the next planet which is simple. But you will have to wait for a long while or be frustrated because of the matchmaking because the only way to join in an a game in the middle of the game, in which seems more than likely that there is a near full party doing the defense node you obviously cannot solo, is complete that map. So you will have to pray that either A) people join in on the map all at the same time you decide to do that same map or B) pray a few people in the community will spare the time to even bother helping you out. I have tried to finish the same node for the past two days which is a defense mission. Twice I had to wait for around an hour for even one guy to join me in a game just to have the both of us wait 30 minutes hoping someone joins us in middle of game just to fail miserably and with the same complaint about the community could never get anyone to help me out with the map because they either want to do endgame or talk about other things. With the pros and cons in place why the cons have more description than the pros are is the fact i would rather give the full explanation for the cons to give you a better idea of why its a con. I am not saying this game is terrible it is the best free to play third person shooter and the creators of this game deliver what they promise in the third person shooter in which pvp is not a major requirement. When you shove most of the cons aside, the game has its charm but the reason why I wouldn't recommend this game to many is the fact of the crashing problems and major bugs that are affecting the game right now. When they finally fix the problems I might even change my recommendation for this game. But if you have friends who have this game get them together because this game is really fun despite the bugs and crashes. I will keep playing this title until Destiny comes out then this game will pretty much collect dust in my steam library. Edits: Thanks Guru for pointing out the sell button

review: Pros: + Excellent weapon variety + Excellent warframe variety + Vibrant visuals in some areas + Mostly everything cash shop can be obtained free Cons: - Endless grind - Boring enemy variety - So-so plot that is overusing the "awakened hero in troubled times" cliche - Difficulty based off of stat differences - Enemies blend in with the environment due to grays, whites, and blacks being pre-dominant in the art style - Huge focus on grind for it or pay for it model that is thirstier than Nexon - Facebook game style "get the resources and wait 12 hours ~ 24 hours for it to be made" crafting for things as simple as accessing a guild base - Limited inventory slots that can be expanded for microtransactions - Very, very money-hungry - Did I mention it'll make you wait 12 hours or pay roughly 50 cents just to access your guild base faster? - "Hacking" puzzles that attract enemies that can be eliminated by paying tl:dr So-so game at heart ruined by greedy money hungry s who want you to pay for this game with 10000 microtransactions when you could just go and buy other better games. Hell even some Asian-developed mmorpg's brought to the States aren't this blatantly thirsty.

Warframe is a really good game.

review: The game itself is a good example of how F2P should work...everything in the game, from weapons, warframes or even items can be made by yourself using in-game credits and resources you find while playing, you can pay real money if you want to get whatever you want early but is not really necessary so you can fully experience the game without paying anything. Sadly that doesnt mean the game itself is really good, there are just a few maps that you will see over and over and there is no real point in playing the game since there is basically no plot, even though the game is full with lore and no "end game" content, once you reach the last planet and do all missions in it, there is nothing else to do but to keep buying new equipment and level them up and sadly that was my experience, in less than 48 hours i made one new warframe that had one skill that was really powerfull, one sword with a charged attack that could pretty much insta-kill everything (Except bosses) so i didnt really need new equipment after that so it didnt take long before i reached the final planet and finish the last mission and after that....nothing, so i just uninstalled it

game-hours: 13.5
review: I dislike this game for two reasons: 1) if you die, and do not pay real life money to be able to revive, and your teammates cannot get to you in time (maybe because what killed you is now trying to kill THEM) your options are as follows: give up and lose everything even if you spent 20 minutes fighting to a boss and died to him with him at 3% health remaining. That's your only option. Oh, or spend real life money to revive yourself. Yeah, free to play game. Counterpoint you can die a LOT. Because without spending more real life money your weaponry sucks assssss for a very long time, until you have spent hours scouring out of game internets to figure out what the hell to do and how to improve how much damge you do. 2) they give you the option to play a mission in solo mode, sounds neat right? Cool, you can pause the game and get a snack, or stretch, or answer the phone. So handy! Except, in solo mode the missions are just as long as the group missions, with just as many enemies, but no additional ammunition. For some stupid reason, instead of "ammo" coming out of the equivalent of barrels you shoot for loot, there's 4 types of ammo, only two of which you use, and again unless you spend a bunch of real life money your weaponry isn't going to kill guys very quickly, you're going to have a single weapon that's much better than your other one, and the ONLY ammo sources in missions are completely random drops from enemies you kill (if you kill an enemy you might get really lucky and get 30 rifle bullets 1/4 of the time when one of the 4 random ammo types is the loot, but yoiu can get ammo, money, "mods", crafting materials. So that 1/3 of the time that you actually get an ammo drop, only 1/4 of the time is it what you need) If they disconnect "lose ALL progress/time/effort/loot" from real life money expenditures if you die too many times in one day, and if they massively increase ammo drops for solo play this might be a fun game, but as it stands for a casual player there is no way I want to continue playing it. Oh yeah, if you are playing in solo mode and you die you can't even respawn at the beginning of the mission, your choices are "revive" (max 4 times/day unless you spend money, seriously, you can only get killed, in a FPS game with you versus hundreds of enemies, 4 times per day without paying money) or "forfeit". When I realized this, I uninstalled the game and posted this review. That's the most unfun  cashgrab move I've ever seen, in a game that was otherwise fun.

game-hours: 1.6
review: The maps are too big for their own good. The minimap markers are perminently . Sometimes red is an enemy, sometimes its just a door. The markers dont always update so they end up pointing to a location on the visible map instead of marking a direction. Sword combat is fun, but can be very clunky. Sliding requires that you be holding shift and press ctrl, which is hard unless you remove your finger off of the A key and just move forward. Timing attacks can difficult because hack and slash games are just that way. Enemy encounters were infrequent with lots of teammates to do the job. You always have to keep up. Character customization is pretty neat and so is the armor design. You can change the color of anything you want, so you can get pretty cool color schemes. This includes your character's armor and weapons. Unfortunatly the game didnt tell me I would not be able to change class. After having played tutorial it promply asked me which character I wanted to play, with brief descriptions, with no mention what character I had just played. I had no basis on which to chose and ended up getting a female character. From what I've palyed the missions are repetitive and there are litterally like 3 different enemies that just require that you fire at to kill. There is little to no teamwork except for reviving. Teams are spread out among the massive maps and there are little team rally points so they can end up clearing half the mission while you're trying to find them due to the inconsistent, incorrect, map markers. Theres a hacking minigame that was never mentioned and provides no practice or tutorial. I assumed it involved turning peices to form an unbroken line, but that didnt work. The worse thing was I ended up having to do the same mission twice because I couldnt pass the final door to the exit zone because of an invisible wall and ended up spending 5 minutes just wandering around looking for something I might have missed. Additionally, to win a mission everyone must reach the exit zone, therefore if you cant pass the door, nobody can win the mission. If it happens you just have to say bye and disconnect so they can get their rewards and you get nothing. (On my third mission, I made it past a door, but another player couldnt. This was frequent). The UI is pretty confusing at times and finding the starting mission was difficult because you have to remember which planet it was you were sent to. Gameplay itself is alright, but not exceedingly fun. The concept is good, but controls dont complement it. Theres no point in sprinting because you can just flip around 20x faster with arial acrobatics. Not quite fun to start out with. 6/10 Repetitive combat, interesting parkour movement

game-hours: 757.0
review: DO NOT SPEND MONEY ON THIS GAME! This game has game breaking connectivity bugs. Their peer2peer implementation is broken. Strict NAT. DNS Lookup problems. Chat outages. There are times you can connect with someone and then suddenly not connect with the same person. Matchmaking is automatic or relies on chat. There are times chat is down for 12 hours. The chat app itself is terrible. Often times you join a squad then disconnect from them and when you get reinvite Session can't be found. There are times you're in a mission with a squad then host migration separates you from them often times leaving you to solo a mission. Digital Extermes refuse to address these issues because they're too busy focusing on money making bling like porting to XboxOne or PS4 instead of delivering good software. The art is great but their technical (coding, network, matchmaking) team is an utter failure. They'll just say "We're in Beta" or "It's a free game." which is total hogwash because they're accepting money from people. It's not free to people who's paid money like I have. The game is in Delta. Digital Extermes! Don't you think you owe it to your paying customers to provide them with a good software?

game-hours: 1509.5
review: a character has a black hole as face 10/10
game-hours: 467.2
review: After returning to Warframe after a time away from it and logging 400+ hours of play, I can solidly say this game will never be great. The developers frustrate, dissapoint, and hide behind the status of the game being in early access, which has now gone on for a year. Constant game updates and new weaponry do not solve the problems that this game continues to deal with. Missions crash often, it suffers from latency issues often, there is no story, the progression is tedious, grindy, and unfun. Changes to the game come without any compensation and there is no way to respec Warframes or Weapons when the developers feel the need to make changes/buffs/or nerfs. The developers have established a great art style and graphics, but a flawed game. They have no idea where the game is going, all they know how to do is create new weapons and expect you the player to buy more weapon slots on your account to accomodate for them. The game is a hamster wheel. It goes nowhere. This game has no future, it will not be ready this year, I'd wager it won't be next year either at the pace they're going. I'm bored to death of this game. If anything this game needs is for someone else other than DE to be developing it.
game-hours: 25.1
review: Grindfest x P2W
game-hours: 0.9
review: IF YOU LIKE GAY ING PORN PLAY THIS   RIGHT NOW YOU .
game-hours: 10.6
review: While It's initally fun to play warframe once you get past the inital story missions you're going to be quite lost, you really do need to go and look at the wiki to find out just where exactly the game wants you to go. Aside from the three starter suits you're going to have to pay real money if you want a different warframe, or, if you're lucky enough to get a blueprint drop from something, you're going to need to farm difficult missions for hours on end to get the materials and the money you need to build it. This applies to weapons as well. The pay model may be "Pay for convience/time" but it falls into a shady crack where the time you're paying for isn't "Oh, this just takes a while" and is more of "This is stupidly hard unless you've got at least four or five other people to help you and it's nearly impossible to solo it." Pros: Fun gameplay Fair enough blance between melee and the different types of ranged. Interesting concepts. Cons: Missions get repetative fast. It becomes impossible to solo missions after a while unless you've paid for items. Once you use up the inital 50 platinum they give you (Likely buying revive refills) you have to pay for more or get some of the rarest drops in the game to sell. Revive's vanish very quickly and the game seems to want to drain you of them very fast. Once they're gone dying on a solo mission means you have to start from scratch, it's an automatic failure. The game forces you to have people to play with for some of the harder missions. large difficulty spikes mid missions. For example, I was playing defense mission and one wave had enemies that did hardly any damage by themselves, the next wave had a single enemy with a minigun comepletely wreck me in moments without any warning. The weapons and upgrades are costly right out of the starting gate. The game also loves to deprive you of money whenever possible. Very wonky physics and controls for jumping and other aerobatic moves. (Try jumping while you're going into a wallrun, you'll launch off like a rocket.) Overall, fun to be had for a while, but once you get past the story missions you'll see and have a lot of "Insert money here to enjoy game" Moments.

review: Piece of .
game-hours: 10.6
review: While It's initally fun to play warframe once you get past the inital story missions you're going to be quite lost, you really do need to go and look at the wiki to find out just where exactly the game wants you to go. Aside from the three starter suits you're going to have to pay real money if you want a different warframe, or, if you're lucky enough to get a blueprint drop from something, you're going to need to farm difficult missions for hours on end to get the materials and the money you need to build it. This applies to weapons as well. The pay model may be "Pay for convience/time" but it falls into a shady crack where the time you're paying for isn't "Oh, this just takes a while" and is more of "This is stupidly hard unless you've got at least four or five other people to help you and it's nearly impossible to solo it." Pros: Fun gameplay Fair enough blance between melee and the different types of ranged. Interesting concepts. Cons: Missions get repetative fast. It becomes impossible to solo missions after a while unless you've paid for items. Once you use up the inital 50 platinum they give you (Likely buying revive refills) you have to pay for more or get some of the rarest drops in the game to sell. Revive's vanish very quickly and the game seems to want to drain you of them very fast. Once they're gone dying on a solo mission means you have to start from scratch, it's an automatic failure. The game forces you to have people to play with for some of the harder missions. large difficulty spikes mid missions. For example, I was playing defense mission and one wave had enemies that did hardly any damage by themselves, the next wave had a single enemy with a minigun comepletely wreck me in moments without any warning. The weapons and upgrades are costly right out of the starting gate. The game also loves to deprive you of money whenever possible. Very wonky physics and controls for jumping and other aerobatic moves. (Try jumping while you're going into a wallrun, you'll launch off like a rocket.) Overall, fun to be had for a while, but once you get past the story missions you'll see and have a lot of "Insert money here to enjoy game" Moments.

review: It feels like it just gives you loads of bubble gum, you eat it all very quickly because you love it. Then you run out, you can't eat the output of your bubble gum, and your eating of the given bubble gum has made you able to consume the bubble gum with intense speed, too. So you try and try to chew the output of the bubble gum you've chewed, but no spice. As I played this game, me as a player did not really progress, in terms of improving my strategies, or my skills, or my technique. The only thing that had progressed and improved in me when I played was my ability to remember to airkick enemies down, and slide melee around. Also my ability to mash keys. Oh! and to pop life capsules when they're below 50%. Besides that, if you play the game, you're gonna have fun (blindly) for a good three digit amount of hours. But when you're finished with it, you'll feel like you just played farmville, or cookie clicker, or pimp my forma'd items, or dress up barbie.

game-hours: 989.3
review: I enjoyed this game for what it was:a fast third person shooter with lots of customizations for weapons,etc,but as of a few updates ago,developers have been neglecting much needed changes in favor to terrible updates. Worse offender is the "revamped" UI;they went from a simple and fast UI(not perfect,but quite efficient) to a flashy one that requires double or triple the time to navigate thru(which is crucial when you have to manage hundreds of mod cards,etc) and that,on top of being really innefficient compared to the old one,brought issues like motion sickness,extra long loading times,new bugs and glitches,all in favor to a more "consolized" style. The mod card UI also got changed,making a chore to manage the tons of mod card you will get from drops and missions,turning from something that was quick and intuitive from a chore everytime you want to change your loadouts(anbd you need to do that a lot). The only endgame currently is farming Prime gear,which would be ok if it wasnt that the drop tables are completely screwed up because they keep putting new stuff on the loot tables of the same missions,thus diluting the chances of getting what you are looking for(prime gear can be traded,but buying it defeats the purpose of playing,at least for me) Gameplay is still there(and it can be quite fun),but devs decided to bury it under a hideous UI,all for the sake of "immersion";and nowadays you can spend more time trying to set up mods than actually running a mission. As it stands now,PC players are the beta testers for Xbone and PS4 versions.Be warned.

game-hours: 3.1

game-hours: 506.6
review: Read this before jumping to a conclusion. Warframe does a lot of things right, it also does a lot of things wrong that could easily be recified (but aren't). This is a PVE TPS with a lot of RPG elements. This game a lot is more akin to Monster Hunter and Borderlands than any FPS. It plays out like an RPG with virtually no PVP elements. So far there's no problem with any of that setup. It even helps that the aesthetics are amazing. Some of the best art design and graphical quality in any video game. The idea for space ninjas isn't a bad one either. Nor are the controls. Everything plays out more similarly to the trailers than most games. It really makes you feel like a badass. The biggest problem with this game is that it is not accessible to the everyday gamer. This is the main reason I do not recommend it. It essentially becomes an MMORPG where grind for the sake of grinding and get caught in the cycle with not really anything else to do. The early game is practically the same as the end game. You'll spend 100 hours grinding weapon XP to spend another 100 doing it again when you have to reset your weapon levels to make them super powered. There is a "duel room" inside guild HQs (called clan dojos, which are a pretty cool feature) but the PVP interaction is minimal and completely unbalanced. Speaking of unbalanced, the PVE manages to get itself a meta because Digital Extremes (DE) likes to make whatever the newest patch content the most absurdly powerful. Prepare for power creep every 3 months or so that leaves what you just bought almost useless in the end game because there's now something infinitely better. DE's entire marketing system is terribly designed and the 2nd big reason I'm not recommending this. I wish I could say this game is Free-to-Pay, and not Pay-to-win. But that's unfortunately untrue. By locking an actual game mechanic aspect (weapon and warframe slots) behind a paywall without a way in game currency can purchase them inherently makes the game P2W. Not to mention the absolutely ridiculous prices on their purchaseable currency and outrageous prices on the in game items to buy with it. DE's marketing department is clearly not operating on a level it needs to be. And while on the subject of DE's incompetence; they appear to not even have a QA team. Every patch takes 4 hotfixes before things are playable. This most recent one (at the time of writing this it's U14) was especially bad because they started trying to fix what wasn't even broken (the UI). Every time they roll something out there is always more bugs than content or they change something for the worse (Melee 2.0, Shotgun nerf, XP gain nerf) that was actually balanced before. It gets even worse when they argue with their playerbase on the forums trying to justify whatever terrible idea they're implementing despite masses of people telling them it was fine before and no one really had an issue with it. So why do I play this game? Because at its core it has an enormous amount of potential and it really is fun to play with the frames and weapons. The customization is good, the weapons feel good to use, and when you're actually playing it's not a bad experience. Too bad its company seems to be inept and refuses to change the game for the better so its playerbase will stick around for longer than the month it takes them to get bored of doing level III void key runs every day. TL;DR- Monster Hunter + Borderlands + Great Graphics = Amazing potential game that falls flat on its face because it lacks substance that its developers refuse to acknowledge or fix up. I can't recommend this game until it is no longer P2W, has real end game content, and DE hires professional QAs.
game-hours: 11.0

Hmm, glad I didn't buy platinum, which you NEED if you want to get anywhere in the game. A garbage game, with poor service.

review: Warframe is a fun, decent game on its own that's at its best when you play with a few friends and grind for hours on end for new 'Warframes' and weapons. game-hours: 46.0
review: It's enjoyable, it really is, but it all boils down to a boring Numbers game to where you farm endlessly to increase your number to compensate for the enemy's number being higher as you progress higher and higher, all the while waiting for days on-end for the alert that will give you the Mod you want. That's all it is. As flashy and stylish and "cool" as it is, why bother wasting your life when hardly anything regarding what the game throws at you has changed since the game was initially popularized back in, what, 2012 I think? When you really think about it, the game isn't that big: You have the planets' missions and their bosses, T1-T3 Void, Derelict, then what. Nightmare Mode somewhere in all that? Then Clan wars through Dark Sectors? It's all meaningless; there's no endgame worth playing for let alone paying for. There's hardly anything worth bragging about, what are you gonna say, "Hey, I farmed for over 7000 man-hours and my guild controls all the Dark Sectors in Warframe", that doesn't sound like much a feat as opposed to "Hey, I got Rank 1 for my class in Arenas in WoW! I'm also in Grandmaster League in Starcraft 2!" or "I once won a League/DOTA 2 tournament!" You tell me which sounds better. Also, the game would be MUCH more enjoyable if not for the slight "paywall" when it comes to getting a Potato. You either get lucky with a 1 in 500-hours-worth of login rewards to maybe get either one you need (god forbid you get a Catalyst when you wanted a Reactor after thousands of login reward lottery attempts), you wait day after day all-day long hoping that an alert pops up that rewards a Potato or wait for a Good Friday all day long for the Alert that is guaranteed to reward it, or just simply buy it and save all the time in the world. Sure, you could buy them from someone else, but they're expensive man, and if you're like me and in the gutter, you won't have much to offer for a Catalyst. You'd be grinding for days, trying to farm for a decent mod, upgrading them and trading them off before getting a Potato this way. And if you think you're gonna get anywhere without Potato'ing your Frame and/or Weapons, good ing luck with Level 30-50 areas, you'll be doing very miniscule amounts of damage to the bullet sponge enemies and be miserable because you know you can't do anything to increase it further. But let's say you do eventually get that Catalyst(s)/Reactor you've so desperately been wanting for such a long time. Well then, back to farming for mods for the next few weeks! It's such a waste of time. Another thing I dislike SO MUCH about this game is the reliance on alerts and invasions to obtain certain items, especially Auras which are usually the staples to most Builds. It's so mind-boggling for why someone would think this was a good idea. A decent game, F2P or not, should have everything be available to the player and be within arm's reach. "BBb-BB-B-bbBUT IT'S A FREE-TO-PLAY GAME, HOW ELSE COULD THEY MAKE MONEY??!one??!1?!?" Please stop using this as an excuse, Path of Exile does just fine without game-changing premiums (aside from Stash upgrades even though you can simply make Mule Accounts for free). So does Dota 2 and Team Fortress 2, granted they would succeed even without premiums. "But that's only a problem to you!" Believe me, most people that didn't Potato their stuff don't even realize they're stuck in a rut, or they have a friend to help them/give them one. Whatever the case may be, it's still an objective design flaw. "But people might find farming fun" I'm not saying farming is bad, I even like the idea of progression more than the next guy, but progression in Warframe is like a toilet pipe that hasn't been cleaned out in decades so it's clogged with solidified feces and hair clumps and urine, and at some point, someone drilled into the pipe behind the clog and poured concrete into it and sealed it up. If you haven't guessed already, the rushing water is your progression, the clog is the amount of farming you have to do to get to where you want to go, and the concrete is the "Potato Paywall" as I'd like to put it, and you pay money to get a plumber to clean that  out or take classes on plumbing to do it yourself which correlates to waiting the long wait for alerts/invasions. And then you come to the realization that you spent all that effort to declog a toilet that isn't even yours which corresponds to why you should even play Warframe in the first place.

Unbearable to play now goodbye Warframe :'(

review: I enjoyed this game for what it was:a fast third person shooter with lots of customizations for weapons,etc,but as of a few updates ago,developers have been neglecting much needed changes in favor to terrible updates. Worse offender is the "revamped" UI;they went from a simple and fast UI(not perfect,but quite efficient) to a flashy one that requires double or triple the time to navigate thru(which is crucial when you have to manage hundreds of mod cards,etc) and that,on top of being really innefficient compared to the old one,brought issues like motion sickness,extra long loading times,new bugs and glitches,all in favor to a more "consolized" style. The mod card UI also got changed,making a chore to manage the tons of mod card you will get from drops and missions,turning from something that was quick and intuitive from a chore everytime you want to change your loadouts(anbd you need to do that a lot). The only endgame currently is farming Prime gear,which would be ok if it wasnt that the drop tables are completely screwed up because they keep putting new stuff on the loot tables of the same missions,thus diluting the chances of getting what you are looking for(prime gear can be traded,but buying it defeats the purpose of playing,at least for me) Gameplay is still there(and it can be quite fun),but devs decided to bury it under a hideous UI,all for the sake of "immersion";and nowadays you can spend more time trying to set up mods than actually running a mission. As it stands now,PC players are the beta testers for Xbone and PS4 versions.Be warned.

game-hours: 33.1
review: Warframe is special. Not good, not bad, not awful or excellent. Special, like the special little child in everyone knows. This doesn't have to be something bad, sometimes this special little child can be quite fun. Sadly in case of Warframe, it's 50/50. Warframe is a great game with great gameplay and great design, which suffers from it's constant beta state, it's awful grinding and it's hellish amount of bugs and all of these bad points after being released over 1 year ago. The gameplay in Warframe is very fluent, even if you tried to stealth your way through enemies and the remainder of your team isn't. The amounts of weapons is unexpectedly large in the game's early days and it just grew just bigger, which is great. More weapons means more option in ways of killing enemies. The maps may seem repetitive at first, but once you pay actual attention to it, you'll find many new places which you previously missed. But all of these great aspects of this game seem to wither in comparison to all of it's bad points. You will need to grind long, very very long. Even with the resources collector, you'll still need long. You will have to beat the same boss so often just to get all the pieces of one Warframe, that you can beat him blindfolded. But worst of all are the bugs..... just so many bugs. Especially after any form of update the game becomes almost unplayable for about 2 to 3 days. I would like to continue the game, I would like to see more people play it, but what I would like more is to finally see that Digital Extremes to grow a pair and finally stop working on content and start cleaning up this mess. Because once it becomes bug free, this game will be great.

game-hours: 46.0
review: It's enjoyable, it really is, but it all boils down to a boring Numbers game to where you farm endlessly to increase your number to compensate for the enemy's number being higher as you progress higher and higher, all the while waiting for days on-end for the alert that will give you the Mod you want. That's all it is. As flashy and stylish and "cool" as it is, why bother wasting your life when hardly anything regarding what the game throws at you has changed since the game was initially popularized back in, what, 2012 I think? When you really think about it, the game isn't that big: You have the planets' missions and their bosses, T1-T3 Void, Derelict, then what. Nightmare Mode somewhere in all that? Then Clan wars through Dark Sectors? It's all meaningless; there's no endgame worth playing for let alone paying for. There's hardly anything worth bragging about, what are you gonna say, "Hey, I farmed for over 7000 man-hours and my guild controls all the Dark Sectors in Warframe", that doesn't sound like much a feat as opposed to "Hey, I got Rank 1 for my class in Arenas in WoW! I'm also in Grandmaster League in Starcraft 2!" or "I once won a League/DOTA 2 tournament!" You tell me which sounds better. Also, the game would be MUCH more enjoyable if not for the slight "paywall" when it comes to getting a Potato. You either get lucky with a 1 in 500-hours-worth of login rewards to maybe get either one you need (god forbid you get a Catalyst when you wanted a Reactor after thousands of login reward lottery attempts), you wait day after day all-day long hoping that an alert pops up that rewards a Potato or wait for a Good Friday all day long for the Alert that is guaranteed to reward it, or just simply buy it and save all the time in the world. Sure, you could buy them from someone else, but they're expensive man, and if you're like me and in the gutter, you won't have much to offer for a Catalyst. You'd be grinding for days, trying to farm for a decent mod, upgrading them and trading them off before getting a Potato this way. And if you think you're gonna get anywhere without Potato'ing your Frame and/or Weapons, good ing luck with Level 30-50 areas, you'll be doing very miniscule amounts of damage to the bullet sponge enemies and be miserable because you know you can't do anything to increase it further. But let's say you do eventually get that Catalyst(s)/Reactor you've so desperately been wanting for such a long time. Well then, back to farming for mods for the next few weeks! It's such a waste of time. Another thing I dislike SO MUCH about this game is the reliance on alerts and invasions to obtain certain items, especially Auras which are usually the staples to most Builds. It's so mind-boggling for why someone would think this was a good idea. A decent game, F2P or not, should have everything be available to the player and be within arm's reach. "BBb-BB-B-bbBUT IT'S A FREE-TO-PLAY GAME, HOW ELSE COULD THEY MAKE MONEY??!one??!1?!?" Please stop using this as an excuse, Path of Exile does just fine without game-changing premiums (aside from Stash upgrades even though you can simply make Mule Accounts for free). So does Dota 2 and Team Fortress 2, granted they would succeed even without premiums. "But that's only a problem to you!" Believe me, most people that didn't Potato their stuff don't even realize they're stuck in a rut, or they have a friend to help them/give them one. Whatever the case may be, it's still an objective design flaw. "But people might find farming fun" I'm not saying farming is bad, I even like the idea of progression more than the next guy, but progression in Warframe is like a toilet pipe that hasn't been cleaned out in decades so it's clogged with solidified feces and hair clumps and urine, and at some point, someone drilled into the pipe behind the clog and poured concrete into it and sealed it up. If you haven't guessed already, the rushing water is your progression, the clog is the amount of farming you have to do to get to where you want to go, and the concrete is the "Potato Paywall" as I'd like to put it, and you pay money to get a plumber to clean that  out or take classes on plumbing to do it yourself which correlates to waiting the long wait for alerts/invasions. And then you come to the realization that you spent all that effort to declog a toilet that isn't even yours which corresponds to why you should even play Warframe in the first place.

game-hours: 6.2
review: To be honest, I think I expected more of this game than I should have. My biggest complaints are that the levels are all pretty much the same 5 things over and over again, and that the microtransactions are really over the top. I typically don't mind microtransactions all that much, but it's super obvious from day one that they purposely made it difficult to get resources for items so that you would buy them from the Platinum store. Want a new armor other than Mag? Have fun grinding for hundreds of hour just to get one part. However, I love the art in this game, especially on the Tenno, and I think that combining parkour with a fast-paced action shooter was a good idea that got butchered by the paying aspects. If they removed all the microtransactions and sold it for 35 bucks, I would buy it again and play it in a heartbeat. TL;DR- If you don't mind being relentlessly nickled and dimed to death or are a fan of P2W games, you should definitely try it.

review: Bugs. Bugs bugs bugs bugs, and more bugs. This game has more bugs than Assasin's Creed Unity and Halo at launch. Combined. Nothing more frustrating that completing a mission objective and geting stuck in the floor on your way to the exit. This happens way too much, and there is no simple unstuck button. You either have to wait for enemies to kill you (if there are any around), which sometimes fixes it, or abort the mission losing all rewards. Other than frequently getting stuck in the floor and other game breaking bugs, this game has potential to be fun. review: I enjoyed playing, but they use every trick in the book to get your money, making the game almost unplayable for free. All in all it is a fun game but they got too greedy and now I don't play it any more. I imagine it would be less expensive as a monthly subscription game than on its current model. Oh and also the multiplayer is a bit glitchy/frustrating. If your friend drops out of your game, they may as well quit because they have lost every reward up to that point & all of the enemies have been revived & are COMING TO EAT THEIR FACES. Out of interest these are some of their methods to grab money: - Limited lives per day, and choke points late in levels so you are forced to revive (revives cost money) - The drop rate of good items (weapons etc) is rare to encourage you to buy them with money - In-game money will usually only buy you a blueprint of something, which you must then craft, costing EXTRA in-game dosh and items - Crafting (which you have to do to get your new weapons & suits) takes hours/days of real time but if you use money you can bypass the wait - Pets need daily 'medicine' that is expensive with in-game cash, but also available for money - Some rare items are only available as rare rewards from places you can only go if you get a rare drop, and have a limited life span (eg 24 hours) before they are destroyed from your inventory

game-hours: 606.9
review: This game is very simplistic. >Play Mission >Beat Mission >Get Materials >Repeat Infinitely the only time id actually recommend this game is if you need something to play for a month before a real game releases. When you play it for the first time it will feel more like an addiction than anything else. As a F2P it does its job well in keeping things simple enough for the new player to want and obtain, but have also designed things in a way that take time.... albeit monotinous (grindy). When this game starts to make you feel like a robot by repeatedly doing one thing in hopes of obtaining something while feeling no emotion is different for everyone but the end result is the same.... you get burned out. At this point you either quit or you start dropping money to speed things along, which actually isnt going to help anything because the game is still the same. If i was to describe the game when i first started playing it i would say it was "A super awesome space ninja shootem up with potential". But to describe it now after spending more than enough hours to justify an honest review i would say it is, "A Space Ninja Dress Up Game That Slowly Decreases in Enjoyment". The levels are comprised of Blocks/Tile Sets that will be randomly pieced together for each mission. Doesnt mean the enviroment is randomly generated. You are still essentially on rails, but you may pass through 2 or three rooms that look the same before you finish. The enemy Ai is standard. When they tweak difficulty for a mission they dont make the enemies play smarter, they just make them hit harder. There really is no niche playstyle. You just assemble an oufit that lets you kill the most things as fast as possible and thats it, anything other is just a handicap/vanity item. This game also has alot of powercreep due to the way its designed and the amount of new content pertaining to weapons and frames that is released in a rather short amount of time. Now back to the top. I said this game was very simple. When you play this game the only desire to keep playing is to farm materials to make more items (weapons, frames etc.) because "farming IS the game". The crafting isnt interactive and there is nothing tied to crafting other than the materials needed. Its just a content timer. You get materials for a sword and now you have to wait 12 hours for it to finish.... or use real money to purchase 2ndary currency to bypass the timer and get it instantly. When you farm something in a game this simple its not rewarding to obtain it, its more of a relief as in "Omfg im so glad i do not have to keep doing that one mission". This game is not varied nor complex enough to warrant this much grind, the only reason the grind is in place is to make you more susceptible to using real money to get the items in the game. But this is a F2P. And before you realise it will become a very time consuming dressup simulator instead of a adrenaline infused challenging space ninja shooter.

review: It looks great and the twist on an FPS is very imaginative. The maps are gorgeous and the MP teams kept small almost like co-op but you do kind of get herded in the direction the game wants you to go. Make a wrong turn and you either fall off the map to your death or end up in something that resembles the survival mode of a zombie shooter. The power ups and skill trees are a bit wonky to figure out as well. I also experienced a lot of unintended rolls when I wanted to slide so pay attention to the controls. It's a pay to play game, however, so you will hit the wall unless you shell out some cash.

game-hours: 14.6
review: This game is nothing more than a pay-for-items grindhouse. While the gameplay is decent, the tantalizing lack of good items early in the game will have you spinning wheels trying to get things to craft, and then waiting 12 hours to craft something, and how you have to buy (with cash money) all the upgrade slots on your guy and inventory. The prices for all of the items is inconvieniently designed to keep you buying the in-game currency, as you will never come up with an even amount that will allow you to spend it all, unless you buy things that should be included anyway, like color palettes. This is my honest impression of the game, that it is solely designed to be a "you can skip the grind for three easy payments of the low low price of $19.99!" but here's the thing: the entire game is an unabashed grind. I thought the story and gameplay concept was interesting, but the business model feels like "give us more money" disguised as a game. It might say "Free-to-Play!" but it would be more accurate to say "Pay to have fun!" Skip this game, go buy a real game if you are tempted to buy any in-game items

game-hours: 150.5
review: First the good parts of this game. Game play is fun, Landscapes look good, Weapons and armor customization are almost limitless. Now the bad. Ninja's in space is kind of wierd, as are the biotech visuals for the Warframes. I can look past that. Network code is buggy with regular failures to join sessions and disconnects for me and my clan mates. Squad population levels are very slow to update making it confusing and annoying trying to join squads. And I could get past all that too. What makes this a negative review for me is the Rank Up mechanic that is a challenge you have to complete to advance to the next level. You can only perform this challenge once every 24 hours. What makes this bad is the amount of time requried to achieve enough XP to take the challenge, for me this was over 20 hours of game time to reach Rank 2 and that was with the help of my higher level clan mates. I then failed the challenge twice because of inadequate gear and a 3rd time because of the above mentioned network glitchiness. After 3 failures over 3 days I'm annoyed. Annoying potential paying customers is not a good way to run a business.

game-hours: 59.5
review: the only time you'll have fun is when you're not playing this game
game-hours: 93.0
review: To be honest with you, I have given this game a chance and there's something about it that I don't like. I can't quite put my finger on it, but it's there; its omnipresence is what drives me away from playing this game on my own. Granted, I do play when my friends invite me to play with them, but again, there is something, SOMETHING, that prevents me from getting into it. I've noticed a few things with the game, one of which is my eyes always hurt when playing this game due to the sheer amount of information appearing on the screen (explosions, enemies, etc) despite the fact I am running this game on the most minimalistic settings. This is the only game I've ever played where my eyes physically cannot handle the information on the screen and I have to stop and look away every few minutes in order ot be able to continue playing. The story and gameplay are solid and the customization options are great for whichever warframe you want to play. However, the sheer amount of grinding required to get all the resources to build each warframe and weapon is borderline ridiculous (Destiny on PS4/Xbone is much worse), but the microtransactions within the game allow you to acquire the gear you need. The warframes themselves are each unique and have their playstyles that will appeal to different players; whether you want to be a AOE control specialist like Nyx or a Bruiser like Rhino, there is a warframe in the game you will enjoy. The weapons are vast and pack a ton of punch with a wide variety of weapons; bows, pistols, quarterstaffs, etc. Unlike Destiny, this game actually has variety (and a story) in its missions and strays away from the linear go from point a to point b and kill everything type of mission structure. There are capture missions, control missions, assassinations, all of which are incredibly intense and do require teamwork (and maybe strategic planning if you're doing higher level stuff) in order ot pull off. I can understand why people would think the story is interesting but it doesn't appeal to me; I just want the loot and move on. Some of the missions you play, like defense missions, are incredibly easy with the right combinations; my friends and I pick warframes with aoe pulls and stun locks and kill everything relatively easily. Although not technically an exploit, its something that the devs could use to think about how to retool the warframes for certain missions to actually make thme a challenge instead of a snorefest of stun locks; maybe certain warframes could be banned for those missions, maybe have the stuns last a static amount of time and increase their cooldowns. IDK, I'm not the devs, but from my experience, those types of missions are incredibly boring with high level stun locking warframes (although it is an easy way to grind up loot and get exp, it would be more fun and better IMO if it was more challenging). Another problem with this game is the leveling system; it takes too long to level anything and coupled with the endless grinding of loot with seemingly no endgame, it gets kinda boring after a while. Although you can easily level by playing high level missions with other high level warframes, playing alone and trying to level up is a tough task. It would be better to increase the amount of exp you get from lower levels when you are alone (they do give a fair amount I'll admit but an increase would be appreciated) instead of having to repeat the same missions over until you get to an acceptable level. Lastly, since the game is still in beta, there are a ton of glitches. I can't count the times I've fallen through the floor, lagged out of a session, or have bullets go through enenmies and do no damage. I heard a rumor the game generates the world as you play it 9not if it's true) but I believe that is the reason the game glitches so much. The game should premake the maps before you load into the session as it would prevent those gamebreaking bugs from occuring as often. Or even better, actually have prebuilt maps like they do for defense missions and expand on them. In short, it doesn't seem like the game can handle the generated maps alongside the gameplay. That's all I'm going to say about this game for now; there are other problems I have with this game but none come to mind ATM. In summary (tl;dr): If you enjoy grinding you'll love this game, if not, go play something else. + Tons of Customization + Wide Mission Variety + It's free! - Way too much grinding - Microtransactions (optional, but I personally believe they shoudn't exist in any game) - No endgame whatsoever - Glitchy at some points 5/10
game-hours: 59.3

game-hours: 251.7
review: Personally, I love this game. Space ninjas, magic, and mass murder is pretty damn great, However, it has some game breaking bugs that always coincide with events. I had a party bug that made me go solo always, which was no problem, but running a melee only interception is ridiculously difficult. If you're gonna hold an event, make sure that your game doesn't break during it. Seriously. Anyway, I have no other complaints because this game is amazing, but devs, I understand the weekend is your break, but the events usually start on Friday anyway. I really hate that. I really don't wanna play this game because it's gonna suck me into it again, and then break and I"ll be left scratching my head.

review: There's literally only one problem of the game and it's based individually on each person. How far are you willing to go? After completing Weapon Mastery of over 60+ weapons, I can say that it is in fact based on what you're willing to do. The game-play does get repetitive after reaching your first mastery; however, people usually subside this repetitiveness by playing a different style, warframe, or using a different weapon. Dueling is another way, but in the end, I don't expect this game to go competitive where cash prizes may be concerned.
game-hours: 391.3
review: Ignore my playing hours. I've been playing this game every day for 8 months now. First impression: Highly satisfying game. You get to choose one of the three starter Warframes, primary rifle, sidearm and melee weapin with different abilities and properties. As you proceed, you will feel a sense of satisfaction is finishing missions, progressing through the star chart, acquiring new weapons and Warframes along the way. You get a sense of mysteriousness of the story and also you will know that this game has a very deep story-telling waiting to be told. Awesome graphic and sound effects too. After playing it for some time: ADDICTION Yes, you wanna play it again and again and again. Spending hundreds if not thousands of hours to acquire that one weapon, that one part of a Warframe. GRIND AND GRIND AND GRIND until you hate the game. After that you hate yourself.... But DAMN after all that griding, now you have a new weapon, a new Warframe. It feels kinda worth it. You feel like starting a new mission...

review: wwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww
game-hours: 3110.1
review: I guess WarFrame is a PVE style game that puts players through a lot of missions & alerts that are basically all the same from the lowest level ones to the very highest. There are currently 4 or 5 different types of missions which range from Exterminating enemies, to capturing wanted enemies & killing enemies to keep your oxygen levels up. WarFrames can all be obtained for FREE or by buying them for a CASH SHOP currency called Platnium. Most players find them as it isn't hard but it can be very very repetative (The whole game is very very very much so) At this time there are a range of 17 or 18 frames available to players & each one has abilities that are unique to that frame. Weapons & WarFrames can be upgraded by adding or removing mod cards that players get while doing missions (They are dropped by some of the enemies) This can give the weapon extra attributes that can make it do a few very helpful things like dealing certain types of damage. (Like Radiation damage or Viral damage etc) The level system in WarFrame is a bit different from the sort most people will have encountered in most other games in that a player gains Mastery Points only by actually using weapons & frames so they level up. Everything has a level cap of level 30 as far as Frames & weapons go & ATM the highest level available to players Mastery is level 15 or 16 (Cant remember atm sorry) WarFrame was a let down for myself as I have been playing for some time during it's development & it seems to have stalled hard. It has been turned into a grind fest with players having to basically do the same type of missions all the time from the vey lowest levels to the very highest. I wouldn't recommend the game to people I know in real life as it currently stands, & hopefully the developers will find the right track & make the game good again

game-hours: 144.9
review: People have their opinions, some enjoy grinding all day. Some don't. Some are fine with the simple enemy design Some aren't. But when you make people have to pay to continue progressing... Nobody enjoys that. This used to be one of my best go-to games if i just felt like a "kill everything in creative ways" mood. However with the added inventory system that requires you to buy space with platinum i cant progress. As much as I love this game, you cant call it free to play unless you're fine with about 100 hours of gameplay. The inventory system is a way for the creators to milk as much as they can from the players while still passing off the game as free to play instead of just making an initial fee to download it. I don't know if this was recently added or has been in since first created, all i know is if looking for a game you can pour a lot of hours and really get into this is not your game unless you're willing to pay.

game-hours: 4.6
review: I played for a few hours until I noticed my revives were permantely decreasing. Apparently, Warframe gives you 4 revives per day and once you run out you automatically fail missions when you die. From what I've read online your 0/4 revives are replenished daily (a 24 hour cycle I assume). You get 4 lives a day, and every death afer the 4th is an instant mission fail. So 4 tries total across ALL missions you want to play (not 4 per mission, 4 TOTAL), then 1 try per mission attempt after that. Basically, if you want to play 10 missions today you get 4 revives (not 40) just 4...lol. The game lets you buy revive refills for money (currently priced at 12 platinum. You can buy 75 platinum for $5). I can't recommend a game that sells revives and forces players away. Why in the world the developers thought this was a good idea is beyond me. They are esentially forcing players to take a time out for 24 hours if they die too many times...and considering how punishing the game is towards melee I find this baffelling. (The melee combat is very fun and is the main reason I got into the game.) Why oh why would anyone force their player base to take a 24 hour break from their game boggles my mind. If they remove this mechanic I'll consider reinstalling the game. (I was also really looking forward to playing with the little mech and animal companions you can get.) Oh well, there are plenty of other games out there for me. Wouldn't surprise me if this game is completely dead in less then a year because of the revive system. Forcing your players away...that's a new one lol.

review: I know I only spent 3 hours on the game, but trust when I say that this game isn't all its cracked up to be. And let me list down why: -There's no enemy variety. Every enemy looks the same. They also have the same strategy. Go to you and shoot. Most of them act as bullet sponges, and the easiest way to die is when they surround you. Sadly once you figure their tactic the game becomes child's play. -Even though there a different worlds to go to and complete missions almost all the worlds recycle the same levels. Just with different objectives. -The game looks TOO GENERIC. There's nothing in this game that stands out. Its your standard issue Sci-Fi aliens, characters and weapons. They don't look special. -Since the game is in Open Beta (if I'm not mistaken.) I noticed a bug that made me restart the game over and over, through the ALT+F4, cause the game just freezes. If not freezes my character just gets stuck for some reason, BUT I can still access the pause menu. -I also found co-op annoying. Since there is no proper matchmaking, the game tested my patience, and I gave up and I decided on playing the game Solo. -The missions all feel weak. There's nothing new or innovative that is brought up in game, instead we get AGAIN, standard generic missions, mainly: a) Kill Everyone, b) Kill the specific person, c) Save this person, d) Defend this location, Too name a few. -Free to Pay Elements. (Noticed I said Pay instead of Play, because I support F2P IF ITS DONE RIGHT, THIS ONE IS NOT. BECAUSE...) I noticed that most guns are locked off, while the guns that are unlocked are guns that require getting the premium currency, And any amount of grinding won't get you close to what you need. So they start adding paywalls, discretely. And maybe you could avoid them but that would allot a lot of... -GRINDING. YEP. GRINDING. Most levels are hard without the proper equipment, and to get the proper equipment you grind for XP (to unlock them) and Money (to buy them) OR YOU CAN PAY. But the game has atleast a few things good about it: +Graphics. +U.I. +Fast Load Times.

game-hours: 408.2
review: Ninjas Pay Fee
game-hours: 1029.1
review: As of writing, Warframe is post Update 13.2 Warframe has been an ever evolving game since becoming an open beta F2P game, and looks good even with low settings. Not many games out there give the player as much freedom of movement outside of sandbox games. Graphics uses the Evolution Engine that can be very much a powerhouse when settings are placed into the highest settings. The lighting is very vibrant and gives a certain shine that makes sparks and powers very visually extraordinary. Bloom can be overly done though, especially with a few moves. There may be some noticeable clippings in game, but these can be easily missed. In addition, there's a field of vision slider, remappable buttons, and controller support that can make the experience smoother. However, the in-game audio input can be a bit lacking in quality and may not pick up proper speeches. Also, the game is P2P, not on a dedicated server, so there may be lag depending on the host, but when things are at a low ping (which can be set as the search requirement), it can be buttery smooth. Gameplay is the highlight of the game, making it all very fast pace and satisfying to either be a solo ninja or in a small group going up against a small armada. Melee 2.0 as of Update 13 has made melee very visceral and impactful. The guns and frames have some small and big differences, making it a unique experience once more frames and guns are discovered and created. As a space ninja, one can wallrun, backflip, barrelroll, and even stealth takedowns. That being said, the opposition can be quite resourceful and relentless. There are enemies with toxic auras that make close combat very risky or long range snipers that can take out shields for the rest of the army to gun a player down. This is still a game that is PvE at heart though, so don't come expecting a huge PvP scene as the weapons and frames are not scaled for great PvP spectacles. However, what has to be addressed is the elephant in the room of the F2P model. Yes, this game can be a grind with the need to find materials and modules to improve your warframe, arsenal and/or consumables. There is a pay area that uses Platinum, however, this currency is tradable in game, so with good modules and parts, they can be traded for. However, some equipment and frames can be very costly, In addition, after gathering resources to build a frame or weapon, there's a waiting period for the item to be crafting, which can be rushed with platinum needed. There is no real reason to use platinum other than getting items quickly (without having to farm). Thus the warning is coming into this game, expect to spend a lot of time trying to find resources, modules, and leveling up the frames and equipment. All that being said, this game is very much worth the attention and playing with friends. Not many games out there can provide a fabulous sound design (like splitting enemies in half or headshots), very intriguing design, and visceral gameplay. And with constant improvements and additions, it is a still a great game to get into now.
game-hours: 489.5
review: This game starts off very promising and fun, but it eventually boils down to nothing more than retracing your steps over and over and over and over and over and over again. The drops are terrible, the combat gets really boring, and the entire game just feels really clunky. For a game that claimns to be centric to 'space-ninjas', there is nothing resembling ninjas at all, save for a few obsolete Frames/weapons. Did I mention how horribly slow and sluggish these 'ninjas' are? Chris Farley could catch them. If you like broken records, stale combat, or just like farming for hours on end, then Farmframe is for you.
game-hours: 62.8
review: repetitive grind
game-hours: 27.8
review: After playing this game for about 25 hours i came to the conclution that this game , despite looking very pretty and having a cool setting, this game is VERY repetitive even the different mission types feel all too similar. the levels consist of; Metalic space ship, ice planet / metallic space ship like base, and metallic space ship with starnge alien infection inside. And even with the different types of enemies even the enemies tactics stay the same, they run at you with fists out or they shoot at you while sustaining about 10 meters distance. even though the game is well optimised the games graphics feel like they are just there to make your pc work a little, the games flashy use of nvidia physx is quite over the top when even your bullets hitting the ground will create both sparks AND a puff of smoke "pwetty gwaphics" well describes the levels. the abilities work in a card collection style system where you use up points t gain attributes. The games has a fairly large weapon roster but all the weapons take a very long time to aquire if you dont feel like using the microtransactions system. It took around 5 hours just to unlock a second dual pistol which left me feeling rather pathetic when a donator comes along with a large bow and thousands of sparks flying everywhere. There is a system where you can build weapons using "forge" but it can take 24 hours to build a basic shotgun.the poorly named shotgun called "strun" brings me to the names of the game, ths game has rather poorly named equipment such as the "lato" pistol and the "aklato" dual pistols. quite poorly named if you ask me. dispite these previously mentioned flaws the game has, the games is very well polished and i only encountered 1 glich in my playtime where a grineer ragdoll kinda flew away after being shot. The final verdict for this game is 6/10 thanks for reading! by: generation gaming's Joe blackman

game-hours: 3.8
review: I have never taken time to review a game but I had to make an exception for this. This is literally and without exaggeration the most boring and monotonous game I have ever played in my life. Here how you play. Walk through a corridor to find the button to open the door to the next corridor to get to the end of the level. Sometimes there will be two buttons and you will require the presence of another player. A random online player will appear in your game out of nowhere to achieve this and then you can go about ignoring each other. Enemies without AI will shoot at you from the side lines while you ignore them and continue on finding more buttons to open more corridors. - Environments are bland and unchanging. I'm not sure what my environment was supposed to be, but it looked like an abandoned warehouse labyrinth. The main features are long corridors between store rooms with a terminal operated door on each end, repeated ad nauseam. In space. I have not seen level design this bad before. - Enemies are indistinct drones who do nothing interesting but stand on the spot and wait for death whilst very slowly shooting peas at you. I had to deliberately stand still in packs of them to find what it would take to kill me. - The sword doesn't actually cut, it seems to just do damage points. You have to press E to "cut the enemy in half" about 5 times to do enough damage points to kill them, while they shoot you at point blank, doing of course, no damage. - I don't know what my character was supposed to be doing or why, other than opening doors to more doors. I hope I never find out because I'm sure it will make the game even worse. I'm afraid I've actually made the game sound far better than it is, so whatever good impression you get from that, divide it by 50. If you have played games before there will be nothing new here for you. If you are a mindless drone you might be able to use this game to fill the time between now and your death as blandly as possible. Score: 2/100

review: Edit: BEFORE I say anything, let me tell you the raw gameplay is cool, concept outstanding, very fun, but uh... This game WOULD be cool, but the Pay 2 Win feature completly slaughters any chance of any progress. Yes, the first missions are easy and whatnot, but after I got the Rhino blueprints after grinding the second boss, I started to see that crafting was pretty much the only way to get anything without having to pay.You also have to grind the crap out of everything to get what you want, and I'm pretty sure NO ONE wants that. Speaking of grinding, almost everything craftable in the game requires an orokin cell. Said orokin cells, are not found untill Saturn and are not easy to obtain. Which completly sucks considering everything from a low level pisol to the best warframes require one. The reason this is, which is probably really obvious, is because they want you to buy platinum(premium currency) and then buy what you want, therefore having you spend real world money and making Digital Extremes(developers) profit more. This also ENCOURAGES them to keep the P2W feature. Basically, to sum it up, this game has the LARGEST P2W stores I have ever seen. It ruins the game. P2W should not exist, especially in this game where your supposed to feel cool and ninja-like. But the second you join someone else's game, you realize they have Rhino Prime, and some of the most cool but confusing weapons you've ever seen. Then you feel poor and useless. In one sentence, GET THE FFFFFFFFFUDGE OUT OF OUR GAME P2W!

game-hours: 506.9
review: Firstly: IT'S FREE! TRY IT YOURSELF! You'll find that the game gets very repetitive quickly. I've put about 300 hours into this game in total, 129 on the Steam version. The game is grinding from the first mission. Leveling up the mastery rank to unlock weapons or grinding to collect resources which are needed to craft Weapons, new Warframes, and Sentinels. You'll then have to farm mods to make your equipment worth something. Then once the weapons have been crafted; you'll end up having to wait 12-24 hours for that weapon to build and with Clan Tech weapons, it could take upwards to a weak. After that, if you find out that you actually enjoy the game; you'll find yourself needing Platinum to collect more Warframes, Weapons, and Sentinels. However now with the trading system, platinum can be aquired for free given you find willing customers. Now that the main negatives are done the positives: Beautiful Graphics Relatively friendly and helpful community Events occur often Good support with patches New content often Warframes are unique with several being exceptions ( As new Warframes are added, older ones get nerfed. For example: Volt was one of the first Warframes and he was for sometime, the main Warframe that did damage. When Nova was unlocked she became the primary damage dealer and Volt got nerfed to make her more of a choice. Now, in Update 11.5 Nova was nerfed to make Oberon and usefull choice. ) Enemies are challenging, in the start. The game isn't bad as in it's full of flaws. It's bad as in it is extremely repetitive, it gets to be alot of grinding.

review: Edit: This game is being aquired by PWE, avoid at all costs Don't bother with this game. It'd dead in the water, no one told the new players is all. The devs are not transparent at all, and will change things without even putting patch notes up, and even when they do they leave out 50% of what they actually change. On top of that, they listen to the PvP community [reported around 10% of the community] and are trying to shoehorn in PvP as the main staple of a PvE game. On top of that, balance doesn't exist; Depending on the dev's mood, one 'class' will be the most powerful, and only viable class, while all others get serever nerfs [See Trinity, the healer that can't heal.], and only a handful of weapons, gated behind a grind or pay wall, are viable beyond the starting area. The devs ahve come out and said that they purposfully only want certaint [classes] and weapons to be viable, making a teired system which leads to everyone having the same build. Lastly, changes to the game are wild and almost damning. And example, they updated the boss system so that, instead of being at a fixed level as they were before, bosses now scale depending on your level, and will always be higher level than you. Health, Armor [% damage reduction], and damage are all tied to Level with enemies, thus the higher the level, the more of the above said enemy will have. Bosses can break the level cap of 100 due to the new system, mechanically making them impossable to beat, and requiring missions to be abandoned. This game is in it's death throws, and the devs have resorted to nickling and diming the playerbase, and openly admit it. Don't bother spending money or time on this, it's going to be dead before it 'launches'.

game-hours: 318.5
review: At a time when many Free-to-play games feature very unfair monetization, Warframe is a breath of fresh air. Firstly, it is one of the best looking F2P titles I have ever seen. Secondly, the combat system is very enjoyable and the community is VERY active. Thirdly and most importantly, the monetization is very fair in this game. You can easily work towards building ANY weapons in the game by sinking time into it or simply by purchasing it through the store. However, compared to games like Planetside 2, gaining weapons and frames without spending money is a very feasible way to progress in the game. I would suggest supporting these developers - you can tell they love what they do. I highly reccomend this to anybody. CONS: Graphically demanding (but very well optimized).
game-hours: 269.8
review: It's an amazing game, ultimately flawed for many either due to it's lack of PVP for some and repetitive item grinding nature. If you can look over those two issues that some will have, you will have an outstanding game with ninja's flipping of walls throwing elemental force powers while, with steady upgrades from a determined developer the game is well supported. It's pricing model is a little rough, however there is a daily login reward which after consistent daily activity you have the chance of a 75% off the purchase of currency, then everything is good with the model.

review: For a Free To Play Shooter, this game is incredible! Don't look at that 66 out of 100 Metascore and say to yourself that this game is going to be bad, because the gameplay in this is very well done, even though you are pretty much killing the Human Race and other Alien Species. Many people who may have played Mass Effect should be settled very quickly into this game as well, but if you are not a Mass Effect player you should get into the combat system very easily anyway. The only negative thing I can really think of is the recycled maps for different planets, Mars would look like Pluto, which is strange since Mars is the Red Planet, usually this is patched every update though so there is more variaty to the planets. Another good thing is that Microtransactions arn't compulsary in this game, most things you can buy with Platinum (Bought Currency) you can earn by earning Credits (In-Game Curreny), it justs takes a bit more time. Overall I think this is a great Shooter, maybe if this was proper paid game, it may not be worth it, but for Free, this is Awesome. 8 Out Of 10 Kubrows ;)

game-hours: 159.3
review: Even though I'm not that good at this game, I still enjoy it. The survival, the stealth, the missions in-general! It's all so perfect and it fits this world which was created. AND! It's free! This Warframe LOOKS beautiful and the gameplay is fluent, the parkour element can be irritating yet it still works when you use it correctly. However, most say this game is P2W -- I respectfully disagree, as some items you can pay for, you can simply craft the items when you have a blueprint, I found a Banshee Chassis and Paris bow blueprints, which is pretty good. The Tenno you can play as add a whole new, not very complex but again, extremely fluent gameplay. You can go to the very well balanced Excalibur, the first. Electrocute your enemies with Volt, fry them -- LITERALLY! You can also crush your enemies with Mag, again -- quite literally. Ram through a barrage of Grineer with Rhino! Turn invisible and move behind your enemies with an advantage, create a energy created duplicate of yourself to distract enemies to get an advantage as Loki! These are five Tenno from many more, it's extremely lovely to have so many options but that can irritate you also, you always must think about what Tenno is good for what! Excalibur is a mostly all-round Tenno, Rhino -- I would say is pretty offense to me, there are so many options it's amazing. I would actually never think to remove this game or decide not to play it, I give it a 9/10 with a seal of badassery, a must own game. Get it.
