game-hours: 1468.8
review: Don't get me wrong. This game is awesome in many ways, but the the system seems to rely to much on players paying money in order to get the "full experience" of warframe. The gameplay is great, giving you many options in terms of combat flexibility, the graphics are nice too, with a beautiful motion blur and depth of field effect. The visual style is very focused, giving the game a clean feel. So, no problem with the game. Now here comes my real issue. The paywalls. Do you want to ressurect after dying? Buy platnum. Want extra colors? 5.00 USD. (Or more, I forget.) Want weapons without crafting them? Up to $20.00. Want a new warframe? Buy one for 40.00. Forty. Dollars. I could buy extra characters in other games for less then FIVE. This game seems to be very, very harsh toward solo players who don't like paying money. In spite of this, the game's still very nice, in spite of some buggy mechanics here and there. The experience is ruined by the paywalls for me, however. So that being said, I would not recommend this game until they have the common sense to stop the lavicious greed seething behind this game, or at least lower the price of their "platnum".

review: Don't get me wrong. This game is awesome in many ways, but the the system seems to rely to much on players paying money in order to get the "full experience" of warframe. The gameplay is great, giving you many options in terms of combat flexibility, the graphics are nice too, with a beautiful motion blur and depth of field effect. The visual style is very focused, giving the game a clean feel. So, no problem with the game. Now here comes my real issue. The paywalls. Do you want to ressurect after dying? Buy platnum. Want extra colors? 5.00 USD. (Or more, I forget.) Want weapons without crafting them? Up to $20.00. Want a new warframe? Buy one for 40.00. Forty. Dollars. I could buy extra characters in other games for less then FIVE. This game seems to be very, very harsh toward solo players who don't like paying money. In spite of this, the game's still very nice, in spite of some buggy mechanics here and there. The experience is ruined by the paywalls for me, however. So that being said, I would not recommend this game until they have the common sense to stop the lavicious greed seething behind this game, or at least lower the price of their "platnum".
game-hours: 0.2
review: NO!
game-hours: 660.7
review: Warframe is a rpg-shooter in a sci-fi space scenario. The player can choose between different forms called "Warframes" with special abilities. While a warframe can be equipped with mods (attribute enhancements) the player can chose between dozens of weapons for ranged and melee combat. The difficulty of Warframe is very low. New players have a hard time but after the first 30-50 hours of gameplay the game becomes very easy and repetitive. There are no rewards for mastering a missions in a short time or suriving very long. Endgame doesn't exist because it is not rewarded by any means. The overall financial strategy of this game is to restrict items by one-time events, forcing people to trade them for real money. This includes more powerfull mods and weapons. While this concept works well for people who have no real life schedule, it doesn't work for casual gamers.

game-hours: 29.6
review: *Since the game is f2p, I'd strongly recommend that you play it for yourself and form your own criteria. I doubt you will lose anything from trying it, other than time, that is. The main objective of this review is to offer feedback to the developers, so that they (hopefully) make this game better and not so much of a chore to play.* A grindfest from the toes to the scalp. Warframe's promise was quite good: to make you feel like a real futuristic badass ninja with superpowers. The showcasing of so many planets, missions, game modes, warframes, weapons and powers appeared to show an incredible amount of diversity gameplay-wise. Unfortunately, this is not the case. Although the combat mechanics are well developed and the controls are somewhat fluid, the game feels immensely repetitive. There is no goal other than to grind and get new stuff to keep grinding so you can build other stuff and then just keep grinding again. There's no point, no meta-game. You just keep playing for the sake of grinding on hopes that the other warframes and weapons will drastically affect gameplay or offer variation to the extremely boring gameplay. But wait, why am I saying it's so repetitive and bad when I just said there are so many maps, guns, modes etc. and combat mechanics are well developed? Well, for starters, the brain-dead AI doesn't helps at all. Harder areas only mean that you will find the same idiotic enemies that you faced in your first hours on Warframe with more health and damage output. It's enough to say that this kills any degree of possible variety, gameplay-wise and removes any sense of a tactical approach to the mission. Changing your warframe and gear doesn't mean more variety, it means you will have much more chance to win on higher "difficulties" and against other people on pvp by using stronger stuff. Speaking of tactical approaches, stealth is a joke, a very bad one. Enemies spawn from nowhere when you re-enter an area, usually in front of you, even if you just left it 5 seconds ago or went into a ventilation pipe; brain-dead AI makes it almost impossible to predict enemies' movement, confusing parkour mechanics often leave you in non-desired places, stealth kills require you to wait for the "Press E to make a stealth kill" window to appear, limited-to-no options to flank or avoid your enemies, etc. It's just plain hilarious how you can sprint and run just behind an enemy or stand 10 feet away, in front of them and they won't do a thing, even if there is a light source. But walk 3 more feet and they magically make all the room to go into maximum alert against you. Finally, the micro-transactions, an expected feature on a f2p. It's true that they don't force you on paying by adding paywalls. You can get everything by grinding, which is pretty good. The problem? It's only TECHNICALLY good. A person with a life, a job and responsabilities that can't play 6-9 hours per day will become almost immediately frustrated when he/she realizes that it takes more than 60 hours of grinding materials to build something, then a full day to complete it. Obviously, shortcuts will be seeked and micro-transactions will occur. For most people, micro-transactions are forced by difficulties of life itself. That's a smart way of avoiding hate. Good job Digital Extremes, you dodged a bullet there. Of course, you will find almost no one criticizing the grinding mechanics and the micro-transactions because it's a coop game. What other people buys with real money or by loosing it's life on this game won't enrage you in any way. On the contrary, because he/she will aid you. But still, I'd really like if the developers made every weapon unique in their own way, not just leveled/stronger versions of previous weapons or new, insanely OP'd weapons and warframes focused on encouraging even more grinding to become even more OP. They could learn a lot about PlanetSide 2's balance. Overall, Warframe's great mechanics and ideas get completely ruined by the mistake of turning it all into one, giant grindfest. It's a real pity to see such a promising coop shooter and amazing fighting mechanics go to waste.

Need more revives? They cost real money to buy... And you'll NEED them in some of these poorly designed levels... And boy, the money to content ratio in this game is laughably poor. review: This is a "wonderful" pay to win experience that was actually good is a few ways when I first downloaded it over a year ago. Now it is not. The pay to win got even worse, the graphics and "menus" were changed for the worst, when I played a grineer mision recently the special effects were like popup ads, it remained unbelivable repetitive, the boss fights are bad, and require little to no skill (as long as you bought the good guns and upgrades, or spent months trying to, you can hold your fire button and occasionally strafe to beat them), and the list goes on. I will say, sometimes it is fin to shoot something in its face and watch it explode, but in order to have any difficulty, the game either throws so many enimies at you it feels like you have a bees nest chasing you, or add a special enemy that, despite being much below your level sometimes, is able to do something cheap (like charge at you, too fast to dodge, and remove all of your sheild) and kill you almost instantly. As for the pay to win, spend enough money, and you can be level 60, and have all the level 60 weapons, and the best upgrades for them without playing a single round. Another way it got annoying was how when me and my friends wanted a clan dojo, and the weapons it came with, it took us one to three days AND an item that is near imposible to get without paying, unless there is a special event going on (forma). Or, someone with the money to do so could spend some of it to get the forma, and complete te room instantly. Also, almost all of the things you can craft take a few days, with some very small things taking hours, and things you might need a few of i one round taking thirty seconds. One more thing, one of the weapons i spent weeks trying to get from the dojo was given for free to everyone playing on a certain day. In conclusion, the game is bad. Everything I love about other games is not present in this game. Me and my friends used to love it, because it used to be a bit better, but then it got repetitive. There was a pont when almost everyone in my friends list was playing it, but now on;y one or two do, and the others havent in a very long time. If I had to guess, less than thirty percent of the people who gave good ratings still play the game.

When with infected they could have wall crawling,wall/roof pouncing ect. or having some sort of unique attack style other then get target in visible range then fire til i or it dies. All up it's a fun game for awhile but once you notice how limited it is and how much of a grind fest it is you will move on.

game-hours: 22.4
review: I played Warframe for a little bit. I have to say it really spoke to me and was great fun with my friends, going on missions, fight, explore, and get loot, and whatnot. I liked the playability of the frames, how they moved and how you could do some interesting parcour-like tricks with them. I liked the cards that you could slot in your armor and weapons to modify how your warframe operated, and I especially liked finding new cards so you could upgrade and do all that good "build"-stuff. After a while though (I say this after some 20+ hours of play), the combat got really boring, repetitive and just didn't feel like there was any point to it. The missions, environments and loot is pretty much always the same, you can't really do anything with your money, don't get me started on the leveling "system", and if you want to craft and upgrade, you have to heavily invest your time into it (or bust out the ole credit card). And maybe that's the problem, I just don't have the time or patience to keep grinding missions and doing events. I feel like I would have liked this game when I was 15 to 18 years old, when I had the stamina to just keep doing the same mission after repetitive mission. As it stands, I don't like the game because the challenge to me seems to be a test of how much time you're willing to spend getting minimal rewards and character growth. So it's a no from me. I don't recommend this game.

game-hours: 1.4
review: The interesting concept of swappable abilities is negated by the fact that 90% of the content must be purchased with real money transactions. You'll have to purchase a pack ranging from $50 to $200 in order to unlock weapons and other characters. If the game had limited these transactions to merely cosmetic features, or had allowed a one time purchase of the game and the ability to earn them by playing I might sit down for another couple of sessions in the hope of earning something cool instead of having to buy my way to victory. Also, if a player dies 4 times during the day, they must spend more real money for additional revivals. The enemies and gameplay are mediocre, though Warframe tries to include a wall running mechanic to spice things up. It's sadly under utilized in every area, making each stage a forgettable copy-and-pasted version of the last. Enemies have a tendency to slide and teleport around as well. They have a chance to drop ability cards for you to equip, which an interesting idea, but since shooting everything in the face with your default weapon (which doesn't require recharging like abilities do) clears them away just as well, there's no real tactical reason to use them. The main characters and weapons look pretty good, but the stages and opponents are all forgettably grimdark. Do you have an hour to kill on a gimmick shooter? Look no further. Want something with a more depth? Go play Tribes: Ascend instead.

review: I did not like Warframe, it's short, missions are repetitive and buggy. For example, one mission I was trying to find and capture 2 guys. First of all the minimap icon for the guy I was supposed to find was not right and then someone else finished the mission then every enemy went after me. If that isn't bad enough, the crafting is not well thought out. To craft things, you have to farm for rare materials that you can rarely find, or the thing you are looking for is on a planet that have enemies that are 5 levels higher than you. And if you think you can just buy wepons from the store, then you are wrong. Most, if not all the good items, require real money to buy, so I take this time to mention that the game is free to play. My final complaint is that there is little to no cover in the game and only one enemy has a melee only attack. And if that's not bad enough, than listen to this, I am not completely sure if there is a crouch button. So all and all don't get this game. It's not as good as it looks. If you are looking for a game like this I would suggest Destiny

review: Warframe does a number of things oh, so right, then misses a lot of potential, then botches the landing hard with an ultra-grindy mid-to-late game. There's fun to be had, but the longer you play it for the less fun you'll have. And like so many other addictive, grindy games, it's usually after you've wasted way too much time that you realize how little fun you've been having all along. May be worth a play if you have dexterity and just want to blast and slice some dudes. But be very careful about getting sucked in because this game does not reward dilligence; it punishes it.

game-hours: 924.6
review: This is a review of the latest update to the game rather than the game as a whole, with the hope of maybe prompting the devs to fix some of the issues. I shall start with things that I think have been improved so as not to appear too negative! Good things: 1. The new alert menu is a great new feature, I've always thought that this was a much needed addition. 2. The new abilty system is an improvement, it opens up more drain points to equip more usefull mods. It also means you can have all four abilities fully upgraded without sacrificing other handy mods 3. Can now see the per-mission bonus objective during the mission rather than just at the start if you remembered to skip the intro 4. Some colourblind friendly features have been implemented, it is now easier to see if lockers are locked or not, now just hoping they apply a similar feature to doors! Bad things: 1. Can no longer rank up, indeed completing missions lowers your mastery rank rather than increases it 2. The air smash attack is now more awkward to initiate, and no longer works with certain melee weapons 3. The U.I has been altered, and is now less clear and less colourblind friendly. In regard to better locker system, I'm not sure why this has been done. The paler colours tend to blend into the light background, and as things have been made smaller they are harder to see even if your not colourblind. 4. Hacking console interface has been altered.It has been made larger, resulting in the right hand side of the minigame being off the edge of the screen, and the new colour scheme is less clear from a colourblind point of view. 5. Sentinel AI has been adjusted, I only have Dethcube so I cant comment on the others, but Dethcube now only uses the vaporize special ability on dead enemies, or on thin air. It also changes target too often so his minigun style weapon never lives up to its full potential 6. Codex entry graphics seem to be glitched, they no longer have any textures. The models are just black shapes on a black background. There also seems to be some weapons missing I cant comment on the Archwing content yet because I have stopped playing the game until I stop losing progress for completing missions, so I havent been able to try them yet. If this post is in the wrong place, apologies and please feel free to relocate it!

review: Warframe was a absolutely amazing game. Until the archwings. The numerous bugs i've encountered have mostly all been with the new "archwing" gamemode (and in particular, the Limbo theorem quest.) (dont get me wrong though, everything else with this game is absolutely perfect.) I was recently playing this quest when i noticed many things wrong about the gamemode (i was playing the interception mode). First of all, i noticed the grineer have absolutely no idea what 'contesting an objective' is. no matter what the grineer instantly capture points despite me being there to contest them. instantly. Secondly, the grineer spawn in basically unstoppable and unrelenting swarms. seriously, its like an ork waaaaagh. though that may be just because im not that high of a level with my archwing stuffsydoodles. Thirdly, when you do complete the mission, i find it difficult to "kill them all". mostly because they're INSIDE the asteroids. good luck getting to them. and then theres the constant crashing. In game, in the loading screen, and, wierdly enough, in the launcher menu- thing. all the crashes all the time, and you don't keep your rewards when you crash. It really sucks. Overall, Warframe is a Great game, and i hope it will continue to be so. But the archwing is just too much rage for me to handle XD. I really hope these bugs will be fixed ASAP, but until then (or until i manage to actually complete the limbo quest without too much crashing and rage!) im giving this a nosauce.

review: What a piece of  money grubbing game. It is a free to play scam and that's it. Some f2p games are great, some are ones that are only truly enjoyable if you spend money in their cash shop. Spending money on a f2p game should NOT be a requirement, but here it is. Unless you like grinding dozens upon dozens upon dozens of hours to unlock one measly new frame, you have to buy one, and a good one costs $20. That's insane, but not to the greedy f2p cash grabbers that made this money grubbing suckfest. The game is only mediocre at best so it is not fun enough to grind that long. The developers only care about the cash shop and getting people to spend their money in it. This is the exact formula that 99.99% of cell phone games use: let the player play for free for a little while, then require them to spend a  of money in the expensive as fk cash shop to advance and enjoy more of the game, at least over $20. And they charge for everything: weapons, mods, frames, aesthetics, literally everything. I've never seen a f2p game be this deceiptful in it's usage of the term "free to play". It has generic combat, sound, controls, and graphics. The graphics in the store page screenshots look amazing but the actual game looks nothing like that. The levels are bland as  so the only good graphics come from character models and effects. The levels are also poorly done and boring and linear as fk. Really bad level design. After putting about 7 hours into this, it is just not good enough to warrant the dozens and dozens of hours I would need to grind to get anything worth a . I will be damned if I spend a dime on this before I would put that money towards a purchase where instead of buying platinum for a f2p game which is beyond stupid and a major waste of money, I will spend that money towards actually owning a game. And a good one, not something with a generic feeling engine like this dog crap.

game-hours: 131.5
review: Every game fits into a niche. Warframe, unfortunately, only excells in meeting the typical "here's a goal, hit it faster by paying real money. Oh, and by the way, if you don't pay, it's going to be a terrible time." From day one, it's a struggle. The learning curve is smooth, that's always good, but the tutorials don't get involved enough and player reviews are needed to dive further into the game. The beginning of the game leaves you with many questions and only one customization option: pick one of three starting warframes. After you've got the basics down, you'll quickly realize that you're going to be stuck with the same gear for an entire planet, if not more. Let's talk AI. This is some VERY bad AI. The bots are sometimes easily kited (I've manipulated the first two bosses to where I'm untargettable) and they lock on far too hard. Once, while I'm using the mag "crush" ability an enemy just stood there (was about 10 feet away, only enemy on my screen) and for some reason wasn't picked up by the ability. But nontheless, the ability still activates and leaves me unable to do anything while my shields and health go from over 700 combined to nothing, and because you can only revive yourself 4 times per day without paying (what the ?) I'm left with no items, no credits, and nothing for my half hour grind. I have been playing for over an hour and a half this morning, and haven't gotten a ing drop. I've tried an "interception" mission a few times, twice solo and twice online. Can't find anyone to speak english if there's even anyone online in what is obviously a forced co-op mission. What a terrible idea. You know, some players wish to play solo as it's a better achievement? Every mission becomes instantly easy with 3 competent teammates (which is surprisingly rare, but more than often you'll get a level 10 grinding the missions and you won't even get a shot in by the time he wrecks the entire level) As far as advancement, once you reach the later levels, you'll realize that you've been running the same maps with slightly changed goals and buffed AI repeatedly, and the nonexistant endgame is pretty frustrating. With the hopes that with the money that I'm seeing some of these confused players spending, the company will improve this game monumentally I think I'll level a warframe to 30 and then uninstall. Don't waste your time with "Warframe" unless you're completely bored with every other game in your library. Warframe will most likely evolve into a "" genre where it will only be played vigorously by a small population which will defend its terible mechanics to the grave. Only once those players have finally moved on will they realize their mistake.

review: From a collector's point of view and only from this view : Stay away from this game. game-hours: 35.6
review: What seemed like a great game with the ideal F2P cash-shop method turned out to be a next level farm fest. One where a Korean MMO would squeal out of envy. And if I wanted to farm that much I wouldve played Destiny instead since I paid for that From the 30-ish hours I played the last 2 weeks at least 12 hours where to get a Kubrow egg, a Kubrow is a companion who fights along your side. Which you can only obtain from one single planet be destroying Kubrow dens (dont ask me the logic in that) and they are extremely rare. I gave up after 12 hours of farming, I guess I wont complete that quest Next to farming a long time for a single item you need for a quest, you have the standard farming for blueprints, mods and materials. No biggie, and if you have the blueprints and materials to create an item youre being put in a time-gate. With that I mean if you press the build button to assemble an item you have to wait 12 to 48(!) hours till its finished! Or you can pull out your wallet to finish it instantly Given if you have the inventory space to put the item in. You see as a free2player you have very limited inventory space, which forces you to think about which weapon you want to keep and which one to dump. That would be fine if the game didnt forced you to use as many different items (guns, swords, Warframes, Kubrows and Archwings). You see, the game uses a Mastery system. The more XP your items gained and the more of them you max levelled each of them, the higher your Mastery level will be. You need to level your Mastery level to unlock weapons from the store and gain more loadout slots (dont confuse loadout slots with inventory space). And since youve limited inventory slots, levelling your Mastery will become even a bigger pain then it already is. And the only way to expand your inventory is either by pulling out your wallet, or to go farm even more to get an item youll be able to sell for premium currency so youll be able to expand your inventory so you can go farm again to get the items you want till your inventory is full again. Then you can start the circle again I dont know about you but that isnt my definition of fun. Dont get me wrong, the game is good gameplay wise, but forcing someone to either pay or farm so he can farm more later on is a deal breaker for me. At least its not P2W which they got that going for them.

review: Warframe, where do I start? Well you cant move till the maps are loaded in (Happens alot) By-far, the worst thing about this game is the grind, you want to buy a Boltor? That will be 225 platnium or, you can go grind for hours to get a single weapon. Or just pay 225 platnium. The platnium prices are a bit over-priced, its not so less of a Pay2Win game, but a grindfest to where you kinda are forced to buy platnium because some items are almost impossible to get. The game has gotten better lately, but it shouldnt do the kind of payment method they have, its overpriced and its obvious that they are trying to rip you dry. This game isnt that play for gameplay except for the glitches and errors, but the grind is rediculous. I cant rate this game due to it being really good but really bad at the same time (Love hate relationship)but I can give it a nickname, "Grind Simulator 2014"

game-hours: 289.0
review: Warframe is a 3rd person shooter with co-op muiltplayer. There are around 140 (rough esimate) levels in warframe all based on different planets under a solar system. Each level has different game modes set to it like defence, capture and survival which can add a lot of varitey to the game. In each planet you can find different materials and items as you play through it to complete certain types of things like weapons which can bring a bit of farming at the start. During each planet there will be boss to fight with its own type of style and will drop special blueprints for a warframe. These warframes are different types of suits which can be used like fire and electric. You can only have 2 without having to pay for more. During your travels through space you will come across new blueprints, new bad guys and mod which can make a weapon or frame better. The game is good allround but after time it can become stale having to farm for materials going through the same level 20 times for one thing. During missions you will see that you will be coming acros the same layout of level over and over which makes the game repetitive and boring. In my opinion it is good at start but losses replay value quick I rate 6/10 I know it is in beta but it gets boring and repetitive to quick.

review: The visuals are fantastic, the gameplay is solid, matchmaking works just fine and there's not much lag. What's wrong with it then? This is because certain components of warframes can only be found in the latest stages of the game, meaning if you don't want to spend cash, you essentially have to nearly beat the game using the same 4 abilities that come with your starter warframe before you'll be able to get a new one. It would be like forcing you to only use 1 champion in league of legends until you reach level 30.

review: Warframe was a promising title until the last updates where the core game, being a coop-shooter, become more and more neglected. With each updates we get larger bureaucratic overheads. The update 15 reached new heights in this. A space shooter not worthy for a mobile phone game. A reputation system so simple and bland, that I would no call it a system. Etc. Also the devs seem to be more and more detached from the community, they put up votes about design decisions which are ignored, etc. This is not the game it was a year ago. You have tons of small task to do, which are irrelevant in the end and endless grind. I can not recommend the game anymore. UPDATE Update 16 pushed the game even more into boredom and medicority. Same quests (do three missions and get frame), 2 new (worhless) weapons and another collect something to get something. Items revised 4-5 times, abilites changed without notification, bad communication with the commnity are still present in the game. There is still minimal story or lore in the game. game-hours: 67.1
review: Starting out, this game is godlike. It's everything I've ever wanted in a 3rd person shooter--sci-fi, parkour, explosions, and smooth combat while using your parkour. My one big problem--Technically it's free-to-play, but the amount of time you have to put in to get the resources you need to craft the materials to make your weapons/armor is obscene. Positively obscene. Steam says I only have 8 hours on record, but that's because most of my time was playing offline, where I have about two hundred. Speaking of which, playing offline is actually just as fun as playing online. Maybe it's a little harder, but that just encourages you to use your parkour/stealth abilities with more effectiveness. In any case, I know that this game is free. i know they have to make money somehow, and they won't make any if it's easy to earn it in-game. However, I really think that they could cut down a little on the grinding and let us have fun just blasting  away. One last major complaint (and this is the biggest one): Leveling up is nearly impossible. They give you a small amount of time to kill a ridiculous number of people with only 4 revives or so (which, trust me, you'll burn right through). Maybe I just suck, but I haven't passed even the first test. This wouldn't be so bad if you could just replay it, but you can only test once every 24 hours. This is COMPLETE . But otherwise it's pretty fun. Overall Pros- Smooth gameplay, parkour doesn't interrupt combat, upgrade systems, level systems, good co-op community, fun weapons, and nothing super repetitive. Cons- Technically f2p, but a major grindfest, levelling up is ridiculously difficult, and buying money is way too expensive.

review: Warframe is, in my opinion, one of the best examples of a free to play. It keeps you entertained with the cool boss battles, weapons, and skill sets(warframes). Though this game can get quite stale if you attempt to play it alone, which means get a couple of friends to download this and set off a weekend to beat the crap out of enemies with your preferred loadout. Also, you can obtain every weapon and warframe without paying, it just more of a, pardon my language, pain in the  because it means you have to go full grind mode and collect massive amounts of items for a item, which is actually the incentive to pay for platinum, real currency, to take less time to grind. Still this game is much better than most other free to plays, which show a pay to win model.

game-hours: 430.4
review: This is how you do F2P. With one or two exceptions, this is the most fair, balanced F2P model I have ever seen. The exception to this is the very limited invintory space the game give you at start, forcing you to buy more slots, other than this, the F2P model here is flawless. Now we talk about the graphics: Personally, I think this game looks good. Very good. My rig can handle maxed out graphics, however my AMD processor does not let NVIDIA PhsX run, other than that, pretty good graphics, lower end PCs should be able to run the game fairly well on the lowest settings. Now, moving on to gameplay: Th controls are...awkward at first, but once you are used to them, they feel very smooth, and fast. not much else to say about the controls right now. Overall I like this game, and the developers behind it. Download Warframe and see if it's your cup of tea.

review: When I first started this game, I thought it was pretty awesome. I had a great time running through the missions and just playing with other people. Then, I noticed the pay to win feature in later missions. That's probably the only thing I dislike about the game. For example, the first time I played with a player who payed to get a sentinel, his sentinel killed everything and all the rest of us could do was follow him. But, then I realized that even with players like that, the game still maintains a pretty good challenge of trying to out do them and just trying to win. TL;DR: It's really really pay to win but still would recommend.

game-hours: 6.2
review: Recommending because it's a free game, can't complain. So then, Steam says I have 6 hours played so far, and well after those 6 hours I still feel like I'm doing the exact same thing I was doing in the beginning. The game looks ok, the melee combat and bullet deflection looks quite nice, but the levels feel exactly the same. I find myself enjoying a maximum of 2 missions before having to take a break, which is very unusual for me. That said, I do think that if you buy in-game currency via steam or the market, the larger weapon and character variety will make the game a lot more fun. I'm not patient enough to unlock things (it's really quite slow - get materials, then craft, then wait until it's crafted), thus I didn't quite enjoy the game as much as I would have liked. This game is also significantly more fun if you can play with friends on skype or something. Tl;dr - Good simple shooter just for the sake of killing things. Progression without donate too slow.

game-hours: 146.6
review: ing space ninjas nuff said
game-hours: 19.0
review: Remember the first trailer for Dark Sector that showed that the game was originally to take place in space and in the far future? Well Digital Extremes decided to take the concept of that early version of Dark Sector and make a completely new and free to play third person action title out of it. And so Warframe was created. You play as a member of the alien race known as the Tenno, a slight nod to the protagonist in Dark Sector, who has been summoned from the dark reaches of space to the galaxy to fight the evil Grineer who are out to take over the galaxy and also wipe out the Tenno at the same time. But you're far from helpless in your struggle, you have a special battlesuit called a Warframe, each one of them have unique abilities that can turn the tide of battle in your favor, a wide array of firearms and several types of melee weapons, all of which are powerful enough to cut an enemy apart with one single powerful swipe. And you will also be fighting alongside other Tennos in your mission to rid the galaxy of the Grineer as well as any other alien race that intend to wipe you out.

game-hours: 1358.8
review: Buggy Buggy Buggy Buggy Buggy Buggy. Okay what do I mean by 'buggy'? Random disconnects then unable to login, spawning in mid-mission UNDER THE ING FLOOR where you fall for a minute or two before you then die, spawning mid-mission with a totally black screen then dying for no apparent reason, HORRENDUS lag that makes doors unable to open trapping you and then you fail the mission, and the list goes on. So unless you have a LOT of patience and can put up with the awful grind (gives 'rean MMOs a run for their money in that department), game breaking bugs, crashes (be prepared for that A LOT), and stupid stupid stupid client/host system whereby if the host leaves in the middle of the mission (again, happens A LOT) you then stand around where ever you are (say, in the middle of a swarm of mobs and you about to hit your 4th ability) and die unable to move then by all means play Warframe. If not, pass.
game-hours: 0.6
review: AWESOME!!!
game-hours: 312.6
review: This game is amazing. Most maps are very fast paced(except defense missions). This is mostly a PVE game. You can tell right away that this game is made by passionate developers who really care about making a good game, and if you spend some time on their twitch channel and get to know some of the people who put this game together...you'd definitely see that. The game gets frequent updates, with loads of new content. The mechanics of the actual game are nice. The mod system is ok...i like the extras you get from mods but it will definitely take you a while to sift through your thousands of mods to figure out which ones you want to use. The crafting system is nice, i actually do like that it takes a day or two to craft stuff. My biggest complaint would be the limmited inventory space, limmited character space....this is designed to piss you off and make you purchase more space. As a free game though, you can definitely enjoy the hell out of it. There is a decent variety of game modes in this game but after a while it does start to feel like a grind fest...with not much reason to be one...because you don't need the extra stats to beat everything. but thinking about it more...it'd be really difficult to create the ideal system with that in mind. The other thing i really like about this game is they have events going on all the time, to spice things up, but you can also get really useful items that normally you'd have to buy from the shop. PS. Lotus is a total babe.

game-hours: 26.7
review: Currently 26 hours into Warframe here is what I have to say: Warframe is a perfect example of a fast paced third person shooter. Once the game has loaded we are almost immediately thrown into the action, quickly discovering the arsenal that has been given to you. The game is very good when it comes to giving the player a choice in what the would like to do. The customisation is very good, from appearence of your character, to the look and power of your weaponry in game. Combat can be very complex for new players and it is quite essential to master all of the warframe's capabilities, such as running across and up walls. The agility of your character can be some what disorientating at first but putting this to good use can make you feel like a total badass space ninja. It is fun to discover the different kinds of game modes in Warframe but can become very repetitive when looking for that one essential resource to make your next gun. I have spend a lot of time doing the same one mission repeatedly with no luck. This can get very annoying and sometimes makes you just not want to play the game. The game itself may as well be completely multiplayer, which is not a problem but it can be horrible when you're hooked up with someone who has been playing the game a lot longer than you, stealing every single kill opportunity that arises The matchmaking needs a lot of work. Sometimes while playing the game I noice how many in-game purchaces there are, sure the game is free to play so it is expected to have some, but trust me there is WAY to much. It almost feels like a "Pay to win" game as everything is almost impossible to get without forking out some real world money. I do recommend this game as it is a very fun shooter and offers a nice change of gameplay to most other games right now. However if pay to win games are not your thing, I'd advise you to stay a way from playing this game for too long.

game-hours: 117.3
review: Initially when I started this game, Melee 2.0 had not been released and there was only quick melee and charge melee. At the time, I thought Warframe was so boring and that it was going to be a huge flop. I quit the game without changing my weapons even once, and I still had the Braton, the Lato, and the Skana (the only beginning weapons at the time). I was confused at how modding worked, and the maps seemed repetitive and lame, and gameplay overall was not immersive or fun. This all changed after Update 12, when Melee 2.0 came out. Melee 2.0 completely overhauled the way melee weapons are used, and allowed players to have a melee weapon out at all times, instead of just being swung once when the player pressed "E". It also changed the combat system by adding different elements (radiation, magnetism, etc.) and gave mobs different strengths and weaknesses. Channeling allowed the player to add power to his or her melee weapon but use energy in the process. As you can see, the game changed greatly due to this update. But this is not the only reason why I got hooked onto Warframe. Warframe doesn't force you to do anything. In other games, progression comes from your character level and questlines, and how far you go into questlines and the dungeons, etc. This often leads to horribly boring quests that seem like a chore after an hour of playing. In Warframe, every single equipment you have has a mastery rank, or a "level," and the higher the rank, the more mods you can equip to the weapon. The max rank is 30 for all equips, but even when you get an item to 30, you can "forma" it to reset it to rank 0 and change a "polarity" of the weapon (you will understand this when you start to play). Thus, players can endlessly upgrade their weapons and different warframes with a plethora of mods that can also be upgraded themselves. All warframes and weapons are weak without mods (there's no ONE weapon thats considered "the best"; all weapons are viable in their own way), and even if two players have the same weapon, they could be modded differently to bring different results. I get a huge amount of satisfaction every single time I create a new weapon or warframe because of the time I put into the game collecting the various materials and blueprints. Most of the fun that I get from this game comes from a sense of achievement in my collection of weapons, warframes, and sentinels. I don't like the game for its graphics/aesthetics (although the graphics are badass), because you WILL SEE SIMILAR/SAME LEVEL LAYOUTS if you play this game). I guarantee you will be playing the same map over and over in order to get a certain resource or material. The combat is okay, it keeps you interested and is very fast-paced, but it doesn't make the game. To wrap up, if you want to have a different sort of progression in which a character level does not define everything, and if you're looking for a sense of achievement and satisfaction in collecting a plethora of weapons and mechanic suits (each with their own skillset), and modding all of these things in different combinations to reach different playstyles, play warframe :D

game-hours: 43.2
review: Great third person shooter. The visual style is fairly unique. Action is fast, and the warframes allow for a great variety of gameplay. You play against AI opponents, alongside other players. A recent update added PVP, so now you can play against other warframes as well. Wall jumping, melee weapons, guns...oh so many guns! Graphics are top notch with all the fancy shaders that you would expect from a modern PC title, yet it can be scaled easily to lower system specs. The User Interface could use a lot of work, right now it is more style than substance and makes upgrading mods and your Warframe more difficult than it needs to be. But, it looks great. You don't need to pay to get into the game, and once you get into it a few bucks here or there to speed things along will probably be worth it. The developers are dedicated to the title, and version 14 added several new features for new players to make the game more accessible. Oh, and did I mention ninja wall running?? Yes there is ninja wall running! Run along walls to avoid fire and shoot your opponents, flip up onto a platform and summersault over your enemy to slash them with your sword...all great fun!

review: Warframe is a really fun free-to-play MMO that takes gameplay by missions. Teaming up with up to 3 other players, each 4 person squad tackles the designated challenge with an array of different weapons, and warframe, providing a multitude of power and player combinations. The game itself can be entirely played without spending a single cent, through hard work and determination. Though if you're the kind of person who wants to collect everything, you WILL have to pay for extra weapon and warframe SLOTS (not the frames and weapons themself). Since I'm that kind of person, I've spent money here and there for more slots. I highly recommend this game for anyone that enjoys 3rd person action/shooters. Especially since it's free!
game-hours: 47.3
review: This game is seemingly fun, loot driven, has good progression, enjoyable aesthetic and design, but in my limited run with the game thus far I wanted to give a first impression of the initial state of matchmaking. I mean, the game is pretty easy early on and thats to be expected, but with the way matchmaking works the game tends to pair people by latency and not their gear level. When I finally group, I don't need RAIDEN SUPER GOD ROBOT FLAME SWORD EXPLOSION GUY joining my low level nodes and skullhumping all the challenges into submission before I even face them (sprint mods). That is boring, and I might as well be waxing their plated  to avoid my team mate from dying of friction burns as he speedster hack'n'slashes to victory. With moments like those, it degenerates to me playing solo and then... what's the point? Metal Gear Rising has better combat and slicker boss designs, so what would be the point of slogging through this game? Well, progression. There is a permanency to content being added. There is a satisfaction to unlocking new content, and looking over the wealth of unlockables I as a new player can kick back and say to myself "Yeah, that looks like it'll be awesome when I finally get there". All in all, if you're new like me and looking to start this game - do it with friends, have them be the same gear level as you, and scratch and claw and work your way to cool hi-tech horizons.

game-hours: 305.6
review: Warframe is, to say the least, absurd. You play as a post-human space warrior with powers supported by an eldritch demension to slaughter cannon-fodder hordes of degenerate clones and cyborg corporate drones. Update 14 just came out, and it's definitely a huge step from the beta this once was to a full game. Early playing, once an absurdly difficult task, is now assisted by a whole tutorial quest designed to get you into the game and never come outside again. You possess a small spaceship now, used to upgrade and purchase weapons. It's definitely helped the immersion quite a bit. A big part of this game is grind: playing parts over and over again to get resources to craft weapon parts. You can get everything in the game for free except cosmetics, which must be purchased with in-game currency. The grind can be fun, or it can be not fun. How that turns out is up to you. Story is minimal, gleaned from the lines of your boss and entries in the in-game Codex. What we do have, though, seems amazing, a sci-fi epic spanning thousands of years of which your little adventure is merely the tail end. So overall? It's worth playing, and giving it a try. The devs are very good listeners, and seem very involved in the game they're making, so you really are in on the ground floor here. Spending money may not be advisable, but if the grind breaks your soul, by all means spend some cash. Some weapons are just nearly impossible to craft - ask about Argon Crystals and you'll understand. Good luck, Tenno.
game-hours: 41.4
review: A very addictive game you will explore our echo system like never before, earn multiple weapons armor, pets, abilities and warframes. in a free to play CO-OP multiplayer experience. I find that the game sticks out from other games with its map randomizer the maps are never the same. even though the game is quite repetitive, the game is way more fun to craft and earn your upgrades and weapons by collecting resources on the multiple planets, though if your that guy who just wants to get to the good stuff you can buy your way through the game, though i find it ruins the game a little. i would rate this game an 8.5/10 for its creativity and gameplay overall its a great free to play game and i recommend you give it a try.

review: magic ninjas with guns and rocket launchers who do parkour 10/10 would warframe again
game-hours: 184.5
review: A great stealth shooter, handicapped by its inability to tell you what the missions objectives are. There are no tool tips in mission selection to tell you what to do. Having to use google to find out what mission objectives are ahead of time makes this beautiful and challenging game abusive and neglectful. There is no quest logs, or hints that lead you to the next correct mission. Players can't find out where parts spawn in game without trial and error. The game is solid but the on ship UI and quest interface in so pathetic it makes this not worth the learning curve. The game also gives you a choice of three starting classes but there is no way to test each one with out making 3 accounts or spending cash on the other two free classes. If you like ninja shooters this is a great game to try, but until they figure out how to build a story line and a quest manual it is more of hack and slash than a well crafted game experience. Leveling seems to be completely useless in determining difficulty as stats only increase through moding your gear not through levels. This means your level 15 and your level 1 can have the same stats if you don't mod your gear. Something prehaps your constantly talking computer could mention. All and all this game is fun to play but isn't worth investing the time to figure out how to move up the ranks and play harder missions. Unless you like research this is a try and trash not a keeper.

game-hours: 21.7
review: WarFrame is super addictive and an all around fun PC Game. I can't get enough of it even if I fail a few times! Pros: -Despite WarFrames already being set for you, you are still able to customize them by color or add-ons -Graphics are amazing -Enough variety of weapons to keep you content for awhile -Having the speed and movement of a ninja makes it fun -Tons of modifications to add to your Warframe and/or Weapon to make them better without paying -Has a Window or Fullscreen Option -Pet(Companion) System -Start a Guild -Play Solo or with Others -Plenty of funny moments (Pro or Con as these are due to minor bugs with the enemies and do NOT affect the game.) -Option to "Pay and Play" Cons -Sometimes there is too much of a "glare" with lighted weapons or the Sun -Running and jumping over ledges can be fast-paced. Not being careful can send you in the wrong direction -Playing with a laptop mouse makes using the bow or guns a bit difficult as you cannot aim AND shoot at the same time. Best to get a cheap USB Mouse. Helps out in the long run. -Even there is an option to "Pay and Play", not paying could make your progress slow. (**See end of post for details) -Have to pay for minor silly things, like Color Palettes. One is given to you for free but very few select colors. ** When NOT paying to play, you can buy blueprints with money earned in the game. Unfortunately gathering materials can be a lot of work or near impossible. Once you get the materials you have to wait a few days for that Warframe or Weapons to be crafted. Tip: Something I learned in the game which made me happy. Wild Kubrows on Planet Earth can be your allies instead of enemies if you move around them correctly or in some cases not aim your weapon at them. They will attack the enemy which will distract the enemy from you either giving you the chance to shoot them down or escape. But if you shoot down the enemy be prepared to defend yourself against some Wild Kubrows.

game-hours: 404.3
review: I only tried Warframe because I noticed the art direction was exactly the same as another game, Dark Sector. Go look it up, because it's pretty neat. Anyway, it turns out Warframe was the "original" idea that Digital Extremes wanted to make. This is grand because Warframe is rather good. Back when I first started playing Warframe, it was nothing like it is now. Everything has been polished and lots of content has been added. It's your run of the mill co-op game with grinding all over the place. Thankfully, it's possible to get everything without paying a cent. Nothing outside of some cosmetics is locked from the player. All of the loot drops for schematics and parts are based on chance, but they only drop at certain locations. If you know where, you can find it. If you have some friends to play with, it's even easier to get the items. There's no publisher, such as EA, lurking over Digital Extremes and demanding things; so, there's more emphasis on pleasing the players into forking over money than resorting to  tactics to leech money, see EA (again). Chances are, you'll play this for a good 10 hours, then fork over $20 to just get a slight boost and to support DE. Warframe is a prime example of how to do Free-to-Play. Worth your time.
game-hours: 1876.5
review: I've been playing Warframes for over a year now. Up until update 14, I would have strongly reccomended this game. It ran fine on my machine with problems coming up only rarely. But, alas, since up14 it's been a bugged out mess. Sometimes I can see the UI, most of the time I can't. The planet map is at times clear, but likewise, most of the time the mission maps within the planets are undistinguishable and pixelated. Probably 25% of the time I'm in-game I experience a crash. The devs wanted to make the game more immersive, which, if they had done that within the actual missions, would have been a good idea. But they chose to redo the whole UI and greatly complicate the simple, well organized one they already had. They went for a WOW affect when you enter the game, and to some extent I think they acheived it. But in doing so it really added a lot more work to upgrade your frame or weapons. The foundry is now a total mystery to me (O, if only I could actually see it.) It's now a real PITA to make even simple changes., so sadly I've all but abandoned the game. I will check in from time to time to see if they are fixing the MANY problems, and maybe if they do I'll recommend this game. But until then, I'd pass on it, at least for now.
game-hours: 549.8
review: I have invested many hours into Warframe. Despite that, I still have mixed feelings about it. As a sort of mmo-shooter, it controls quite well, and delivers on the fantasy of playing a sci-fi space ninja in power armor shooting a machine gun while running along a wall. That said, as a F2P shooter, the game can begin to get repetitive as it asks you to either grind for materials or pony up cash to get in the fast lane. This wouldn't be that bad, but classically, someone could just buy a game for 60$. Now, 60$ will hardly unlock 1% of a game. The game is constantly being updated, which is a boon and a liability. Its always nice that there are events happening, new weapons, and new characters to play as. However, new updates often break existing gameplay or completely redo how weapons, damage, and equipment works, to the extent that if I don't play for a month, I will come back and find all my knowledge has been invalidated. I generally find myself spending more time on the wiki than in the game, as there is a lot to know and the game doesn't really seem interested in telling you most of it. That said, a lot of the enhancements being made are polishing the game to a fine shine and it has seen a lot of updates in the years its been out. With all the caveats listed above, its probably the least abusive F2P game I've played, as nearly everything of value can be unlocked in game, and the based game is actually fun (unlike so many compulsion based F2P games). If you haven't already played Warframe, here's my advice. Find a couple friends, download it together, and play in a lan-party scenario. Warframe is much funner when the focus is on having fun with friends in a bombastic world than when grinding for unlocks. Its free to try, so you might as well give it a chance.

game-hours: 265.9
review: This game is tons of fun, from the array of awesome space ninjas and beautiful graphics to the fluid combat system. I clocked hundreds of hours into it. The endgame pretty much consists of maxing out the weapons you bought or took days to build. Each time you want to make it more efficient to max out, you have to reset its level. It's free to play, but that doesn't mean it's without temptations to spend money. It's extremely expensive to upgrade some of the mods to put in your gear, and there is a whole trading market for them. However, it's not very optimized for steam, and it shows. A few updates ago, the launcher completely stopped working, so I can no longer patch or play this game. So I recommend this to any shooter fan -- if it works.
game-hours: 54.6

game-hours: 16.9
review: If you like Ninjas/Aliens, this is a game for you. You're a complete badass with a sword, primary and secondary weapon. Most items are able to be collected in game, instead of having to buy everything (Free to Play cliche). If you want to build items instead of buying them, it takes time to gather the materials and the building itself takes a ton of time, but is worth it in the end. Super fun, especially when with a group of friends. At first it can get repetitive, but the more you play and earn better items and new planets, it becomes more fun that it was when you started. Overall, great game!
game-hours: 100.5
review: The current game is quite enjoyable. Despite still being in a beta stage there is quite a lot of content, the combat system is dynamic and allows a lot of different playstyles. But since it is a beta it there are alos some bugs (which happen every now and then but generally dont cause too much problems (though you'll probably have to manually abort a few missions or alt+f4 the game). A few bugs I've encountered: game hanging on trying to find a squad, some hosting problems (especially if the host disconects), getting the wrong map, enemies not spawning correctly (like they dont spawn for a while - though this is great if you get this in interception missions <- atype of point capture mission). Clan battles (battles between clans that allow non clan members to fight for either side) are in my experience pretty laggy at times. I've several times experienced MASSIVE desyncs where I had to actually guess where the enemy that I just saw will be for my attacks to hit and see what I did seconds after it or even be completely unable to change or use my weapons. This is not a common problem but since the game is still in beta stage don't be surprised if it happens to you too. I really am looking forward to see how this game will evolve especially to see if Lotus (your ingame advisor/boss figure) will start giving actually useful inmission advice (instead of the usual ambigous ''you are surrounded by enemy'' or ''a lot of enemies ahead, prepare for a fight'').

review: I Am a Sandwich this is a fun game play it or i will take over the world and eat all humans like you eat us
game-hours: 387.2
review: Ever just want to feel like a badass? This is the game for you. You play as superpowered space-samurai, called Tenno. You and your fellow Tenno will fight across the entire solar system against a legion of bloodthirsty space marines whose very DNA is degrading from 'over-cloning'; a sprawling corporate private army of high tech robots and engineers; and the endless hordes of the 'Infested'-- a techno-virus cranked up to 11 that has mutated and corrupted the space marine clones, and the corporate robotics/engineers into relentless primal killing machines. Fear not though- for you and your brethren have at your command the power of the gods themselves. You are able to conjour up infernos, hurl lightning bolts, and bend the fabric of space-time itself. Not only this, but you are clad in ancient war armour from a lost civilization, which allows you to perform superhuman feats, and weather incredible amounts of punishment. Add to that a gigantic arsenal of weapons that would make any collector green with envy- AND the ability to use them like they were a part of your very body and you become unstoppable. You awake from cryosleep after an unknown amount of time to a devastated solar system, surrounded by multiple enemies hell bent on your utter annihilation, and have noone to rely on but your few brethren and the weapons at your side. Your enemies don't stand a chance. TL;DR: Primarily PvE. You are a badass space samurai with super powers. Aesthetics and graphics are fantastic, gameplay can get kinda grindy, but grinding is not required to enjoy the game- its only for the endgame stuff. Cash shop, but the game is not Pay To Win. (Even if it was its a pve game, so...) Finally: It is free2play so you have nothing to lose by trying it.

game-hours: 1884.4
review: warframe can not be compared to any other game i have ever played. it has a backstory and a side story going on in real time, or so it seems to me. your character doesn't have a set story, leaving you free to carve your own path but in a different way than in skyrim or fallout, general sargus ruk (boss) once said "are you just mercenaries... fighting for scraps?" which i can see as one of the best descriptions i have heard, and was meant as an insult, as you don't have a goal other than to kill people and take their stuff so that you can make more stuff to kill people with, rinse and repeat. i have seen a lot of people critizising how un-ninja like the characters are in this game what with their magic powers, excessive armor, super guns and warhammers and the like but they fail to realize that these arent your average ninja... oh no these are space ninjas. magical space ninjas fighting a cyborg clone empire, a religious group that worships tech and alien zombie versions of both of those fighting alongside each other in order to kill you. the lotus(your mission director) is leading you to preserve the balance of the war between the corpus(tech worshipers) and grineer(cyborg clones) because you don't want either side to win as the grineer want to rule the entire fricken solar system and if the corpus win then they will actively search for the tenno(you) which the only reason they arent yet is bacause they are fighting the grineer, keeping the infestation(zombies) at bay and attempting to stop AladV(I hope cuz thats in the best interest of everyone as he is experimenting on his own soldiers). the grineer are trying to take over the solar system which would be bad as they would kill the tenno and lotus as they are not grineer, and trying to find a cure for the "genetic deterioration"(does that mean they get old quickly?) that is a result of generations of overcloning. the infestation are just kinda there. and they all want your head on a silver platter. do i recommend this game? this game is not for everyone but i love it and its only going uphill from here. just keep in mind that you will have to wait when making equipment andpay about $1 (USA currency) to own more than 2 warframes, 10 weapons, two sentinel(little thingys that float above your shoulder and shoot stuff) packs(thats 1 sentinel and its corosponding weapon) and use the following colors on those things: black, most greys, purple, ocorine. so there is a slight pay barrier but nothing too serious as i havn't run into a problem with it except when choosing which warframe i like better when im makeing a new one so as long as you can make choices, like shooting cyborgs, have a stomach for blood, and can wait for stuff you will love this game

review: For a F2P game, Waframe has surely made a name for itself. This 3PS is very impressive in terms of its unique character set, diverse environmental setting and large weapon selection. As the game has progressed over time, more and more functionalities have been introduced in order to create an easier to understand interface within the modding and mapping systems. Join the Tenno forces today, if you think you're Ninja enough! P.S: Update 14 just came out! And I must say, it just sets the game to an entirely new level of OMGAWESOMESAUCENESS!!! I already thought this was possibly the best F2P game out there, but now I can say that with no doubt what so ever. The interface is far more interactive, pulling you into an interactive prologue which explains a bit about the Tenno and their history, and the intergalactic war between the Grineer (and Corpus). The game has become even more realistic on its sci-fi basis by providing players with their very own warships, to which they can build upon and travel through the voids of space in to distant and neighbouring planets. Overall, I very much so enjoyed this game. It can be a bit stressful when clearing out enemies and hakcing computer consoles, but that makes it that much more enjoyable. I like AI, how they will hide behind walls and such when they become aware of your pressence, and I find it quire humours how you can stealth kill an enemy right in front of the others and they just stand there and completly disregaurd the fact that their friend is laying on the ground with an arrow stuck in his back. Overall I'd give this game an 8/10.

game-hours: 268.1
review: Okay, so right up front: Space Ninjas. Did that sell you? If so, go ahead and install. It's free and like, space ninjas. No? Okay, i'll see if I can help. I'd call it a grindy exploitive mess, but the basic gameplay is so ridiculously solid and fun that I just don't really mind the cash-shop . The cash shop is crazy overpriced, but if you wait for the potential daily 50% off coupon it's not bad. It's also completely optional if you're okay with grinding. If you don't know, it's a third-person co-op shooter. It's got a lot of emphasis on run-and-gun though rather than the usual cover-based stuff. It's got this really cool movement system that allows neat parkour antics and the gunplay is really satisfying. It's a little unforgiving to newcomers so it's likely you'll need to look up some youtube tutorials before you understand some of the more complex systems. It's worth the time investment though. EDIT: Since writing this review the devs have gone through a lot of effort to streamline the learning experience and it's much better now. One thing i've really got to highlight is how SPECTACULAR this game runs. I was able to pump this game up to maximum setting easily on my pretty mid-range rig and it looks fantastic and runs at a full 60fps even with hundreds of characters on screen. Likewise it was optimized well enough that I got it running on my $300 laptop as well with no graphical lag at all. This game works on literally ANYTHING. Fantastic work. The world's neat looking, there's some light sprinklings of story and lore, but for the most part it's all about that grind. I like it, but it definitely takes some work to get properly into.

game-hours: 91.5
review: In essence, this is what I would have wanted from any multiplayer function to come out of Mass Effect. The feel of the game is in fact similar to the series, but differs in the heavy incorporation of platforming andstylistic choices. It is obvious that the game, at this time, has some holes, particularly in platforming controls, but it is fun and visceral. I'm always a fan of co-op games, with RPG elements in particular, and Warframe, despite some short-comings, satifies that itch. Beware though, as with many games in this monetary mold there is a strong pay-to-win feel. Nearly all items of statistic consequence can be unlocked through play, but the number of hours required to do so, in untenable to anyone unwilling or unable to put in the commitment. Also be aware that the game is built around co-op. If your connection or computer is not up to the task you may find yourself aggravating fellow players unintentionally.

game-hours: 699.3
review: After playing this game for over a year, i cannot endorse it. The latest update, U14, is a gigantice step backwards in terms of UI and functionality- instead of a simple UI designed to get you into games shooting things, the UI is now centered around a 'starship' that requires the player to physically walk around to interact with the various important functions, not to mention that the player model actually blocks parts of the UI menus- specifically in both mods and foundry. It was absolutley laden with bugs on release- despite being delayed a week, then a day- and still releasing at 6am the day after it had been delayed to. This delay pattern, by the way, is no means unique for the game. Instead of saying "it's ready when it's ready" THe devs seem content to announce a release date then fail to release the update on time. As for content: It's grind to grind, and absolutley rife with RNG issues. Master rank, the overarching player level system, has absolutley zero meaning besides a few pointless rank-locked weapons that the meta no longer considers viable. Once the majority of weapons and frames are leveled to rank 30, they can be sold. However, leveling them does nothing, as there is no endgame content to engage in. PvP was added as, at best, an afterthought, and is horifficaly unbalanced as a result. In over a year of updates, there has been no endgame, though there is some 'endgame content' promised, the currently released item, badlands or dark sectors (a shoutout to a mediocre at best title from the same company) serve only to allow players to access other missions in which to grind. Keep in mind that these issues are ones that have been ongoing since at least last March, and have not improved. Warframe has not improved significantly since it's 'release', and shows no signs of doing so. At best it provides maybe 20 hours worth of content, and that's being exceedingly generous. I haven't gone into other longstanding issues because it'd do nothing to illustrate my point further: the game isn't worth the time to play. If you're desperate for a F2P, this title may give you a night's entertainment, but if you're looking for a long term game, skip it.

game-hours: 253.6
review: I have played this game, for so many hours (I only recently obtained it on steam so my hours here doesn't do that statement much justice), and I can competently say this game is AWESOME. Flawed, but awesome nonetheless. Pros, fast paced gameplay with parkour elements, tons of weapons, warframes, and customization, and a very balanced system overall. The designs in this game are incredible and extremely unique. The designs of the warframes themselves is very unique and has this sort of, organic, alien feel to it. Combat is fun, fast, and visceral, killing tons of enemies and watching their bodies get ripped to pieces and steam from the heat of your blade is so satisfying. Plus, the graphics themselves is very flashy, with glare EVERYWHERE, giving the game a very cool and unique style to its looks. Not to mention the very interesting parkour system, sliding, wallrunning and jumping, and climbing allows you to move in some ways I've never seen in a TPS. The music is also very stylised, instead of guitar riffs or epic choirs, its all very drum heavy, attributing to the game's style of "ninjas in space." However, my problems with the game began to sink in after awhile. First off, this game is WAY too freaking grindy. So much grinding to get parts to build . SO MUCH. And its always the SAME freaking boss that you have to kill. Plus, once you finally do get enough freaking parts to build your stuff, it always takes DAYS, why? Who knows. Another thing is, while the games graphics are very appealing, the particles could definitely use some work. Explosions and blood splatters look awful, yet anything using physX actually looks really damn cool. Also, this game is way too money heavy, I like it in a F2P game where the pay currency is kept to cosmetics and thats it, but here, EVERYTHING can be bought with the pay currency. Resources, weapons, cosmetics, warframes, everything. Seriously, you can even get rid of the waiting time for your stuff with the stupid currency, its ridiculous. And if you dont pay, everything in this game then takes a lot of time, a LOT of time. However, even though this game is heavily flawed, it is an excellent game, definitely worth playing.

review: You are a cybernetic ninja fighting against an empire with a lust for war; a high-tech race of advanced cyborgs, robots, and powerful corporate conglomerates; and a scourge that threatens to wipe out and corrupt all life. Also, you are an alien. Those warmongers I mentioned? Those guys are from Earth. Those robot dudes? Experts at technological warfare and cybernetic manipulation. The scourge? It's a  Zerg infestation (FYI it's actually called "The Infestation") The best part is that your ninja isn't so crass as to be just a cybernetic alien ninja, you can have a psychic cybernetic alien ninja, a cybernetic alien ninja pyromancer, you can have a complete-screwball-who-murderapes-everything-in-his-path cybernetic alien ninja, I think you get the point. If you enjoy free running, combined with well-designed maps and environments, combined with awesome enemies and bosses, combined with powerful and badass guns, combined with uberbadass melee weapons, combined with SUPER CYBERNETIC ALIEN NINJA POWERS, then this game is for you and anyone who enjoys good games.

review: If you like Ninjas/Aliens, this is a game for you. You're a complete badass with a sword, primary and secondary weapon. If you want to build items instead of buying them, it takes time to gather the materials and the building itself takes a ton of time, but is worth it in the end. Super fun, especially when with a group of friends. At first it can get repetitive, but the more you play and earn better items and new planets, it becomes more fun that it was when you started. game-hours: 100.5
review: The current game is quite enjoyable. Despite still being in a beta stage there is quite a lot of content, the combat system is dynamic and allows a lot of different playstyles. But since it is a beta it there are alos some bugs (which happen every now and then but generally dont cause too much problems (though you'll probably have to manually abort a few missions or alt+f4 the game). A few bugs I've encountered: game hanging on trying to find a squad, some hosting problems (especially if the host disconects), getting the wrong map, enemies not spawning correctly (like they dont spawn for a while - though this is great if you get this in interception missions <- atype of point capture mission). Clan battles (battles between clans that allow non clan members to fight for either side) are in my experience pretty laggy at times. I've several times experienced MASSIVE desyncs where I had to actually guess where the enemy that I just saw will be for my attacks to hit and see what I did seconds after it or even be completely unable to change or use my weapons. This is not a common problem but since the game is still in beta stage don't be surprised if it happens to you too. I really am looking forward to see how this game will evolve especially to see if Lotus (your ingame advisor/boss figure) will start giving actually useful inmission advice (instead of the usual ambigous ''you are surrounded by enemy'' or ''a lot of enemies ahead, prepare for a fight'').

review: My re-review for this game. The early game is still difficult. But that really depends on playstyle. The first few guns are rather crap, and you can't farm very well on solo, especially early on. The remedy to this is public play or friend play. Either grab a friend or two and team up to progress to Saturn to farm for things for new warframes or weapons, or do the same with public matchmaking. Once you start off, the game gets more fun and a little less challenging. I finally finished a new melee weapon, primary, and Rhino warframe, and was much better off than I was with my Excalibur. If you intend to play this game for a while, don't waste any time finding a new frame or primary weapon. You're going to need them.

review: Awesome game once you realize it's more of a TPS dungeon crawler heavliy influenced by mass effect. Everything in the game is faily easy to obtain without money(aside from a few cosmedics) and everything is based on a RGN drop rate and can be sold/traded for in game money or in game currency. It's a flawless design, you'll never feel a need to pay and you won't feel scammed if you do pay. It has extremely fast paced, high framrate action. Definitly one of the best games I've ever played.

review: If you like explosions, constant action, co-op gameplay, and slicing & dicing, then pick up this game. In my opinion the market in this game is great. You buy a blueprint for whatever item you want (gun, new secondary, melee weapons, or a shiny new warframe to play as) and then you build it using items found during missions. This forces the player to work for their success. It also has a unique mod system that gives you anything from increased shields to more bullets. All for free, you cant go wrong picking up this game.
