game-hours: 525.1
review: I think this is the greatest Free to play game that exists. it has great mechanics, great action, a colourfull customization system, and decent teamwork. It's like Mass Effect with almost no story and a lot of shooting, hacking and slashing with kind of an rpg type character/weapons progression. Sure, it still has some annoying bugs, but that will never interfere with gameplay. The market is a raving microtransaction fest, but if you are smart, resourceful and patient; you will be able to advance your characters traits with out spending a dime (albeit slowly, but still...), just grab any materials you find in the missions, buy only blueprints in the market and take the advantage of the 50 platinum account setup gift (My suggestion for one orokin reactor and one Orokin catalyst). The graphics are solid. Great textures and lighting, moderately colourfull, but could use a lot more diversity. The missions are standard: Extermination, escort, survival, defense, assassination, abuction and so forth. It's not bad, but still could ad something more creative. There is a clan/PvP mode but that is not the highlght of the game. The co-op is. A big gripe i have with this game is that your inventory system is limited, so you'll have to sell some stuff that you worked so hard on upgrading as soon as you craft or build a few new stuff. Another thing that is bugging me is that you level up your account separately, hence some of the weapons and warframes are XP locked. This is unnecessary, since the game is charging you for those things anyway. And don't tell me that those weapons are overpowered or something like that. You can meke a basic shotgun overpowered after extensive gameplay. In conclusion, Warframe is a fun and addictive third person action game with a bright future ahead, and if you are a fan of games like Mass Effect, Metal Gear Rising: Revengance, Transformers: War for Cybertron and Vanquish and can tolerate the account lvl. up, the limited inventory system and the repetative mission design this game could be right up your alley. I give it 8 out of 10.

review: It's an MMO Third-person co-op shooter, yes a co-op shooter. The PvP conclave was added in the Update 10 in September 2013 but the heart of this game is the 4 people co-op. Each warframe have 4 different unique skills and abilities to use and quite similiar to ninjas. And when they're in space, this game is basically space ninjas shooting aliens. There are many game modes that diversify from other shooters and provide variety instead of just shooting things outright. The downside of this game and all MMOs is (of course) the "grinding" for materials and blueprints. It's still in open-beta so expect newer content, changes, and the bugs that comes with it. All in all 8/10.

game-hours: 23.7
review: Love this game - very addictive.
game-hours: 60.4
review: Only recently switched from the dev's client to steam client, mainly to make it look like i'm actually doing something on steam. Anyway, I played a moderate amount almost a year ago. The combat is very smooth, though there's a couple melee attacks that lock you in animation. Those specific animations feel quite jarring and sometimes even out of control, but thankfully there aren't many of those. I highly reccomend rebinding the slide button to something other than control, because you'll be using that a lot (sliding gives you a speed boost, and you slide in mid-air to do slide/spin attack which is very useful, slide-jump is very fast and useful too, and sliding in mid-air also gives a boost. I personally bound slide to space and jump to 't'). On that note, the movement system is quite well-made, with the exception of wall-running (the boost that you get after leaving the surface is quite uncontrollable, usually) and sometimes the jump button has too many uses (and does something you don't want it to do). Once that I've come back, the combat changed. The weapons got harder-hitting. The enemies were pretty much the same though. The difficulty actually curves downwards as you get the necessary upgrades, then later starts to curve upwards as enemies start to do more and more damage. If there's one major flaw about the game, it would be the amount of grind there is. This game is mostly for getting the most flashy items to show to your friends, as prime weapons take quite a substantial time to grind for. Prime warframes take even longer. Stalker weapons would be another; the dread and the despair are the best bow and kunai, respectively, but they require you to get a stalker's mark and summon him to defeat him. The amount of grinding for stalker hunts is quite ridiculous, considering that he has a 1.5% spawn rate (up to 2.5%, i believe). The missions are also quite repetitive and boring. It's still all about 'go in, shoot everything, get out'. This game also has a tendency to give older players an advantage (mostly to keep them playing, i guess). Such as the cicero/tethra mods, snipetron vandal, and more recently the breeding grounds. With the exception of one event (primed chamber, which only slightly more than 101 copies were handed out), these events don't really give a large advantage to old players. They do give them a slight edge, however slight it may be. Last line: Great to mess around with if you're willing to get past the first bit of the difficulty curve, but it quickly gets repetitive and boring. I'd recommend only for the experience of a different shooter, since its movement doesn't have any parallels. Its combat though... that one I'll leave up for grabs.
game-hours: 199.6
review: The best part about this game to me is that even though you can spend real money and get almost anything you want at the start, it really doesn't matter since skill still plays a huge part in what you can and cant do. Also there is nothing that cant be gotten by farming, and there is even stuff that you can only get by farming that is not available in the market. The game can be a little repetitive, but what isn't entertaining about being a space ninja and running into a crowd of enemies and killing them all with throwing knives, or killing them with a blast of fire. Play this game, you won't regret it.

game-hours: 30.8

game-hours: 20.6
review: Nice game, I play it on Intel HD Graphic.
game-hours: 1253.6
review: This game has changed tremendously over the last year and for the better. When I first started playing back in June '13, it was a cool little game to just collect stuff in, level up items, and fool around a bit. The game underwent a major overhaul for its PS4 release and is now expanding in all categories including lore, map variety, mods, weapons, and warframes. I updated this review pre-update 14, and the additional quest/lore system, upcoming mass-UI, and player ships are HUGE improvements to look forward which will further solidify the game as a serious and unqiue title. The mechanics are very attractive, mixing fast movement with gunplay/melee combat and the special powers of each warframe. The mod system can change up combat as you see fit, and any gun/melee/warframe is viable with enough love put into it. The graphics are bright and shiny, and the game is pretty well-optimized for older systems. Tile sets for maps are finally taking the game off of ships and onto planets. Sounds for enemies and environments continue to be updated for the better. Dojos offer players a way to create clans and design/decorate their own "house" of sorts. Warframes and weapons can have customized color, attachements, armor, skins, and syndanas (scarves). Best of all, the game boasts a dedicated developer team who usually respond quickly and respectfully to the thoughts and wishes of the community. They even run live streams which are fun to watch and offer a kind of interaction that a lot of games miss. One of the biggest improvements I've seen due to this dev-player interaction is through events, which were once extremely annoying due to their setup but are now engaging and fair to both the occassional player and the diehard clan alike. The cash shop for this game is also rather extreme but this is F2P and to be expected. The game lacks dedicated servers, but several changes put into the grouping system have made joining a terrible host much less common. The pve/psueo-pvp Dark Sector system was arguably released too early and right now doesn't offer players/alliances much benefit. However, with DE's track record, it's suitable to have faith the Dark Sectors will continue to be improved upon. There is an actual pvp system in the game, but having never bothered with it, I can't offer any opinion. RNG is perhaps the one big drawback of this game. Much of the game's content relies on RNG, which after a while gets very tiresome. To date, not much has been done to allow players to have some influence over RNG (except outright buying said items through store or prime access) and there are many tweaks that could be made to make things less grindy. Yet, there's a lot of good in the game and all the reason to trust that improvements will continue. If the game had some kind of membership system, I'd definitely buy into it without a second thought. It's plenty obvious this game is growing and growing quickly under focused guidance. It's good to see a team that's not afraid to remain in the beta phase and still get stuff done. High hopes for this one!
game-hours: 22.3
review: Im having some login issues where it keeps adding unessisay letters and my war frame freezes in the middle of game play but other then that the game is excellent

review: This game gets crap from people for being pay-to-win. It has no such aspect. This game has given me countless hours of fun while not having to pay a dime. If you do want the Platinum, you can sell/trade things to other players who have payed, or trade them for a piece of equipment you have a hard time finding. The Devs do their job by releasing updates constantly bettering the game for its players, putting up livestreams, checking the forums for bugs and many other things. A++++ for Warframe.

review: I believe this game has much potential. It needs improvment in areas espicially how it runs. At first i thought the diffuculty was my PC, even though other games run very smooth on it, so i put everything graphics wise to its absolute lowest and still encounterd frame rate drops. Although thats the great thing about PC games, they can be greatly improved. Beyond that, this is a tuly an amazing game and im yet to encounter any bugs. Combat is very cool and addicting with great wall running mechanics and animations that truly make you feel like a cyber ninja. missions are HUGE and should take you and your friends, assuming your online, awhile to complete. The Ai works well, you wont really be challenged unless your alone however. Platnum is the worst money drainer as i only have 40 platnum without paying, and items cost all the way to 300 platnum. You can choose from 3 starting characters, and need alot of platnum to get more. as a score, its atleast an 8/10. i didnt really get into the story, which is good but pretty confusing, and you might not get as many frame rate drops as i did. Overall this is an amazing free to play game that i highly recomend.

game-hours: 578.8
review: In all honesty, I can't truly "recommend" this game, as in my opinion, a "recommendation" is something that you would give a game that you can play as a "Main" game. Something like Battlefield, or Ghost Recon. Something that has depth to the gameplay, and a variety of ways to play. While this game does have some depth, and some variety, it's mostly surface level. There is very little variation in missions. The most variation you'll get is what KIND of mission you pick. And even then, your stuck with only a few options. Namely massacre all the enemies, rescue a prisoner, grab some intel, plant false information, sabatoge a generator, or some variant of Capture the Flag. Basically. But that in no means makes this a bad game. It's fun as a kind of off game when you want to shoot some stuff up, sure. The gunplay is tight, rewarding, and the variations of weaknesses that each enemy has (Again though, a very limited amount) requires you to learn what works best against what faction, and within that, what enemy within each faction specifically.

All in all Fun for the first week or two then just gets frustrating and repetitive without getting into groups, or active clans.

game-hours: 6.2
review: not too big and still good
game-hours: 296.8
review: If you like horde style slash 'em ups this is the game for you. Set in a Sci-Fi setting as a Tenno warrior, a really cool space ninja, you go and fight hordes of enemies. The game is in 3rd person, but what does this do for the game? A lot. The wallruns and flips would be near impossible with another model and with this 3rd person model it adds to the impact of what you do. When fighting enemies it gives you and your Warframe the benefit of seeing your enemies unlike if it was 3rd person. The fighting is what carries the game, with the combat being extremely visceral and gorey. While this setting can be turned off, and may have to be if you have a weak system, it adds to the enjoyment of the fighting. You can use guns, melee weapons, and the skills of your Warframe in battle. This may sound like a weak experience given similar games on the market, Warframe's appeal comes from the sheer variety and difficulty that the game offers. There are 3 different enemy types on the game, all different in how they are to fight against. The Grineer are not unlike enemies you'd see in a CoD Survival mode, the Infested are like fighting the flood from Halo, and the Corpus are tech. reliant faction like the Covenant from Halo. This enemy variety means that you have multiple options in fighting on Warframe, and with multiple enemy types within each faction, you'll likely only be bored after countless hours of fighting them. The fighting itself is what carries the game, as I have stated previously in this review. There are many different weapons that you can use, but you are limited to 3 weapons at any given point. A primary weapon, a bow if you'd like, a assault rifle, a shotgun, and a sniper rifle are the extent of your options in this category. Secondaries are limited though, with a few types of unique weapons (such as Kunai), with the rest of the weapons being pistols. Melee is the most interesting aspect of combat though. Heavy weapons, light weapons, dual weapons and others make up this category. Each weapon plays differently with different qualities making each weapon unique and fun to play with. These three categories are further supplemented by attachments, or as Warframe calls them, or Mods. Mods take multiple forms, from elemental damage mods to fire rate mods. Because of the many different types of mods available on Warframe this means that there are enough different playstyles available to make every weapon setup unique to each player. Mods are essential in succeeding on Warframe, and leveling them up is even more important than that. This is a problem with the game though, along with acquiring additonal Warframes to play with. Mods take a long time to acquire. By 100 hours and 20$ spent on platinum I have multiple pages avallable, with many at extremely high levels. This took hours of farming to accomplish, and real life currency--while this could have been avoided. This took most of my in game currency as well, keeping me well below levels to acquire parts for weapons and warframes. This leads to the next issue of the game, the crafting system. While I will be the first to applaud it for being one of the fairest I have seen in a free-to-play game, like the process of acquiring mods and leveling them up it is very tedious. Acquiring the blueprints for weapons will cost in game currency, not platinum though, which take time to farm and acquire. The foundry system then requires more farming to get the bits and pieces to make the weapon on top of buying a blueprint--lengthening the time it takes to get the weapon that you want. Warframes are the toughest to acquire on Warframe. Each part requires farming extensively in game in order to acquire that part. Then it requires you to build each part and then combine all of these parts to finally build the warframe they wanted. The tediousness that follows this process makes it seem like nothing is being accomplished or done in game, which pressures players to purchase the in-game currency of platinum. The question that then follows is: Is it worth it? I can say that it is with certainty. While there is a slight entry fee to play as much as you'd like, when you do the game becomes a lot of fun and enjoyable to play. Once you spend that fee, around 20$, the game opens up and allows you to play with many new weapons and warframes. Late-game there isn't too much to do other than continuously farm for new items to play with along with warframes. So, if you want to play a horde killing game and feel like a badass, Warframe is the game for you.

review: I have been playing this game for almost two years now, and I have seen this games ups and downs. I'll start of by saying that this is a VERY good game that you can play for hours on end. You should definetely give this game a try if you want: 1. An active and friendly community. 2. A long lasting game that you will play for a while. 3. Bugs that take like a year to patch. (lol) In all my time playing this game I have never really come up with any problems, other than those bugs that the Devs are finally fixing. The community is great, I have never gotten into an argument with anyone (which is rare for me). By the time you're finished with the latest update/patch there will already be a new update with a crap-load of new content. Best of all, you don't HAVE to pay to get everything. Although buying platinum makes things easier, you can obtain everything in the game without having to pay a penny, with the exception of one or two guns. 10/10

game-hours: 387.4
review: Warframe appeals to me, in a way that very few games manage. Even going through a single mission, every replay gives you a randomly assembled path. Where you once ran through a deforested and fortified energyplant on earth, you'd run through a thriving forest, filled with wildlife and overgrown walkways, leading to a complete change in the required maneuvers. Suddenly, instead of sliding down a flat hill, you're urged to climb between and steep stone wall, and climbing across branches. And this is leaving out the robotic Corpus faction, with their pristine interiors with hidden airducts, teleporters, criss-crossing walkways and their fuel tunnels, as well as the robust Grineer faction, with their rugged barracks and chemical plants, AND the parasitic Infestation, that not only changes the gunplay, but also brings a sprawling atmosphere, were EVERYTHING around you is alive, and possibly deadly. The weapon types are many, diverse, equally powerful as they are breathtaking. Whether you find yourself yearning for an explosive bow-n-arrow, a chaotic tesla rifle, a powerful shotgun with poisonous shells or a scythe that literally blows an enemy apart rather than cutting them open, is all up to you. Combining element mods lets you play with fire, ice, electricity and poison, in whichever combination you like, and the best part, is that with multiples of the same element type, you can create double the effect, such as explosive gas, or a viral radiation. Warframe allows you to change your gameplay on the fly, offering ways to go completely unseen, aswell as giving no quarter as to how much of a pounding that you'll get, should you get spotted. What's that? A brutish adversary is throwing flaming hazards and explosives everywhere? Well, we'll just open a window for that to clear up. IN OUTER SPACE!
game-hours: 377.9
review: Warframe is a great game. Its offers alot for what you're paying (which is nothing). you are a ninja like thing called a tenno and your job is to cleanse the solar system of the enemy factions. It has great graphics and great gameplay. If you download this game you will not be disappointed.
game-hours: 1365.7
review: Let me start by saying that warframe, in no way, forces a pay2win style of play. This is the best part about the game. If you could buy it with real money, you can find it somewhere in game with enough time and patience. The gameplay is repetitive, this is the games biggest weakness, but there is some varience in regards to how you accomplish the goals. In PVE, you are trying to kill x enemies, kill specific enemies, or gather x macguffins, etc... The frame (the character class essentially) varies your abilities, speed, and base stats. Each frame has a good theme to it. Excalibur is very much your jack of all trades class being very balanced, Mag focuses on magnetic type attacks, Volt on electric ones, etc... Some frames are better suited to most tasks, dealing more damage, or providing better control of enemy forces. Once you find something you like though, you can stick with it and use upgrades to make it much stronger. PVP has just been introduced in terms of clan vs. clan play. It is in the works of being balanced, and while some classes outright dominate others, there is still some fun to be had. It is true some are "better" than others on paper, but there is nothing stopping you from using any gun. Machine guns, sniper rifles, semi-auto rifles, magnums, six-shooters, and more for guns. Melee is also quite fun with many "stance" mods, or fighting styles, allowing combos, which is essentially the timing of the attack button with few inputs other than that. Farming these stance mods can be tedious though, some being ridiculously rare and dropping off rare enemies, others just being so common you sell them for some credits. You get axes, hammers, swords, daggers, katanas, and even a boomerang. Variety is there, so find your favorite. Finally, the game is constantly being developed and DE, the developer, is very involved with the community. Events and updates are out often enough to satisfy most players. If you want some quick action and good play, give it a shot, it is free after all.

review: Warframe is a good game. One of its best features is its beauty. Everything in the game looks crisp and clear from the environments on the different planets to your warframe's armor and abilities. Charging in and destroying waves after waves of enemies by using your amazing powers is a great experience and seeing how to coordinate them with your teammates makes it even more enjoyable. The downside of this game is its repetitiveness. Missions, environments, and enemies lack in diversity. Even the method to upgrade your warframe is repetitive. You need to reach max rank to "upgrade" and once that is done you start at zero rank all over again. This is a enjoyable game to play but it might get boring after awhile.

game-hours: 8.2
review: awesome game
game-hours: 28.2
review: Warframe is a game that some close friends recommended to me to try out. It's free so I thought "why not?" I was greeted with a rather hectic and somewhat all over the place tutorial. There was a recent update as of writing this that apparently changed the tutorial for new players and even though I have not seen it, I have good faith the game devs put all the feedback and advice they got in order to change it for the better. The game is a 3rd person shooter, which for me is a real eye catcher. In today's gaming world, most games that want to involve shooting almost all go for the obvious first person perspective. Warframe changes that and I will say that at first it feels a bit awkward to play, over time you get used to it and after a few setting changes, you are ready to go. Now the controls and control mappings are a bit awkward, I have mapped out all the buttons that I need to keys that are somewhat easy and more comfortable for me to reach. It still feels a bit awkward though but I don't have one of those super uber gaming mice that have 10 buttons on it so I can't really blame the game for that. The graphics are alright, I don't really like to judge a game by graphics alone, but although not the best... It's decent. The whole going to different planets and different missions, as well as the ability to play with other players/friends or by yourself is pretty neat. The missions however, are not too exciting. There is several mission types: kill all enemies, collect the maguffin, capture and hold the points, survive waves of enemies till you die or leave, kill boss dude... It's all great... but all the planets have the same types of missions just with different enemies and evironments. It get's a little stale after a while, which can effect the replay value. Speaking of, the replay value is pretty great. You can customize your character, make new characters, new weapons. Its all there, but its a little weak due to having some items (most cosmetic though) cost real money. Making new weapons and blueprints for different characters requires farming and grinding which can turn alot of people off. This 3rd person shooter/rpg mixture has alot of potential, but it is boged down with somewhat over complicated mechanics and tedious farming. Final thoughts... It's not a perfect game, not by a long shot. However, I would not say its a bad game. It's free right now so give it a shot, if you don't like it... then that's fine. If you like it... Then awesome! This game is certainly something that will take most gamers out of their comfort zones, and I appreciate Warframe for doing that.

game-hours: 231.7
review: Great Game
game-hours: 2343.8
review: I've played this enough to tell you that it's getting better. It already started out good when it went open beta. Most players who had issues sighted mostly repetetive play. Oddly enough, that can be said about most games that people love playing, from pacman to Call of Duty. I've read other reviews giriping about the enemy AI, to be honest, I think it's about right, tech reliant corpus have and numerically superior Grineer enemies use both flanking and cover fire, map and mission specifics do come into it, but really, their AI doesn't need to be more than rudimentary. The other faction; infested, are close quarters, flood-like opponents. A practiced squad of players can cope with even high level opponents, but the game has a knack of overwhelming you at surprising moments that you'll be leaning on your teammates for. Complaints around the games thin plot and game lore is again, a matter of personal perspective, I don't need or want masses of information for a game that is combat centric, it's nice, but ultimately unecessary. A degree of preference certainly comes into it. I've had masses of fun with only a few moments of being pissed off. The causes of the latter have been taken care of through the updates from 6 all the way to update 14 that has again, pushed the game a lot further with a massive UI overhaul and newer gameplay elements (Kubrows are awesome) I've enjoyed the games technical consistency. The bugs have been almost invisible to me. The community side is certainly growing. Trading has been an excellent addition, and the upcoming player ship is something I really am looking forward to. This game is constantly improving. game modes introduced through events will be made persistent instead of one offs, giving more variety of play. You can go totally Ninja now and use just a melee weapon (seriously good fun) Plus, weapons and Warframes are now varied enough to allow players to specialise. Wrapping up, DE is doing a good job, and when you weigh that against the cost of playing (which is very very little) Warframe really is a frakking awesome game.

game-hours: 358.2
review: Short review: Good: Very fun gameplay, deep customization, lots of special missions, decent bosses, good friend system (used to be bad but was fixed) and a well-thought out clan system. Bad: Bad level design, parkour aspect not put to its fullmost potential. Ugly: Repetition, lack of completely different gameplay modes, requires a massive amount of patience. Long review: Warframe takes the ridiculous idea of ninja space pirates and puts it into effect, and I must say, they did a good job at it. If you already don't know, the game is a third-person shooter which involves a lot of running and gunning, slicing and dicing, and of course, looting. Each Warframe which you choose to play as is very unique in their own ways; you have one that can pull enemies in or crush them, one that can revive the dead and have them fight for him, one that can conjuire tornados, and some samurai-focused ones which focus on stronger melee attacks and whatnot. The game's story is very lackluster; you have two factions, the Grineer and Corpus, fighting against one another, with the Warframes, known as the Tenno, being the in-between faction whom are interested in gathering treasures, along with a fourth faction known as the Infested which are basically fungi-like parasites or something. There are some supernatural elements and legacies too, not that it's all too important. In terms of gameplay, Warframe is very fluid and fast, combining lots of different attacks, maneuvers, and so on for each of your Warframes. Many of the maps in this game are massive, and there are often different paths to take everytime, although the game does have a knack of limiting your movement and giving you a single path however. Many of the levels do have some secret rooms which require a bit of parkouring skill to reach at times, although this isn't true for all maps of the game. One major downfall is that while the game does include wall running and climbing, none of the maps are designed to allow you to use such tactics mid-combat, but only to traverse specific gaps, which is the greatest downfall for the game maps. Still, the game could benefit with new maps, as there tends to be a ridiculous amount of missions but only around eight maps in total. In short, the maps for this game aren't all that impressive. Warframe both has an abundance and shortage of content. For abundance, there are tons of mods to use to upgrade your weapons and Warframe, not to mention several special missions types, secret enemies, special rewards, and so on. Your weapons range from pistols, rifles, shotguns to bows, rocket launchers, laser beams, and so on. There are several damage types too, and several factors for each weapon, giving the player a lot of calculation and planning out to do to obtain the ultimate build. For shortage, it's the repetition. This game is VERY repetitive. The missions are always the same, even for special missions, and the ones that aren't usually have very slight variances between them. To add to that, sometimes you'll be finding yourself replaying missions you already completed just to get the resources which you need to build your next weapon or item, with a resource system that makes it a very tedious task, as you are given small changes for resources per drop while crafting costs you thousands of that resource. Truth be told, however, the game does have a very fun combat system, which partially, but not completely, excuses them. There's also a clan system, which also offers a lot of customizability and other extras, such as trading, obstacle courses, and research labs for special weapons, to players. The friend system in this game used to be terrible, but it's good to see that this has been fixed - at least on my side. The Pay 2 Win model in Warframe locks at least one or two items from every category for non-premium players, and often makes it a whole lot easier to buy the item that you want instead of having to go through all the tedious farming. Still, the system is not too broken. The game will still lock off stronger weapons for newcomers, meaning that neither premium nor freemium will be able to purchase those weapons unless by rising in ranks, which takes a TON of playtime. I don't have a lot of experience with free online games, as Warframe is the only one I dared play, but I personally think this is a fair system; not too broken to make freemium players feel left out, nor to make premium players feel that their donation was not for something worthwhile - at least if you don't buy the packs, since one of them gives you one of the best secondary weapons in the game. Only the cosmetics are entirely locked to premium members. On the plus side, the game does give you 50 spending currency of the premium monetary system, which isn't much, but you can still use them. While the game is still very fun, some people will complain over how it takes a ridiculous chunk of time and gameplay before one can actually get anything good. Your starting weapons are complete trash, with the exception of the pistol (when I started, it was bad, but I think they fixed that), and the game will require you to play for hours before you can start getting weapons that are far much better. Thankfully, they made it easier to purchase some weapons for beginners, which is a relief. My recommendation is to play Warframe unless you are a very impatient person. It's free anyways, and the filesize of the game is around 4 GB of download, so why not? However, the amount of grinding required to be able to get through this game is ridiculous, so be careful. Tip: Both the Braton and Strun are decent weapons to replace your rubbish primary weapon, at least until you can start getting some of the better weapons. Plus, both are weapons which you can easily buy right off the bat. For secondaries, you have the Magnus, although you do need mods to increase its critical damage to improve it. Chronus is also a good sword to replace your other worse sword, at least until you reach higher levels. Also, there is no specific "best weapon": most of the weapons are good and balanced, so pick whichever suits your playstyle. You might also want to constantly check the Warframe wiki for weapon stats, enemy stats, Warframe builds, and so on.

game-hours: 1.2
review: I LOVE IT. Thats all I have to say. <3
game-hours: 1013.1
review: *Final Review* So I have a lot of time under my belt playing Warframe and I'd like to give credit where it's due. First off gameplay is a lot of fun in this game. If you enjoy 3rd person shooter+co-op action you won't find a better game, especially for free-fiddy. At first it's a bit slow and takes awhile to gather the 'must haves'. Once you get the hang of how the mods and powers work, you'll be blasting through enemies day in 'n day out. There's plenty to keep you busy and a ton of different weapons and frames(characters/tenno/classes) to earn. You can literately get anything in the game without paying a single $. You most likely won't mind spending a bit on the game after playing it for awhile though. You can always find a match doing one of the many game modes and as long as you spend your first free 50 credits on orokin catalyst and/or orokin reactors to boost your gear, you can play all the content and do very well at it. So here's the run down. Gameplay 7/10 Why not a full 10? It is by far one of my most enjoyed games in a few years, but I started awhile ago and have earned most of what I find interesting already. While the game provides non-stop action on a variety of maps, after so long I find the process of getting new equipment or hunting for new mods extremely boring and repetitive. It was bad to the point I would make all fresh gear and start back on the first map, then play the first worlds through helping new players, because it was more gratifying than spending 100 hours farming 1 map for 1 mod that only drops from 1 unit that spawns 5 times on that 1 map and has a 0.001% drop rate. At first you won't notice this at all. I can only play the same content repeatedly with different skins over it so many times. But other than that, it's fun to play. Controls are great, takes some getting used to before you get full ninja status. You do feel powerful when playing almost all characters, some where nerfed a little to much and are less useful. Some of the maps are truly well designed and look great. Audio 9/10 One point of because some sounds are always at max volume even when produced far away. Buuut... Great audio on guns. Powers have curious and well suited sounds. Music during certain parts, *such as rushing towards the exit and getting that bogo drum roll* are really well placed and immerse you. Noise from enemies plays well in the enviroment, letting you tell distance with foot steps or voices. AND THE VOICES! AHAHA! eh.. Each of the enemy races have their own languages, pretty interesting to listen to them shout commands for taking you out. Graphics 10/10 While not super HD impressive mode. They are really intense, especially when played on max settings. But most importantly is the art style of the Tenno themselves that warrents a full 10 points of golden credit here. Some things are a little weird... like too many male Tenno having a giant crotch protector piece on their armor.. yeah.. But other than that visually pleasing to play. Plenty of glow effects and bouncing neon particles to entertain your meek little brain. Story/RP 2/10? There just isn't a ton of content here, I mean there is plenty to read about and you can prowl around on the forums for more. But I didn't find it engaging or well included in the game as you play. You have to seek it out on your own and apply it the same. Still an amazingly unique and beautifully done concept. Would like to see more Tenno to Tenno interaction or an explanation about the giant three headed monster trapped in this tiny room on an old spaceship adrift in the void and how it managed to survive there.. and where did it poop. NOT-P2W 9/10 Only reason this doesn't get a 10/10 is because not buying the orokin catalyst/cores means you will be at half strength until you do and they do not come around in events often. Also there is a HUGE market in this game selling items you can only get by playing high level content. Some things that took me months to grind for at the start you can now buy for pennies on a dollar. 50$ can essientially buy you all the 'leet gear' (Prime frames, weapons, super rare mods) because people will sell extremely cheap just to get that extra 10 plat for a slot! But you can really earn everything for free, by selling in game items... or being extremely patient. Overall I give it a 9/10 - kept my interest for a long time and that is very difficult for games these days. If you are thinking about trying it, stop. DOWNLOAD IT NOW. Just give it some time, you won't be pwning es in the first 5 seconds and people will be waaaaaaay stronger and faster than you sometimes. It is unfair for high levels to be farming low end maps BUT try to watch how they move and copy them. As long as you're fast and mobile, you're a good ninja!

game-hours: 38.2
review: TL;DR: Warframe is an addictive, fast-paced, and unique spin on tradition 3rd-person shooters that is well worth a try, but might not hold your interest for too long. Not TL;DR: Despite what steam says, I have been playing Warframe for quite a long time before I connected it to steam, have done everything from the lowest to highest level missions, and have invested time into playing it in as many different ways as I could, so you can trust me as a reviewer. Warframe is certainly a unique experience that constantly rewards you for your time, and can hold your attention for hundreds of hours...but then again so can Candy Crush and Farmville. Warframe is very fast-paced, action-packed, and lives up to it's unofficial descriptor of "Space Ninjas". It is NOT pay-2-win, no matter what anybody else might say. Every item in the game has it's purpose, and almost anything you can get with real money you can get for free as long as you're willing to put a little bit of time into it (the only exception to this is cosmetic items that do nothing for the game besides make you look different. But even then, you can still sell rare items on trade chat for platinum to go and purchase those cosmetics). The graphics are beautiful, although they have a few bugs. The gameplay is fluid and rewarding, although it can get a bit old after a while. The game is certainly grindy, but that can be overlooked due to the fact rewards are constant enough to make you feel like you're actually doing something with your time, and as I said before, it has the exact same addiction factor as Candy Crush does...doing the same thing over and over again, but the illusion of difference is put over it enough, and doing that same thing is fun enough that it keeps you coming back for more. The community is somewhat garbage, as "Space Ninjas" tends to draw in little kids that think it's cute to "troll" region chat and do everything they can to sabotage a mission and throw tantrums frequently when they don't get their way, but a good portion of the people playing Warframe are mature enough to enjoy playing online, although if you so desire, you can set it so you only play with friends, or play offline if you choose (although harder missions make playing offline near-impossible if you don't know the game really well). Playing online also comes with issues, as the game has no servers beyond account data saves and chat, and so uses peer-2-peer hosting for missions. So if the host has crap internet, you will experience a lot of lag that will get annoying VERY quickly. The game also, being in open-beta, updates frequently enough that things are always changing, so you won't stay too bored for long. The story of the game is hard to follow and pointless, although it is pretty interesting if you take the time to research lore, but otherwise it's just there as filler to give a vague reason for why you are parkouring through space stations and planetary bases obliterating entire legions of enemies. All in all, Warframe is 100% worth a try, and I HIGHLY recommend it to any gamer interested in shooters. It is easy to become addicted to this game but it is also just as easy to get bored with it.

review: Four words: Cybernetic Ninjas with Guns. The game is a 4 of 5 or a 7 of 10. It has good graphics and great gameplay. The game is still is a work in progress and the new updates are polishing up an already well-built game. The co-op is the fondation of the game, but a bit of a let down when you are forced to race through a mission because your teammates decide to race to see who can kill the boss the fastest. This can be fixed by communication with the teammates or knowing your team, however it can be a time consuming to find people who operate like you do or will tolerate scavenging for resources (which is essential). The mod and upgrade menus are pretty straight forward and easy to use. I would recommend if you like the shooting of Halo, the free-running of Mirror's Edge, and the sword play of Dynasty Warriors.

game-hours: 935.7
review: Man...where to begin? Are you still searching for the one? this is the one! First of all, after you download this game and start playing a little bit, you'll question yourself; How is this even possible? is this actually free? This, literally can't be free, there must be some mistake --------WF---------------------------------------------------- And i'm not overrating it i'm serious if it weren't free i wouldn't be surprised, Warframe is a hero among others in its age, Pros: +Not a Pay-To-Win. +Amazing graphics, even more amazing, amazing-er with the nVidia physx effects. +Honest Free-To-Play, no paywalls what so ever. +On market, if you want something, you can have it by hunting the resources for it, or its parts. +Really friendly community, ask something you don't know on the 'Region' channel and get a quick answer or if you ask for help you'll get it pretty soon. +The support desk for glitches and bugs and after-update-things Will look into it and figure it out. +Constant new Weapons and new Warframe, with every update you'll see new stuff and maybe, sometimes a bit of the Warframe story/Lore. +New player often told the devs that they can't figure out how this unique warframe universe works- or you know simply how-to-play, the last few updates added the game a huge guide for the new players, you can actually learn the whole game by simply checking it out +A short prologue after you signed in for the first time, will help you greatly. Cons: -There is no actual storyline the player can follow, this is one of the few cons i can tell, so if you want an epic story like a- umm like mass effect? you might not like this. -Yes it Can get repetetive, but the game itself is really awesome, its there when you want it. -The other thing is, lets say you have a finished weapon in the foundry but you reached the capacity of your storage, you have to buy slots with plats the same thing goes with the Warframes too, the game gives you 50 plats at the beginning i recommend using it on the capacity. But you can always use the trade to have the plats, i actually buy plats time to time but i usually use the trade in the game to get plats. I actually regret saying the last con (but as the years past by the steam rewiews are important for the player), beacuse a game like Warframe with a developer team like this, i don't mind buying slots, these guys deserve it, With every update a huge improvement, a lot of new stuff, Dedicated players, a huge community with ever-active match-making, its Warframe and its an honest F2P. Plus, it's cool and it's always there whenever you wanna blow stuff up or assasinate silently, and its free so why not?

game-hours: 1704.6
review: with over 1,400 hours of gameplay i can give you a great review on this game. If you like being able customize your gun, pets, characters and other stuff, this game offers amazing options for that. If you like fast paced action, slicing enemies in half and seeing the epic gore as you feel like a god among the weaklings this game offers that too. Being space ninjas known as Tenno that are given missions by the Lotus(our female overlord) your job is to keep the solar system in balance. Yes you get to go planet to planet and moons as well as you fight the enemy factions! There are the Grineer which are future USMC soldiers that have robot parts, their main leader is Captain Vor. There are also the Corpus, which are a greedy army of humans that use robotic technology to help them in combat. They are what i call futuristic asians lol. Another faction is the Infested, which is basically grineer and corpus + other creatures that got infected with the technicide virus and turned into vicious freaky creatures that stop at nothing to rip your face off. There are bosses of each factions, infact theres about 1 boss per planet/moon in the solar system. BEST THING EVER ABOUT THIS GAME OVER ALL IS THIS. It is free to play. You can pay to get a currency called Platinum which you can use to buy color pallets/ slots for more weapons and guns if you are too lazy to farm for, BUT if you are too poor to buy some, don't worry you can trade with rich players and get platinum from them instead. I personally buy platinum all the time because i love buying cool decorative armor and stuff but you can go your whole life on this game and not spend 1 single penny ever and still be as powerfull as the guy who spent over 100$ already (like i did :P ) I recommend this game, i recommend you change the video settings as well. I dont like the blur or the color correction option and i also dont like the bloom option. But to each their own. this game is 10/10 and the developers are so funny and they love their players and we love them. They even added a feature in the game just because i asked for it. Its pure simple fun and there is always something to do. Coming Update 15 (i dont know when u are reading this) but update 15 is going to blow people away and i hope you stick around because it is worth playing

review: A fun third person shooter with a lot of dynamic options on how to achieve the mission objectives within missions. The difference between marching down a hallway in nearly invincible armor burning everything in your path or sneaking behind an enemy commander and riddling them with arrows can be achieved by the difference of a warframe and a single weapon. And each unit gets 3 weapon slots per mission (primary ranged weapon, secondary ranged weapon, melee weapon) allowing for many unique capabilities even among the same warframes. And there are hundreds of mods that change damage type and weapon capabilities, making each weapon unique to its owner.

game-hours: 1136.8
review: Despite peoples claims for it being a "Pay2Win" game you'd be terribly mistaken. All frames are obtainable through regular play. You can choose to invest real money if you so wish to get the frames you wish or you may choose to get it as you would with any other game. It's not a mmo, more of a 4-player Co-op Third Person action game. Allowing you to take control of a Warframe. Refered too as "Tenno" the race controlling it. (Basically you're a space ninja.) You get to zip line, Run along walls, back flip walls, slash a big  sword and generally kick . There are three factions: Corpus, Grineer and Infested. Infested: The Infested are mostly melee based. With strange alien/corrupted creatures that can inflict deadly poisons or maul you to death. Corpus: The Corpus are like the evil science type guys. These have Moa robots. (Practically guns with legs.) They mostly use lazer weapons. Not only that there are melee corpus who make use of electric prods. (nasty) As well as the annoying shield spray robots which can repair the shields of foes around it, Grineer: The Grineer unlike the corpus have more "standard*" type weapons. Less futuristic. They also have melee uses who try to slice you. You'll find them doing a lot of damage if they successfully land a hit. Originally this game had started off as something so very small. With only a few frames: Loki, Excalibur, Volt, Rhino and Mag it slowly started growing and becoming so much more. Really basic levels and basic movement and have strongly benefitted from constant player feedback improving the game with every update. The game is extremely responsive however be prepared to get a hand ache after hours of play with how much you need to keep moving to avoid enemies and help allies. One minor issue for me is that this game lacks any cover mechanic. (enemies can cover but you are unable to.) Blocking is in the game but it also feels rather pointless since I've found myself in little to no situations where it was actually neccesary or helpful. It is also assigned by default to mouse button 4. If you're old fashioned like me and have a mouse with only 3 buttons you may need to assign it to a spot on your keyboard. The game is simple, the graphics amazing. It works on my really sub-standard PC with a graphics card as basic as an ASUS EAH6450 with a simple (God-awful) AMD Athlon 64 Processor 3200+ 1.99 Ghz and 3.00GB of RAM running Win-XP SP3. (Yes this pc is about as old as the hills.) You may not be able to play with friends with a PC like this but you sure as hell can play the game at well over 30fps and as far as I'm concerned that is absolutely astonishing. Considering many other games with worse graphics than this run about as fast as a snale on salt. Do I recommend this game? Hell yes, I would recommend it to everyone. Even if you wouldn't like it. Try it anyway since it's free to play and you really just can't complain. (I've had more hours out of this beauty than I have out of any AAA $60.00 piece of over hyped trash.)

game-hours: 23.6
review: Digital Extreames. You might know the name looking on the back of the StarTrek game of 2013. They did awful on that, so this has to be the same right? If you think that Warframe is the same as StarTrek, please, download this game to see how wrong you are. StarTrek had some hype to it. It looked good, but playing was not the same. Warframe didn't have much hype when I first downloaded it. It looked too good for my computer, and so after turning down the graphical settings, I finally got to experiance this bliss. I'm not going to drag on with this one like I do most of my reviews. It'll be as quick as it did to make me fall in love with this game. So graphics, I've never seen anything more beautiful. Controls are tight, resposive, and swift. Map design is ingenious, with corridors and platforms, different goals for ships, and loot a-plenty. Pay to win aspect is pretty much not there. It's more of "You can earn this item but it's also avalable for purchase", making handing over money an option rather then a task. The bouncy Shoot-N'-Slash combat is mindblowing, sounds are the best I've heard ever, and over all Warframe is something you should download right now. I'm not one for the whole rating system, but I have to give this a 10\10. It is amazing, and whoever is curious to download it, please get a better computer or a PS4 so you can experiance the tubular graphics while playing an off the hizzy game.

game-hours: 686.6
review: I've been playing this game for a year now, and with about 430- hours of gameplay, i must say... this is something else. Gameplay: Game being in open beta, gameplay is bound to change in the time after I write this review, for now it has a good selection of game modes (most of them Pve, becuase of lore there is not much point on PvP, although there is some) most of the game boiling down to you crushing, slashing, piercing, burning and blowing up all the enemies that are in front of you. Speaking of which, there are 3 mayor groups of enemies, this may seem a little short but its really not much of a problem, as each branches in several types of enemies that give variety to the game. Economically: First of, I never trust free-to-play games, you play for a while and *BAAM* "Give us money!!!", warframe changed that for me, with accessible prices, discounts (25%,50% and 75%) and the chance to get the paid currency (platinum, plat for short) by selling to other players what you get throught sheer effort and don't need/want. There are, however, a really few limitations to those who can't get platinum, such as a limited space of warframes(suits of armor) and weapons(primary, secondary and melee, then again this slots are the cheapest platinum-paid items in-game, so spending your free inicial 50 plats wisely, you can fix this problem as you play the game. All the other things (leaving aside most aesthetics) in-game can be obtained by playing the game, pretty much every gameplay (permanent weapon and warframe boosters and the like) that can be obtained by paying, can be obtained by playing. Verdict: 10/10 This game is at least a must-try, it's everything a free-to-play should be, you can feel that the people behind it want you to play it to share the love for the game and, in my opinion, they charge as much as to keep themselves floating and the game developing, just as they should.

game-hours: 22.5
review: Warframe is one of the better free-to-play games because it doesn't have a pay to win setup. Almost everything in the game can be gotten simply by playing the game except: cosmetic items, temporary boosters, and extra slots to hold more weapons, and warframes in your inventory. It does requires alot of commitment to get to the higher levelled parts of the game, and can be off-putting to some people. Starting off can be difficult and is best played with a group of friends to help with fulling a party to make missions easier. Joining a clan is recommended in this game because there is alot of content that needs to be researched in a clan dojo before you can make it. The further you get into warframe the better it gets because you get to take part in special events, fight new enemy types and bosses, tryout new gametypes, find rare mods and weapons, and even prime gear.

game-hours: 436.0
review: Grindy, confusing and boring. very pretty, kinda fast, but that's all it's got. combat is either stupidly easy, or ly hard. UI is confusing, Starting tutorials are broken (there is always someone asking about a broken something or other in the lobby chat), weapon/armour upgrades make next to no sense. on top of all that the game doesnt even explain itself untill you're already 2 hours in, and even then you actually have to go looking for it deep in the forgotten menus of moria. I played a couple of multiplayer missions back in the day with a group and it was ridiculous, 3 newbies and a single guy who just blizted everything. played another game after the recent patch, same deal. that one guy who looks like he's spent thousands of dollars of real money on fancy armour customisations comes along and expects you all to be as good as he is right out of the box, then yells at you when he dies because you didnt save him. I cannot in good faith recommend warframe as a completed product given the massive amounts of bugs and constant overhauls of the core game mechanics. download at your peril. Editing this review: going to leave the initial review up there, for integrity's sake. the saving graces this game has are few, but substantial. the previous review I wrote while i was rather miffed, so it shouldnt be paid too much attention. The community is lovely, and usually that massively overpowered guy in the pimped out armour will help you find where you need to be, or give you some good tips as far as how to fight, or move. playing with friends is great, it feels like a whole different game when you are fighting alongside a couple friends and communicating well. as for what I said about the combat, yes at times it can be rediculously hard, but I think that's mostly due to the randomization of the levels and placement of enemies that is done by the game. I enjoy a challenge, so when the game spawns 4 times as many enemies as usual it's a chance to show myself how much of a badass I am, or go down in a blaze of glory. the tutorial I've heard should be fixed now, which is good for new players. I've also heard there's going to be another large change to the gameplay coming, and it's reminded me that a game that evolves with it's players is a very interesting thing. still, this game does have a steep learning curve and a lot of things that feel like grind, which I still disagree with. but gad dang is it purty. this has to be one of the best looking games I've ever seen, many many cinematic moments. so there you go. download at your peril, and if you do? welcome to the fray Tenno.

review: If you don't like grinding, I suggest you discontinue this read. "Expensive game. Made changes to compensate against speed runners which ruined the potiental in this game. Enjoyed choosing between being stealthy, or switching to combat. Now near impossible to do multiplayer stealth." - This was my old review. I now do recommend this game, however it still is a grind fest. I am happy that they fixed the spawn rates, stealth system, and included a few new game modes to help grinding. Positives +Many Game Modes: Survival, Defense, Capture, Spy, etc, all a bit different. +Lots of different equipments and warframes to chooe from to help ease the grinding. +Multiplayer runs, dojo/clan systems. +Clans can build their own base. +Interesting PvP system for dueling, clan wars, and territory ownership. +Everything in the shop can be built, best items aren't avaliable for purchase on cash. +Trading system that includes trading in-game currency and cash-currency +Material listed planet by planet to help find the materials you need. +Neat Damage 2.0 and Melee 2.0 system to put a lot of details into equipment and battle. Negatives -Lots of items require 12-24 hours to build. Warframes being 72 hours (After the 12 hour parts are built) -Only option to speed build items is real money. -Cash store is really really expensive. (Ex: 20 Plat for a colours to customize your own warframe) -Customization to personalize your warframe all cost money, very few choices can be earned by in-game currency. -Some of the warframes are a little overpowered, and some are very underpowered. -Limited slots of owning weapons and warframe. (Cost money to get more slots) I find once you find your kind of warframe, and weapons. The grind isn't so bad.

review: This game absolutely amazing and extremely addicting! The graphics are awesome; the gameplay is fluid, and I, personally, experience very little lag, even though my computer is not that great and lags on most games I play or try to play. The character customization is also very good, even if you don't have any money since some extra colors are available to you for free. And, if you do have the money, the possibilites are nearly endless from changing what type of Warframe you use to what body type it has to the decorative armor pieces that it wears, and the various color palletes give a vast aray of possible color combinations. The only thing I'd even think to complain about is how the maps tend to repeat, but, at the same time, I like how the maps are generated randomly from a specific set of rooms each time a mission is started, preventing the entire map for a mission being the same multiple times in a row. There are a couple glitches I have come across, though, but glitches are to be expected in pretty much any game, and the ones I've seen are nothing that really ruin the game's fun and excitement. There's also that fact that there is no PvP, except in Clan Dojos, but that is so easy to overlook with how exciting everything else is. Overall, this could perhaps be one of the best games, if not the best game, I have ever played. It is definitely worth the download, and you really have nothing to lose if you happen to not like it.

game-hours: 789.8
review: Warframe is one of those games that definitely isn't for everyone. Although I found the art style unique and interesting, the organic/metal look of the titular warframes that represent your player can be off-putting for some. The graphics overall are top notch, however. The gameplay is almost entirely centered around grinding in the quest for more expansive warframe and weapon choices, and that may be the dealbreaker for many. There IS PVP in the game, but I haven't played enough to form an opinion of its quality, as the game is almost entirely PVE focused. But if you can get past the grind, Warframe fits the niche of mindless gaming, similar to perhaps mobile games, or long but slow games, like Civilization. The most accurate description of why I enjoy the game so much is "It's a co-op game you can play alone". You can drop in to any mission on the galaxy map and join a group of people already in there (up to 4 players) with no fuss. There is very little established "ettiquette" for the game; no need to say gg at mission end, no fancy lingo (until you get to "end game"), and since it's PVE and people can generally survive on their own (enemies do not scale ridiculously up in health when a new player joins, so there is little reason to reject someone). All that is really expected of you is to revive downed players and not be dead or afk 24/7. You can go entire missions without anyone saying a word to each other. So maybe you're not asocial like me and need a social aspect. The game offers a clan system that you can use to group up with similarly minded individuals; and sometimes co-ordination is required for the end game content. The ability to drop in and out with little to no strings attached and play a few sessions ranging anywhere from 15-60 minutes each (there is a endless mission type where you can play against increasingly difficult opponents for as long as you like) is very relaxing for me. Combine that with a very addicting progression system that consists of creating new weapons and warframes with no real established meta means you can play whatever you want. The downsides: unless you spend money or become a master of the trade market, you will be very limited in your warframe and weapon choices, as the number of inventory slots is very limited. Also, sometimes I find myself wondering why I am playing a game that is essentially an endless pve grinding treadmill; I find the common response in the community is to simply stop playing until the itch comes back, and when you do start playing again there will be all new equipment waiting for you! TLDR: No strings attached very low pressure game with minimal time dedication (maybe a 15 minute mission time average) with a unique art style and great graphics.

review: Really addictive game if your in too balanced grinding games. Probably the best free to play game out on the market, with no doubt!

game-hours: 215.8
review: Even though the game is still technically in the beta stages, this is one of the more tightly managed and well done games I've played in a long time. As of the time of this review the game is on beta update 13.x on the way to 14, to whit we will see player ships (housing) added to the game. Adding those basic RP elements is what will keep them alive and with profit. From things like new helmets to color sets for your armor and weapons it has the customization most online players long for. Overall this isn't your big brother's online shooter. There actually is a story, though incomplete at the moment, with missions to complete throughout the solar system. You can expect to see a slightly higher caliber of player as you advance into the higher stages. This is because, while you can buy most frames or weapons for cash, you still have to level them up and advance through the planets in a logical order. Each planet offers higher levels of enemies and if you die or forfeit out, then you won't receive the bonuses or full amounts of XP and credits. This means that you don't have a choice but to learn to play the frame you're on with the weapons you have, or get new ones and rerun some low-level stuff to figure it out. One nice element is that ability to play solo, no matter where you are or what mission. You can choose to play solo or in private groups, but you may find that sometimes you need that extra body to absorb bullets . . . or shoot a few extra. Sure, you can get carried, but that's true in just about every online game. You'll always find people that get in the way or on your nerves, but overall the current community is amazing and usually willing to help. This game is a MUST HAVE for anyone who remotely enjoys shooters, who loves to customize their characters, and who likes the ability to pick up people if they want.

game-hours: 587.8
review: So, WarFrame is a game where you play as dudes (or dudettes) called "Tenno", who are an ancient race of guardian-like people blessed with the knowledge and skill to operate a "WarFrame". WarFrames are the suits they wear which grant them crazy abilities which differ from Frame to Frame. You're awakened from cryostasis by a mysterious voice called "The Lotus" who asks your help in maintaining the balance of power in the Solar System while simultaneously helping to recover other lost Tenno comrades. The Solar System is currently dominated by two factions: The Corpus are Star-Trek style space cadets who tromp around in old-timey space-suits and laser rifles who are frequently assisted by support machines like walking energy-minigun robots and floating drones that supply defensive buffs. They worship the almighty credit, and you are worth more to them dead than alive. Most of the time... The Grineer are a "race" of endless genetic clones wearing armor that will remind you heavily of StarCraft's "Marines" (hey, they're even CALLED marines!). They are apparently driven by bloodlust and hatred for everything that isn't them (they will happily buy weapons from the Corpus and then use those weapons to shoot Corpus in the back, and the Corpus will happily sell to them knowing this in advance because: again. Almighty Credit). A third "faction" called "The Infested" exist. They're not really so much a faction as they are an alien locust-like plague sweeping through the System like rats, and you will occasionally have to undertake missions to help wipe them out (often at the behest of Grineer and Corpus soldiers who will then temporarily become your allies in this endeavor as they hire you to help clean out their settlements and bases). The game offers a lot of interesting game-modes, mostly aimed at fighting against the Corpus or Grineer in things such as capturing specific targets, hacking terminals (for a variety of reasons), defending artifacts and sleeping Tenno from repeated onslaughts and of course, simple extermination missions where you wipe out everything on the map that isn't you or your allies. Gameplay is a mix of FPS (mostly in 3rd person unless you zoom, which you will), and TPS (Third Person Slasher). All Tenno are capable of bringing 3 different weapons on every mission, classified as Primaries, Secondaries, and Melee weapons. Primaries are the standard two-handed rifles and other ranged weapons. Secondaries are small one-handed pistols that are sometimes dual-wielded, but allow for important mission-items like datamasses to be carried while they are equipped. Melees are, of course, melee weapons. And regardless of 2 or 1-handed, you can carry a datamass while they are equipped (although you will drop the datamass in the process of swapping between secondaries and melees, but you can just pick it back up after the swap is complete). As stated before, gunplay brings a typical FPS feel to the game and this may turn you off if you're not into FPS's in the first place. But please do not stop playing the game there, as there's a wonderful melee system you can use that's just oh-so-satisfying once you've picked up the basics. Melee is wonderful in WarFrame, although it may take you a while to pick up. When you get to that point where you're advancing on an enemy gunner with your guard held up, taking no damage whatsoever as bullets are deflected off your weapon, and then parrying them as they try to ram you with their elbow so you can score an OHKO finisher attack, you'll fall in love with WarFrame like I did. The only thing I don't really absolutely love about WarFrame is that it's economy is very hostile to new players. Be prepared to grind and grind out your  to get any equipment that's actually worth a damn when you first start. You either need to pay cash to give yourself a decent start or have a powerful friend help you out, because the starting weapons are just completely awful. And WarFrame abilities unranked will not impress you or seem helpful at all. You will need to put some levels into them before you start to notice how great they really are. Buying platinum is not only encouraged, but seems to be bullied on you at many opportunities. Only a small handful of all the weapons on the market can be bought ready-made. The rest must be bought as "blueprints", and then constructed out of materials which will require you to make quite a bit of progress in the game before you even have access to them. To top this off, once you actually have the materials required to construct the weapons you want, they will take anywhere between 12 hours to a whole day (sometimes more than that) to actually construct. Time that you can skip if you're willing to spend a little cash... In short, the game is fantastic, but playing completely free requires a patience, tolerance and skill only found in ACTUAL ninjas (aka, not a sane person). Or, y'know, you can gang up with some random public shmucks who will steal all the action from you at best, and be complete f***ups and fail the mission for you at worst. Highly suggested to play with friends for maximum enjoyment.

game-hours: 67.6
review: This game has dynamic movement controls allowing for fast paced game play or fast silent gameplay. The characters are adaptable to different play styles of first person shooter with a side arm, or swordplay. The third person view keeps you locked into the sci-fi setting by allowing you to see your warframe kick . It has the option to play solo, exclusively with friends, or online with a public lobby for each mission. Drop-in games are usually successful and team work is commonplace. Overall this game is a refreshing change to your first person shooter sci-fi action games. The storyline is interesting, and although I wont go into to detail, there could be more interaction. This is not an RPG, this is a mission oriented team play third person shooter. Weapons are able to be modded for better efficiency, though it would be nice to see those mods change the physical appearance. A downside I have found is the difficulty to gain special currency for new warframes, and new gear. Fantastic game, addictive as well - My husband now plays the game with me after only watching me play.

game-hours: 597.6
review: This game is a lot of fun. You get to go around to different planets as a robot(cyborg?) ninja and ninja many enemies to death. It is free to play, so no risk for you to give it a try. They did something very peculiar with the cash shop however. The punishment for earning new robot suits in the game versus buying them with real-world money is death. Bear with me as I explain. There are two methods to get new robot suits(the standard issue ones anyways). 1) Someone pays real-world cash for them. You or someone you traded your items too for platnium(the cash shop currency) laid down some money so you can get that shiney new warframe(robot suit). 2) You farmed the pieces in the game itself and then crafted the warframe. So you invested your time and the game makers did not get paid. At this point, everything is still on the up and up. However, what I didn't mention is this: If you employ method 2, you will most likely recieve a stalker's mark and the game will send a super-powerful NPC to invade your game and kill you, which removes the mark. In summary... If you played the game to get new suits instead of just buying them with real money, expect to be punished by being ganked by the game's cash shop enforcer. P.S. I still recommend playing this.

game-hours: 173.6
review: Warframe is unique. It is unique because all of the weapons and warframes are craftable and easy to obtain. Most Free-To-Play games these days are pretty much Pay To Win and people who pay have an advantage over the people who don't pay. The game offers hours of fun and the satisfaction of building a new warframe is unbeatable. The enemy AI is alright and does have 1-2 bugs or glitches every so often. The wide range of guns and warframes offer more fun and playstyles to the game, be it charging head first into battle, taking a stealthy approach or using the OP Paris Prime or Synapse to decimate your foes. Each warframe offers unique abilities such as absorbing damage and being nearly invincible while using the Rhino, or using Nova to completely kill everything in your path with her Antimatter abilities. Overall, the game is very fun and players are always willing to help you out, but with the ability of being a bit repetitive and sometimes boring with an OP setup. I give this game 8/10. This game deserves a reccomendation.

game-hours: 765.4
review: Personally I like this game a lot, however my pinion is no reasonable argument for you, the reader. Therefore I'll just objectively list as much positive and negative features of this game as currently available: + The game is Free to Play and virtually everything in-game can be acquired for free, save for a few old items such as rewards for special events or for early backers + The game features a lot of different warframes (characters) and weapons to play with that you can fully customize through "mods" + The game heavily focuses on Coop, missions will definitely go a lot smoother if you work in teams with predetermined tactics and also some of the warframes have great synergy with eachother to make eachother more useful ingame + It is currently still in Beta, so you can still expect a lot more content + There is no pay to win in this game - yes, you can pay to instantly get a weapon or frame, but you can't make it stronger than a free user so it purely serves to save you grinding time - other than that payment is purely useful for cosmetic items + The game boasts fairly good graphics and great physics that also allow a lot of detailed wall running and melee combo's + The game boasts competitive leaderboards in between clans and also has conflicts where clan can fight over resources + Every clan has a dojo where you can spar, trade and buy new equipment with ingame credits + Free users can fairly easily obtain items that they can sell to other players for the paid credits (platinum) + In some missions the game rewards exploration by hiding special loot containers that may drop rare mods, these mods do not tend to be worth too much amongst players, however - Some weapons and warframes clearly make the game too easy to play and are perhaps intended to attract a more casual audience while ensuring their success in missions - The random chance on rewards in this game can be quite annoying, you can do a mission for dozens of times for an item with a 10% drop chance and still never get it - Enemies and bosses tend to be quite easy, there are a few modes/missions where the enemies get progressively stronger to the point where they could no longer be killed (if you come that far) but overall there are no major challenges - Once you obtain as good as every item in the game there isn't much of an incentive to keep playing, at the moment - The lack of a public market or auction system makes trading very unreliable - The fact that this is one of those games that is in Beta for years while already having payment options is always a little... suspicious, but hey - the game itself is still free - People without a lot of free time will probably have a really hard time grinding for resources, but you could see this as an incentive to keep playing for things you'd like to obtain
game-hours: 841.7

game-hours: 93.8
review: There's really nothing much you can lose by trying this game out. It's F2P with a cash shop and if you don't like it, your not out any money. It's definetly fun to play with friends and offers a good challenge as you progress in the game. There are a ton of levels and you can really choose how you want to play the game. One downside of the game is that it is all instances, which can get old. If your looking for a fun game to spend a few hours on when your bored of other games, this game will keep you occupied and provides enough to do that will keep you coming back. Another downside to the game is the cash shop. A lot of the cooler stuff you need to spend real money. Also, the amount of warframes that are free to try are very limited. If you want some of the more unique warframes, you'll have to dish out the dough. With that said, I'd say the game is worth a try. 7.8/10 in my book!
