game-hours: 984.7
review: Gravedigger Fagus said it best: "It's a game about space ninjas destroying space nazis and futuristic EA representatives. I don't think I need to say any more here." You can't leave out the mutant zombie versions of said nazis and EA reps. It's like this, you and your crew infiltrate ships and bases on various planets and   up (and that's just with the weapons)! When everything is done, your team rolls out like nothing happened. "Space nazis, what space nazis?" Exactly. Seriously though, the game is extremely fun. You get your choice of Primary, secondary and melee weapons, per loadout, from an assortment of weapons from each faction (with an option to go melee only). There are several Warframes to choose from, each with unique abilities. You can customize the colors for pretty much EVERYTHING! You aquire Mods to make your weapons and Warframes more powerful. You can have up to 3 different mod loadouts and color schemes for everything. Practically every weapon and warframe can be attained through crafting. The game is updated fairly frequently, and most importantly, it's FREE! So if you're like me and enjoy shooters, co-op, hack and slash, love ninjas and are flat broke, this is the game for you!

game-hours: 73.4
review: This game... whew, where do I begin? I shall start with the technical elements. The graphics (on my 1920 X 1080 HD screen) are smooth and flawless. I have yet to see a graphical error, and I see these in almost every game. This game is one of the few TRULY free-to-play games on the market. All it takes is patience, friends, a plan, and an understanding of the concept of bugeting resources. It has one of the kindest playerbases I have ever had the pleasure of encountering, people who will let you jump right in to their Tower IV Defense and only give you a little crap for being a level 6 Loki Prime. This game is an unforgettable experience, with a storyline that I can only call "epic", genius original ideas for most aspects of the game, and parkour system that flows so smoothly that I still cannot believe functions as well as it does. It's a game for people who don't want to spend a dime, as well as one who loves to pump money ito videogames. The grinding can be frustrating and tedious, and some missions seem unnessecarily difficult, but with a group of friends and a little bit of time, these things cease to exist. In this game, you strive to build your own weapons and Warframes, and though it takes longer, I have to say, it's damn satisfying. 10/10. Get in here, Tenno. We need you.
game-hours: 1024.3
review: This game is just amazing... One of my favorites. You should try it. --- READ BELOW --- It is a bit repetitive but its really fun if you give some time in it. Digital Extremes always create new weapons and warframes(suits) every once in a while. They keep things updated and fix bugs that sneak in every update. Your goal is to be the strongest and gain the most powerful weapons. There is no campaign mode, but seperate missions. You gotta do all of the missions to unlock others and you gain credits and mods along with materials to craft new, stronger weapons in the foundry. I never really get tired of this game because DE always finds something new to bring out. Recently they have created a new frame called Oberon and 3 additional weapons. Don't listen to the metascore! Its all opinions. EDIT >>> This game is alright... It was fun for a while, and it worth a try. It is pretty repititive but you should put some time in it to see all of the game. It is pretty fun to kill enemies at first, but after a while, when you have killed many, many, many enemies, it numbs the feeling. DE is very well known for their updates and love for their fans. Every week to a month, expect something new the appear. Bugs are constantly being fixed, which is a good thing. Veterans of the game have been brainwashed to do the same thing they always have been doing for the past months, always trying to find something to do and supporting DE forever and looking forward to updates. TL;DR Warframe is fun at the start, many things to do, but after playing for a long, long time, it has gotten boring. I do not play this anymore, and if i do, its only for a little bit. The game is very repititive, and some may find pleasure in playing this game.

game-hours: 611.0
review: Warframe is space ninjas. Trust me, it's just what you wanted. Intense combat, swordplay and hack&slash, powers that crush the foe and make you seem op. This game has it all, and trust me, it's much more challenging than you think. A Tenno's path follows one of discipline and of belief. You can go about the game with choices and options and room for improvement. But to get there one must be a master of all he uses. So to advance through the game, which takes place in our own solar system, there is an urgency to max out every weapon, warframe, sentinel, and archwing: Mastery rank. Some of the more excellent arms are locked in higher mastery ranks and must be attained through the virtues of patience and determination. They're all worth it, for they have some pretty excellent stats. But patience also lets you play for free. It's just enough time to master one set of weapons, buy another set and make the parts while still gathering materials on nice planets. The game is better played with others, for the rewards go up the longer in some missions you stay. Those powers stack when you have more than one person each with 4 unique powers. It can get pretty tactical in a hairy situation. The MMO aspect this game has is collecting. It's all about going out and getting as many resources as you can by unlocking the solar system by planet and collecting rarer things like keys to the void (even more rewards) and nav coordinates and some of the newer bossfights too. Time is required even for these, but one who would spend for a game like this can get what he needs at the market. Nothing is unobtainable by playing free though. If you find rare blueprints or mods, you can sell them if you have a clan. Clans provide a dojo where you can visit your trading post and invite others for trades. You can go to other clans by joining people in them too. Don't be hasty in selling credits, as they're used in many places of the game. I expect more stability in the versions to come.

review: OMG SO MUCH YES In just a few weeks i have put over 100 hours into this and it is still so fun, Digital extremes did well in creating a fun, free-to-play game the DOES NOT force you to buy items with real world money to get the best gear in game(thats not to say you cant, but its just as easy to get it yourself through playing the game) Here are a few pro's >It's free >It's extremely well made and of a high quality, it rivals most AAA titles >The combat system is so good >The loadout combinations are amazing, there are so many cool weapons and items you can use, including Guns, Bow, Whips, Swords, boomerangs, crossbows, explosives, and not to mention your frames(The characters you can play as) powers that make your playstyle super unique, such as i, have a character(the valkyr) who is customized so i run into battle, take a bunch of damage to get energy, become invinible then heal from my melee attacks, then rinse wash repeat, and i also have a super tank character who just doesnt die, and if he does he has a longer bleedout time for survivabilty. Everyone is so helpful > There is a player run trading community where you can trade items for money for the CASH SHOP which is amazing in my opinion, so not only is the game free but you can earn the only currency you have to pay for by trading with other players. Give it a shot, even if its only for 10 minutes, who knows you might fall in love... I did!

review: This game is awesome! After selling my Xbox 360 and jumping onto the PC train, I was looking for a game that was similar to a game just recently released, Destiny. Like Destiny, Warframe has a system of co-op missions with a jump in/out style. I really like the storyline of this game so far, but I'm still a pretty low level. It's got just enough challenge to keep me going. The only gripe I have with this game is the lack of gamepad support for the menus. The game feels right playing from my couch with my Xbox 360 pad, but when I need to grab my mouse just for navigating through menus, it kind of breaks up the gameplay for me. I know the game is on PS4 and Xbox One, and that it already works with the gamepad on those systems, so what is stopping it from working on PC? Anyway, the game is great. The mechanics work, there are plenty of guns and weapons to suit anyone's play style. Congratulations Digital Extremes, you made a very solid F2P game. I look forward to playing it more countless hours to come.

review: COOL AND FUN GAME !!!
game-hours: 1038.7
review: First things first. This game is extremely graphics intensive. Not only should one have a good graphics card, but one's computer should have a multi-core fast processor along with a fair amount of ram. Warframe is in my opinion a solid 7/10. Here are the reasons why.(Notice not all may be listed). Pros 1. The game has a high amount of customization with its system of how one can customize their character with mods and weapons that can be chosen from. One can find these mods by doing and completing missions/levels located on each planet. Weapons can have mods placed on them, same with the character, at the cost of points obtained by leveling them up. The maximum level/rank that can be obtained at the writing of this review is 30. Points can be increased by mods and other items. When combined the points can be more than doubled. Players can have up to around 9 mod slots on each weapon/character. 2. Another positive towards Warframe is each character useable has a set of abilities unique to them. Other characters are unable to use abilities that are used by another. This adds a sense of completion towards the game. 3. There is an online mode in which one can play to join others and assist those who need help completing a mission. This also helps to introduce others to more experience players and possibly new friends. There is also a mode called "Solo" in which a player can play by themselves. Cons 1. One of the massive cons to this game is the multi-player capabilities. Problems can occur when attempting to join a friend to play missions. When attempting to join an error can show up showing the message "Failed to join session". Despite players internet connection/s this can occur. A way to solve this can be done by players going into online mode and joining a game. Then inviting the other/s to their game session. It is important to know that if the player is the host this will not work. This may need to be done every time Warframe is started in order to play together. Having to continually do this will eventually cause frustration and may ruin the overall feel and experience of the game. 2. Variety of missions can become a problem with the current amount available to players. (Some may be unlisted) a. Exterminate b. Hijack c. Deception d. Spy e. Interception f. Defense g. Nightmare Mode h. Survival i. Assassination Missions j. Mobile Defense k. Sabotage l. Invasion While this may seem as though one has many choices to choose from, these missions are the only types found on all of the planets. This makes the game repetitive as one will find themselves repeating the same objective in a similar pattern. 3. A major problem towards the game is the cost of platinum. Warframes/Characters can cost upwards of 300+ platinum. One can obtain 75 platinum at the cost of $5 USD. Most items cost about $10 USD or up, to get. However, their is an alternative to buy items than with real world money. One can purchase blueprints with energy credits. Energy credits are obtained though doing missions and/or selling blueprints. These blueprints can be used in what is called the Foundry. The Foundry allows a player to craft items at the cost of resources. Resources are collect though doing missions and/or though the use of "Extractors". The usual amount of time to craft a weapon is around 12 hours from the start of crafting. Warframes/Characters will take 3 days. It is important to note that items can be rushed in the Foundry though the use of Platinum. It is also important to keep in mind that one can obtain discounts though login rewards. The maximum amount for a discount is around 75% off. Items not normally found on missions can be obtained though rewards from Alert missions.

game-hours: 827.8
review: Warframe allows you to select from one of many Warframes to fight as, with mods and stances to enhance your weapons, warframe, and sentinels. Plus there is a lot of customization available; however, if you want to customize, you will have to use platinum for most things like colors and armor, which means you have to fork over real money. It is "free to play" if you are happy with just a couple of Warframes, but you'll be too addicted and have to puchase additional Warframe slots and weapon slots and this means real money. I still highly recommend this game. It has a bit of a learning curve, but once you get onto it, it becomes easy to understand. Plus the community is a great aspect, there are in-game chat rooms for Region (general chat in your geographic region), Recruiting (where you can join other games or recruit for your clan), and Trading (which allows users to buy, sell, or trade items). And the developers host numerous interactive events like PrimeTime which puts two of the developers in a mission with real life players and other watch the feed on Twitch, and the DevStream which features several of the developers talking about the game and upcoming changes. Both allow users to submit questions and win free platinum.

game-hours: 153.3
review: Just Play it,
game-hours: 179.3
review: You can be Magical Space Ninjas 10/10
game-hours: 234.0
review: Alright, so where to begin? Warframe is a sci-fi game that takes place far into the future. Humanity has degraded into the cloned clones called "Grineer" and the corporate big shots known as "Corpus". As well, a nanobot infestation is infecting large parts of the galaxies and turning members of both these factions into the "infested". You play as the Tenno, ancient warriors, frozen in a deep sleep, waiting for the day to wake up and clean house on the galaxy... Which is now. So, this game has in my opinion, a solid premise, as far as story line goes, and something I would say is considerably unique, that is, considering what else is available. The gameplay? Very fluid, lots of "parkour" like moves to do, it's a great third person shooter, and melee combat game. The shooting is fluid, reloading and switching weapons, in fact, for having such movie-esque moves, this game functions quite simply. Near well anyone could pick it up and learn very fast how to execute the wicked looking jumps, slides, and backflips the game has to offer. The stages you go through were well designed in terms of allowing for free movement, having rooms tall enough, or wide enough to accomodate the parkour style Warframe delivers. In addition to having large rooms, these rooms often have walls you can run across, cover you can climb up, gaps you can leap over, and so on. The guns? Well, a lot of them are unique, and they act like you'd expect any gun to in a third person shooter, and again, they did a great job keeping fluid motions for having so much variety. Variety. Well, I hope you like guns... And swords... And pistols... And scythes, knives, shotguns, rocket launchers, snipers, Glaives, and so on... One thing Warframe certainly does not fall short of, is weapons. There is a massive variety of equipment to choose from, which helps fit whatever gamestyle you like. In addition to the large cache of weapons, there's a bountiful amount of Warframes to choose from! The Warframe, is the suit you wear, eac one having unique abilities and stats. Short term? I'd recommend this game to anyone in a heartbeat, my only concern for Warframe, is that they seem to have stuck to a very "grind" focused path, where you are continually leveling up to get better, but the enemies often times don't scale, and the game gets quite easy. This is more than fixable, however, and I have confidence the end game will get better. Did I mentiond Warframe is free? I would have easily paid to have this game, and I didn't have to. I recommend this to any parkour/shooter fans out there. Thanks for the reading.

review: Well let us start off by saying I am bad at writing reviews. As I was beggining to write this I tried to come up with some cons about Warframe, but I could not do so. I gave it about thirty minutes and not even a hint of a con appeared in my mind. I would like to share my opinion on Waframe before I list any pros. My opinion being that Warframe is a truly amazing game. I did not think I would ever end up where I was in this game. At first I despised the idea of it, but I gave it a try. Now everyday is a day of wanting to play Warframe, playing Warframe, and thinking about playing Warframe tomorrow. People will always text me and ask me to hangout but I always say "I am working" or "I am busy." However, I made new friends, perhaps even a family. It feels as if I have another life, a place to escape to. If that does not tell you that I love this game my current 851.3 hours will ( which will certainly be increasing ;D ). Well since Warframe is nothing but pros I will just settle by spitting out the larger, more positive attributes. Some pros being: +great community +amazing graphics +phenomenal customization in both modding and physical appearances +certainly not a pay to win +perfect mechanics +always new stuff and fixes +joyful gameplay There is far too many pros to list, in my opinion. game-hours: 345.4
review: This story requires a bit of setup. Last year, a friend of mine whom I'd known from gaming for a long time contacted me and told me about this great new game that was in beta that he was backing as a founder (called a "Grandmaster" in-game) called Warframe. A third person cooperative shooter with elements of Phantasy Star Online/Diablo loot runs, procedurally generated levels, and more content being added all the time. The game was difficult to start, as there are many keys for various secret parkour maneuvers. Running along walls! Sliding down ziplines! Soon, I was completely hooked; my friend and I were playing late into the night, trying to grind out just one more piece necessary to build a new component or weapon, or trying to beat our best time on the Survival missions -- where you fend off an ever growing wave of foes as life support ticks down. Over the year, there were many great victories, hair raising last second escapes, and new friends joining our little group. Many hours were spent joking around with each other on Skype, cracking jokes, blasting weird songs at each other, and coming up with our own stupid little catchphrases. Flash forward a year; Warframe now has space combat, new Warframes, new weapons, and new combat controls. The game still has its original style, but it's so much improved. Last week, our four player regular team developed some incredible strategies that let us get further than we ever had on wave defense missions. The only thing that made us stop was getting tired. On Tuesday, my friend who invited me to the game a year ago didn't show up that night. I found out on Wednesday that he had passed away suddenly from an undiagnosed health condition. The shock of it is still hitting us hard. The friendships that we had formed through the game, gone in an instant. It hardly feels real. I keep expecting him to log in and be there, ready to do another defense mission, and it's difficult to accept that we'll be going it alone now. We contacted Digital Extremes, the company that makes the game, and asked if there was anything we could do. They dedicated their 11/20/2014 episode of their webcast to the memory of our friend and read our memorials to him on the air. Their reactions were heartfelt and touching. They really do listen to and react to the community. I not only recommend the game for how much fun it is (I recommend you play it with a group of friends on voice chat -- up to four per session; your gameplay experience may vary alone, and form a clan or join one just because many items are clan-only), I recommend it for how responsive the game developers are to the community. They constantly improve it and add new content, items, and weapons. There is a storyline that is unfolding. The voice acting is delightful. You could easily play this game without spending a single dollar of real world currency on it (real world currency is used for cosmetics and increasing the number of Warframes and weapons you can own, or buying things that you can't wait for). Thanks, Digital Extremes. And rest in peace, Woxit.

game-hours: 118.7
review: | Update (24/4/14): It has been a fairly significant chunk of time since I wrote this review of Warframe, and some elements of the game have been expanded upon in ways that alleviate some of the issues I originally had. The premium currency, platinum, can now be traded between players. This provides an option for players who do not wish to put money into the game but want to participate in using the storefront. Users in the comments have pointed out that there are many powerful items which are not available in the store - if you want them, you'll need to grind. Multiple new game modes exist, including "Invasion", a mode which allows players to team up together with the Corpus or the Grineer to work against the opposing faction. This mode gives the player some agency in the kinds of rewards he receives for completing the mission. The latest update introduced Melee 2.0, which delivered improvements to the game's melee combat. The most interesting update comes in the form of Dark Sectors. Clans and alliances can own parts of the Solar System, and can fight for that contested ownership. Clans and Alliances can also set tax and resource requirements on anyone who accesses their conquered territories, leading to territorial battles for supremacy. In conclusion, a decent amount of content has been added to the game. While the core argument of my review holds true, Warframe is finally approaching the level of depth required to elevate itself above a mere grinding game. The new "EVE Online"-esque sector mechanics are particularly promising in that regard. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | Original Review (25/11/13) A great-looking, initially interesting game that feels like one compelling part of what should be a greater whole. Warframe is an interesting entry in the free to play space. It has the looks and the gameplay, but after a while it begins to feel lacking in the way of substance. Gameplay largely involves clearing your way through various missions types as you progress in rank, leveling up your weapons and your Warframe (the game's metaphor for various Classes, each having their own unique abilities, advantages, disadvantages and so on) as you shoot a myriad of alien Grineer, infested hordes, and Corpus robots. Missions range from rescue scenarios where a hostage must be located and escorted to safety, to mobile defense missions where waves of increasingly difficult enemies must be held off as you protect a moving objective. These can all be completed solo, but are made more interesting by grouping up with other players. Higher level missions are tricky by yourself, making teaming up the more attractive proposition. Weapons and Warframes can be augmented with various modifcations that apply the standard Action RPG fare - elemental damage bonuses, increased critical hit damage, faster reload speeds, you name it. This allows for some diversity in gameplay between players, where you may opt to build out your Warframe in a more supportive role, or stock up on mods which provide a more tanky character. So far the game has been well supported with semi-regular content updates and special events, usually in the form of new warframes and weapons, and a "community effort" in which everyone can participate. The only "issue" is that the game is a bit of a grind. In fact, it's a complete grinding game. The main reason for going on missions is in the hopes of accumulating various materials with which to craft the new warframes or weapons. You can use the games "premium" currency to expedite the process of manufacturing said items (which take hours, days of real time to craft) or simply buy them outright from a storefront. Why do you want these new weapons and warframes? To grind more efficiently for materials. This might strike you as a monotonous loop, and to an extent it is, but the joy of the gameplay itself goes a way to allievating the game from being a total bore. Inevitably though you may become tired of the treadmill. The game sometimes feels like it is skirting the boundaries of being gross about its "free to play" nature - you can certainly get almost everything in the game without spending if you're willing to commit to the grind, but it can sometimes feel like game systems are designed to encourage you to give up and bring out your wallet - namely the sheer amount of materials required to craft better equipment, and the time spent waiting for these items to actually be built. It's always questionable when a F2P game includes a long timer alongside a button to make it go away for just a few pounds. Ultimately, if you're just looking for a good looking, nice playing third person shooter with online components and a decent aesthetic, you can do far worse than Warframe. After spending some time with it, however, you might wind up wishing there was a little more to the experience beyond what is currently available.

game-hours: 2945.3
review: Before you read into this review, let me ask you one question. Do you think fun is the most important thing in any game? If you answered yes, stick around and keep reading. If you answered no, you probably wouldn't like Warframe. Warframe gets a lot of flak for being repetative, but I personally feel that the reviewers who complain about the gameplay being repetative are failing to see the bigger picture. Warframe is not about a deep, gripping narrartive or memorable characters, it's about action, fun, and pretty crazy weapon variety. And to top it all off, everything that impacts gameplay can be obtained for free. Warframe is a very specialized game, focused on action, flare, and fun. And boy oh boy does Warframe nail action and fun. With over a dozen unique Warframes(Powersuits used by the player, each with their own unique abilities and stats) to choose from you're sure to find one that you really enjoy playing as. And then there's the weapons. Oh boy, the weapons. This game has almost every kind of Sci-Fi weapon I can think of. We have small scale particle cannons, Beefy sniper rifles, plasma casters, living weapons that shoot everything from Electricity to streams of deadly viruses, an insanely powerful rocket launcher, a Grenade launcher with remote detonation, powerful bows, a gun that shoots spinning saw blades, and of course the obligatory pew-pew assualt rifles to ease new players into the experience. Oh, but that's just the Primaries. In every mission, you will have the option to carry a Primary, a Secondary, and a Melee but you can choose to carry only 1 or 2 if you please. The Secondaries include but are not limited to: Living weapons that shoot Corrosive darts and poison gas, a goo gun that shoots sticky globs of acid that eat right through armor, 2 deadly hand cannons, one of which shoots many metal balls in a shotgun spread while the other shoots a spread of radiation blasts, Miniature plasma casters, rapid fire dual pistols, a spread-rocket launcher that they somehow compressed into the size of a pistol, a pistol that shoots bolts that can pin enemies to walls, deadly and accurate burst fire pistols, pocket snipers, Revolvers, a Lever action beast, Throwing knives, Throwing stars, and a Standard semi-auto pistol to ease new players in. And then there's my favorite weapon class, the Melee. We've got Greatswords that can hit numerous enemies in a wide arc, more conservative longswords that swing fast and allow better mobility while attacking, Dual daggers which generate an incredibly fast flurry of slashes and stabs, whips for when you want the range of a greatsword but the mobility of a longsword, there's also the polearms, Heavy axes, Heavy hammers, ROCKET HAMMER, and even the Thrown melee weapons, useful for killing at a distance while conserving ammo and for stealth kills. More recently Digital Extremes added in 2 Katanas and a set of claws that pop out of your arms like Wolverine. Melee has become much more prominent lately now that DE has completely revamped it. No longer do you simply mash or hold E, now you can perform different combos that require different inputs. These combos are assigned to stance mods that you can apply to your weapon. Each melee weapon class I mentioned above has at least 1 stance mod, and each mod comes with it's own unique combos that are useful for different purposes and situations. My favorites are the Katanas with Decisive Judgement as the stance. I use it to make my tenno look and fight like Vergil from Devil May Cry 3. So yes, Warframe can seem repetative to some people, but not to me. I greatly enjoy the vast arsenal that is placed before me, and I truly believe that these tools of destruction make up for the lack of deep narrative. That said, I thoroughly recommend Warframe to anyone who likes Shooters or character action games, or anyone who likes having fun.

review: Very Fun game, but hopefully they release more in-game content. Everything I wanted to do required real money. I'm not a stranger to F2P MMOs with in game stores, but the actual in game content here is pretty limited. Pretty much pay to win. As far as game play goes, melee range is kinda hard to judge at first, and the controls aren't exactly friendly. you have 3 weapons, and "F" toggles them, however it only seems to toggle between 2 of them unless you hold it down to get the 3rd. When I finally had everything down, and was moving along, I joined my first co-op map, and the person I ran with sprinted to the end and bypassed all the good stuff between... then complained that I was going through, killing things and getting drops (i've read this is a common thing). This is supposedly still in open beta, but it has been for quite some time. I worry this is a game that will get strung along as is for a while and never be finished completely. I'd actually consider paying 60$ for this if I got access to the entire game. There appeares to be a LOT of potential with this game, but its more worried about making money off of miniscule transaction than making a good game. I recommend checking it out, but it's not going to change your world.

game-hours: 24.2
review: In Warframe, you play as a member of a dying race known as the Tenno, who are fighting and losing a war against the evil forces of the Grenier.You jump right into the action, woken up from cryogenic sleep, (like halo) and are forced to fight your way to your ship. Where you make holographic contact with a being known as the lotus. You get a choice of between 4 choices (i think) Excalibur,Volt, Mag, and Loki. Excalibur is a master of melee, so he's really good with swords. Volt, my personal favorite, uses electricity in a variety of ways, he can disable enemy shields, fry em' create a shield of his own, and absort energy. Mag is a master of gravity and magnets, he is able to sweep enemies of their feet and suspend them in the air and smash them back down, he can also do the opposite and make them collapse on themselves. shattering bones and what not. Loki, the illustionist, can mess with the minds of enemies and teleport behind them. (and other stuff I'm not sure about.) Honestly, its not bad, abit pay to win, but mostly fun to play for free, If you're creative you won't really need cash. The whole point of using the: "Ninjas play free" slogan is to let players know that is you are stealthy, you won't need to buy the awesome pack-a-punchesque weapons and upgrades, you can be just as effective with the weapons the give you. Apart from that, the game itself is beatiful, colorful, ingaging and open world. (I mean like really open) You get to travel through, not only the milkyway, but other galaxies that you wouldn't even have imagined. You can also, God willing you have the skill, battle other players in PvP. I mean seriously, you're a space ninja, how awesome is that! If a tenno had to fight a Jedi, I'd go with the Tenno. Gameplay: 8/10 Story: 5/10 PvP: on the fence Visuals: 10/10 Community: 9/10

review: Beautiful and fun, but a bit repetetive. The game itself if free to play, and all content is available without having to spend money, BUT; A large part of progression in the game is building new weapons and leveling them up, to access better weapons and harder content. If you don't spend money to increase your inventory space, you will have to toss out beloved weapons and Warframes to make room for new things that are constantly added to the game. This will severely limit your gameplay experience and versatility for different content. Currently in Beta for over a year running, the game is regularly updated with new content, and has weekly live-show updates from the developers. Come for the charming development team, fun parkour-y gun&swordplay, original and intriguing sci-fi universe. Stay for the never-ending hunt for rare drops.

game-hours: 3807.2
review: Warframe is one of the most unique games I've had the pleasure of playing. Digital Extremes has challenged what we traditionally view video games to be with a decidedly different approach. With a wide arsenal of weapons and frames to choose from, there are so many ways to deliver death and destruction to the countless enemies in your way. Someone decided it was a fun idea to create a sniper rifle that launches sawblades, how cool is that? Then they decided to have a gigantic warhammer with a jet engine strapped to it? Why? Because they can. You have flamethrowers, bows, and no small assortment of rifles and pistols -- along with some even more exotic weapons you simply can't use in any other game. If you feel like blowing off steam from a long day at work, you can fire up warframe and choose whatever instrument of death suits your fancy and go to town on endless creatures and destroy them in truly horrific and neat ways. The f2p model is one of the best I've seen in any game, and could really be seen more as pay4convenience, rather than pay2win. Every frame can be found by beating bosses, every weapon can be built in your foundry. Might take time, but it is free. Warframe has events on a regular basis with exclusive items, and they're constantly putting out new weapons on a weekly or bi-weekly basis. The developers truly seem to have 'fun' in mind when it comes to Warframe, even if things seem repetitive after a while -- I never get tired of slaughtering the same creatures in different ways. Pick up Warframe if you think over-the-top violence involving space ninjas, parkour, rocket launchers, clones, robots, and a space canadian talking to you through your hud is an awesome experience.
game-hours: 1551.4
review: This game grows on you, before you know it you have spent 500+ hours playing it.
game-hours: 207.6
review: Is good.
game-hours: 14.3
review: This is a great game, but the costs for weapons and cosmetics are too high and forces us players to grind or pay. This artificailly increases the playtime. Most of the weapons, tennos, weapon/tenno slots, and cosmetics cost platinum or a ludicrous amount of credits to buy. Purchasing with platinum reduces the grind tremendously but the only way to get platinum is to purchase it or using the in-game trading system. I hope you move the platinum/ micro-transaction solely to the cosmetics, or at the very least, lower the credit costs. I'm not saying this is a bad game, I am just saying that there is a large amount of micro-transactions in this and most other "free to play" games.

game-hours: 779.2
review: Warframe is a great grind game with an enjoyable grind style. You play as Tenno (space ninjas!) and run around doing repetitive missions. Though the missions do burn you out, the combat and manuevers just flow really well. Throughout these missions you pick up mods (which give boosts/unique abilities to your equipment) and resources (used for crafting new equipment) and credits (the "free" in-game currency). Though there is a cash shop (platinum) none of the weapons or warframes are locked behind it. In fact, the only items that are exclusive to the cash shop are cosmetics and grinding boosters (exp multipliers, resource multipliers, credit multipliers, etc). Overall Warframe is a great f2p game and will go for hundreds of hours of play.
game-hours: 31.4

review: Since I tend to ramble when I post I'll be making this short. 1.this game is pay to win. Pretty much everything is behind xp locks or paywalls. 2. A live system has been included. if you get your  kicked by mobs of enemies four times [easy to happen in the beginner levels] then you must wait a day or pay up. No 1-ups here unless you have dosh. 3.like pretty much all free mmo's the community lean between complete trash and decent. 4. for some reason the devs of this game decided to make leveling up a real pain in the . after a certain amount of levels have been reached you must take a test to progress further. This translates to you getting dumped into a small arena where you must kill a blob of enemies on a time limit. If you fail you have to wait a day before you can try again. It's not bad as free mmo goes but there are better games to spend your money on. I'll give it a reluctent thumbs up.

game-hours: 19.0
review: Remember the first trailer for Dark Sector that showed that the game was originally to take place in space and in the far future? Well Digital Extremes decided to take the concept of that early version of Dark Sector and make a completely new and free to play third person action title out of it. And so Warframe was created. You play as a member of the alien race known as the Tenno, a slight nod to the protagonist in Dark Sector, who has been summoned from the dark reaches of space to the galaxy to fight the evil Grineer who are out to take over the galaxy and also wipe out the Tenno at the same time. But you're far from helpless in your struggle, you have a special battlesuit called a Warframe, each one of them have unique abilities that can turn the tide of battle in your favor, a wide array of firearms and several types of melee weapons, all of which are powerful enough to cut an enemy apart with one single powerful swipe. And you will also be fighting alongside other Tennos in your mission to rid the galaxy of the Grineer as well as any other alien race that intend to wipe you out.

review: Iz Good, No?
game-hours: 337.7
review: Amazing game, new content added all the time. The new Melee system transform the game from a standard over the shoulder platform shooter to something different and unique on the market. The credit and Platinum system is definately good and allows that even if you don't decide to put money into the game, that you can aquire >95% of the inventory. Though my only concern would be the Price it is to buy platinum and the effective use out of it. 10 of platinium does not get you far, and for the new frames trying to unlock them via the free route can be time consuming at times. If you are prepared to put a little extra time in the game then everything is worth it. The community side is great and very much almost too friendly. The only things I would ask/improve it this was my own game would be more plat for you buck and the cross play the PS4 users (though both most likey not going to happen due to the natures of both cirumstances. TL:DR? Get the game, it's free and fun with mates. The game is beautiful and there far too much content in comparions to simlar free games on the market.

game-hours: 9.8
review: I really didn't expect to have as much fun with Warframe as I am now when I first saw it. The game's setting and style wasn't much my type of game, but after playing it for a few hours I can appreciate just how beautiful and fun it really is. Warframe is an extremely polished game, with plenty of customization, and many ways to play. It even has cool features such as a Solo mode that you can play offline! A lot of the game's customization lies behind either pay walls, or you can spend in game money to get blueprints and then grind for materials to be able to get the different characters and weapons. It also encourages you to join a clan for various benefits in new weapon types as well as more customization fun with the ability to design your dojo. I would definitely recommend this for people desiring a fun and quick Co-Op experience and who don't mind slow level progression.

game-hours: 263.8
review: Love the game! Over 200 hours played. Such fun, much grinding, wow!
game-hours: 635.2
review: I've played for a while now, and I must say for a f2p game its awesome. Yes there is a pay option and ingame store, however there is nothing game changing that you can buy in the store that you can't get by playing. Yes there's some xp/credit bosters and appearance items but anything that actually changes game play you can get through playing. In fact some of the best (Prime) stuff can only be gained through playing. Gameplay is reminicant of the jedi outcast/academy. Third person shooter/melee with acrobatic elements. Solo players may have issues and without friends the game is VERY VERY grindy. Multiplayer, the community for the most part is full of decent people but in missions an epidemic of "I'm gonna get mine" and kill count padding can make PUGs (pick up groups) very disheartening through mission failures and lack of revives. However if you get into a good group or clan you can bypass those issues. Balance, the frames are all specialized in some form or another, Rhino is a tank based frame high armor and the ability to coat himself in a temorary armor shell that negates all damage, Loki is a tactical based frame less at home in the midsts of combat more at home in the shadows, Nova is a nuker, etc etc. In general the frames are well balanced and no one frame is a god frame. Updates, DE is very active in putting out fixes and updates. They are committed to making sure the game works. Ultimately for a free game i'd say go for it if you're in to Third person shooters, the biggest thing for me is the lack of a pvp focus. yes there is pvp but the game isn't focused on pvp.

review: It's an MMOTPS and is mostly PVE coop with teams of up to 4 people. You pretty much play as a species of Super Space Ninja's called Tenno and go into different space stations and planets to f**k  up. Lot's of action, kind of like a shoot-em-up at points. You have abilities, weapons, and a lot of customization options. It's in Open Beta at the moment, so there are a couple kinks here and there. It's a graphically demanding game, though, so computers with low specs are going to have a little trouble. If you can run League or any popular MMOs you shouldn't have an issue. Truly a god among games.

game-hours: 246.8
review: So, you're a Space Ninja armed with a gun/bow/grenade launcher/weird alien tech weapon and a sword/hammer/fists/mace and wielding crazy powers to destroy/stun/confuse/decimate your enemies? Why have I never heard of this game before??? Seriously, this game is phenomenal, the graphics are amazing, the weapons are fun, the powers are cool, the Dev's are constantly fixing and improving the experience, I cannot find a fault with this FREE game! I don't have a lot of time to play games, but Warframe doesn't require that much dedication to enjoy it at all. The action is fast-paced, the plot is light, the requirements are minimal, the game is ever-evolving giving you new things to do, the tech options (in the form of Mod Cards) are immense. I HIGHLY recommend everyone to try it! What have you got to lose? It's FREE!!!

game-hours: 3.9
review: Fun until you realise that there are many potatos to choose from and the game wants your platinum.
game-hours: 128.7
review: Warframe is a free-to-play shooter with, basically, exo-skeleton soldiers that have different powers and abilities. At heart, the game is as shooter as any other game you'd play on the market, but, throw in the unique powers with each warframe, the customizablilty of the guns and gear with their 'mod' system, the diverse spectrum of weapons, unique movement system... and a free tag on it? You can't beat it, for what you're paying. There is a cash shop that you can use, which supports the game's funding, via platnium that you can buy in packages. In some cases, you can pay-to-win the game to death, buying everything in the store with real-life cash, if you wanted. However, that takes all the fun out of the game, considering half the fun of it is gathering the pieces and materials to create something new and impressive that you've worked for. And constant, free updates? You can't beat that. All in all, a really great game that I'd totally recommend you pick up, even if you're not a huge fan of shooters.

review: gameplay: throughly enjoyable with numerous weapons although it can be a grind story: stale graohics: very pleasing great level design
game-hours: 2413.0
review: The game itself is troubled with innate networking issues and other bugs (it certainly feels like a beta at these points even after years) but overall looks and feels more polished than many big titles out there. The mechanics, movement, control, fighting, menus, everything is fluid. It's main problem is that it's a real grinding game with a usually punishing RNG god watching over it. You can be lucky, sure but most of the time you have to repeat everything again and again and again to get something you want. This wouldn't be so if not for the AI that is like of lemmings, fights are repetitive after a while, especially when you fight against the same enemies on the same map. As a free to play game one of the biggest points of interest is the real-money economy. Thankfully Warframe allows everything useful to be purchased or earned within game without the use of it's real-money currency, Platinum and only slots and vanity stuff (like colors) remain as plat only items. Even those can be gained through events (like when you get a weapon as reward you get a slot with it or on Easter you can purchase an easter color palette for 1 ingame credit, no plat) and even provides coupons as daily rewards if you are lucky. So this part is something that other Free-to-play games could really learn from. So overall the game could use a bit more bug-fixing and creativity but otherwise it's a very good game, arguably the best constructed free-to-play game out there.

review: Where to start, this game is amazing. who dosen't love futuristic ninjas with a large asortment of weaponry and warframes. you (and your sqaud if you chose) are a thought to be a long extinct race called the Tenno. you (and your squad) are sent on challenging missions such as raid, capture, assassination and more. with unique maps and randomly generated scenarios, this game is hard to beat comparied to the other free to play games. it plays well and it is well polished. its flaws are the currency for ingame money called "Platinum", $5.00 = 75 Platinum in which a warframe cost 375 Platinum (depending on the warframe). another flaw is the building system, you go all over the solar system collecting various resurces and materials to build weapons, warframes, ect. but the warframes require a S**T ton of material and some of them you cannot get in one go. you may have the bluprints for the warframe ect. but you nedd to work for it. once you have all of the materials you can build the warfraem, weapon, ect. but it will take 12hrs for weapons, warframe parts 24hrs, warframes them selves will take 3days. but, this game's goods over shadow the bads with F-U-N. so if you like space ninjas, badass weapons, cool looking warframes with unique powers this is for you. game-hours: 8.6
review: AWesome!
game-hours: 170.0
review: Warframe Review: The game is fun. Being able to run on walls and wall jump and do all sorts of ninja moves is very enjoyable. All the warframes do feel different and there are enough weapons and frames for people to find the one that suits their play style. This also ends up being the downfall of the game. Every weapon and frame in the game can be bought with platinum (paid currency) or credits (currency earned in-game). If bought with platinum you get the weapon or frame instantly ready to use. If you use credits however you recieve a blue print and you then have to collect the resources to craft the weapon or frame. This isn't too bad for the weapons but the frames are very tedious to make as they require 3 pieces that are made from 3 other blueprints that cannot be purchased. Expect grinding to craft your weapons and frames and expect more to level them up as well. The game does feature a daily rewards system that might reward you with a discount on platinum of up to 75% off. You can't get platinum by playing but this feature is better than nothing. Playing online can be an issue as well. Servers tend to have high bandwith. The game is set to make the person with the best internet connection the host but it doesn't guarentee anything. Overall the game is entertaining and fun but is still plagued by some Free-to-Play problems. The game is best played with friends as it will provide you with better servers and you might be able to stay sain during grinding. I can't explain it but despite the issues, I keep going back for more with this game. Despite the flaws I keep coming back every now and then and I always enjoy my time. Score: 6.7/10

review: A fast-paced third-person cooperative shooter with light RPG elements, with Ninjas in robotic suits fighting evil factions across the galaxy. The only down side to Warframe is the AI is poor (sometimes they would see me and then run behind boxes ignoring me and my teamates until I attacked them) and although the game randomly generates environments (enemy ships and sometimes planets surfaces) it most of the time just makes you feel like you are playing a level that you completed earlier, with slightly different tweaks. But don't let those flaws prevent you from play this awesome, awesome game.

review: Have played the game for about a week, logged in each day from day one. Love the visuals and the Sci-Fi Samurai/Ninja theme. The way they handle the login screen and the back story are awesome. Having the menus integrated so well into the game as game play it self is neat. Game-play can be fast and furious or slow and steady, depending on how your set your load out.Which is very nice. Selected the Bow as my primary at the get go. Which was fun being able to stealth kill everyone, but then you are suddenly found out by that one soldier.... medium range engagements get a bit tedious.... One gripe I have in this regard is obtaining new weapons. I wanted to get a assault rifle but the cost was too high for me to change after even the second mission . So was stuck with he bow till I ran several missions to collect the credits. Which was till after the whole intro quest finished. So yeah flexibility to try new weapons -at least of the same tier- is non existent... Guess that is the grind element that you get in MMOs. Another thing I find perplexing is the lack of a filter function in the market screen/view. If there is one then it isnt obvious enough.... Would really like to filter "Out" the items that require cash shop currency. Match making kinda sucks as well. Doesn't seem to like me playing with other players. And when it did pair me up, they were like 7 ranks above me. So ended up in missions higher level to me. Or so I presume, I have no idea at this time how to tell my level. ok.. so thats more than one gripe. Overall, I like the game, would love to get into a new warframe and try some other weapons... but guess taht will take time... besides that, the gripes are more annoyances really. Cept the Feral Kubrows... they scare teh crap out of me Q_Q

review: Huge respect for Digital Extremes, for making a AAA game and give it to us for free. The movements and effects were so beautifully rendered, sometimes I wonder if it's really free. My first 4 hours of gameplay was interesting. I didn't explore much at this point, so I'm gonna say it's good enough. The premium item system is quite balanced. Half of it was cosmetics, and it's not to gamebreaking. Another respect for the developers for not using pay2win way. Play it. It's worth your time.

review: If you like co-op shooters then this game is for you. The fact that its free makes it a must play for any gamer. Definitely one of the best F2P available right now. Not your typical F2P game, it is based on co-op not PvP. This game is PLAY to win, not PAY to win. You can buy all the materials to make new gear for prices that i can only describe as extortion. If you put some good time into this game, you can find all of the materials you need to craft the different items and not end up spending 200$ on "Platinum" which is the games paid currency. If you can get a few of your buddies or some good online teammates you are guranteed to have a good time playing this game. Its free, its fun. Try it. Period.

game-hours: 517.1
review: While Warframe is a very well made game, it does have some features that can let some players down. For instance the lack of ability to specialise yourself in anything but Combat or stealth early on is unfortunate. However there are many pros to this game. Pros: Building Weapons and Warframes You have never reached your maximum potential Fun Gameplay Ninja in space! New Hud is nice to look at PVP/Conclave for those who need it Warframes are essentially different classes, and can be changed between missions Cons: Gameplay can wear down on veteran players Without a clan you will need platinum for some things Without a clan higher end weapons will never be available to you The game can feel as though all you do is level items Personally, about 70% of the players I have met are kind and respectful, the other 30 treat Warframe as an outer space Call of Duty, often teabagging you when they should be reviving you. Fortunately if you are with that 30% your warframes get 4 revives each, bringing you back with starting energy, full shields and health. Most Warframes can be built after 3 or more times fighting a boss, meaning a new class will be available to you within 3 days of creating all 3 pieces and getting the Orokin Cell required. However there is still a catch, defeating a boss has a risk of giving you a death mark, sending another psuedo boss after you. Once you enter a mission with a level 5 or over warframe be carefull. The invasions are a nice touch, giving you the choice to side with either of your enemies for rewards, which can often be a hard to aquire material, or a great ammount of credits. Again, choosing a side these days is a risk as The Corpus have a copy of Jupiters boss to send after you, which will put you in a secret mission, and The Grineer have the Grustrag Three, both of these work as the stalker does. Sometimes during this game I found myself in over my head, surrounded or backed into a corner, but such is the beauty of this games co-op system. A friend playing the game can join your mission, or you can join them, and you can fight together, of course, the enemies will become slightly stronger, but having a second man can make all the difference in many missions or boss missions. I personally have found that the most effective team I have seen to date was an Ash, Trinity, Frost and Volt, this team has destroyed even the Hyena Pack and the Dual boss on Phobos. As I write this review I have come to a time where I am begginning not to enjoy warframe as I once did, due to what feels like repetetive levelling, however back when I only had two warframes, both rank 30, I remember having fun destroying entire armies of enemies with nothing but a bow, a pistol and a sword. This game is only as fun as you try to make it. 8/10

game-hours: 1147.5
review: For a free to play game, Warframe certainly gets quite a few things right: The graphics are gorgeous, the game mechanics are simple, & the Frames (characters) are unique, and stand out with personalities even though they don't have dialouge. As a bonus, the developers are very involved in the community; adding new weapons and items, as well as implementing new game modes and events with detailed backgrounds on a regular basis. The weapons and frames are so diverse and numerous, & it's really fun to experiment and find a combination that you call your own. The only problem I have with the games structure is that you get VERY few weapon and frame slots to start with, and you can only get more through buying Platinum (cash). There are so many weapons and frames I feel that they need to add a few more slots, because new players might not have the information they need to sink some money into the game if they can't experiment with more than 2 frames or 4 weapons. And, unfortunately, the starting weapons suck to the maximum, but that should be expected since you need to work your way up. I would definitely reccommend this game to anyone who wants an action / brawler game, because the melee / ninja-acrobatic side is stronger than the shooter side.

review: Whilst not incredibly impressive if taken at surface value, Warframe has many, many hidden layers. The lore and backstory is hidden behind so much secrecy put out by the developers. However, if you play it for long enough, realise just enough, you will work it out eventually. With such a rich and still debated backstory, There's not much not to love. The gameplay is also smooth, but far from being its best feature; bugs and glitches do feature prominently in this game but do get fixed regularly. There's regular content updates and events to do, and the combat is reasonably smooth. Not the best game I've ever played, but for free, it's definitely worth it.

review: A space-aged, ninja fantasy with guns, powers, and laying waste to the enemy. The development team is countable and appear to bring more to the table yearly than most multiplayer games. Its worth a shot if you're questioning it.
game-hours: 5.2
review: I can't talk highly enough about this game. Though don't let that tell you I love everything about it. While I love this game it does have flaws. For starters, the game will get a bit repetitive. A lot of the levels are recycled multiple times. There will be times you will think you're playing on a whole new level, but you may just find out you're on another unexplored part of a different level that you have previously explored. With that said, some of the levels are absolutely enormous and it will take you a long time to explore every inch of some of them with just one run through. Something else adding to how repetitive the game will get is the limited amount of enemy types you will come across. There are only 3 or 4 factions. So you'll be seeing the same enemy types over and over. You'll get used to fighting them. Once you have some weapons that you've spent some time with, that youve customized to you, you will rip through the enemies that you're used to like they aren't even there. Paying to play. Yes the game is free. You will get starting equip. One Warframe [Character], one melee weapon, one sidearm weapon, and one primary weapon. Enough to get you right out there and into the fray. To acquire new characters and weapons though, you will need to grind, quite a bit. First you will ether need to buy [with in game currency, not real money] the recipe for the weapon. Then you'll need to save up the credits to actually build the weapon. Then you'll need to find all the necessary materials which you'll need to grind through levels to acquire. And a lot of times you'll need to grind through a few different planets to get those materials. Once you have it all, you craft the recipe. And that takes time. A lot of time. The most you will wait is 3 days; which is the time to build a new character. Weapons are usually about 12 hours. Speaking of building a character though. Those are even harder. Youll need to find the mission type, boss battle, or planet that the pieces to the Warframe drop in. Once you do that, you need to collect all three pieces, the head, torso, and control system for the frame. But those aren't the actual pieces; they're recipes to get those pieces. Which you will then need to craft with the right materials same as before. Once you have crafted all three parts. You need to craft them together. With the overall recipe for the Warframe. All of this costs a lot of in game credits. And overall will take about 3 days. So it's time consuming. That being said, once you have a bit of gear, once you find a setup that you are used to and enjoy playing with, the grind goes much faster. Youll be hopping from planet to planet grinding out materials and credits like its nothing. Because of that, I recommend playing for a bit. Figure out how much you think this game is worth. Drop that into the game with the purchase of the real money game currency. Me? I love this game. I played it. I enjoyed it. I felt I was playing it more than some of the $60 games I had spent money on. So I dropped $50 into it; I got myself decked out with some new frames that looked fun, some new weapons, and a sentinel. And since then Ive ground out new equipment without even thinking about it just because I was enjoying the game. All my problems with it aside, the game is fun, pure and simple. It may not have a compelling story; it may get a bit repetitive. But its fun. And really thats what a game should be; fun, able to keep your attention. The sign of a good game is a game that you can play for hours and hours without even realizing that time is passing around you. This game did that for me. I recommend it very highly even with the shortcomings I have found with it.

review: Tons of awesome space ninja action? Check. An invention system? Check. Custom Place to call your own? Check. Tons of stuff to collect? Check. Sweet weapons with an ever growing variety? Check. If you're looking for a game that has almost everything, this is it. If you're looking for a game that's non-stop action, with tons of customization, this is it. If your looking for a lame  FPS or 3ps pvp shooter.... this is not it. Beautiful maps, weather effects, day/night cycles, detailed game world with collectable history and an every growing army of badass space ninjas. You want to stand and brawl your enemies to death, there is a Warframe for you. You want to sneak around and snipe unseen? There's a Warframe for you. You want to obliterate massive mobs of bloodthirsty enemies, teleport away and scamper off to the objective... yup, you guessed it, there's a Warframe for you. If you're like me and ever played a shooter and thought, "Man... if I could climb up there....". Well, friends, Warframe lets you do just that. With mad ninja skillz, and expansive maps, you can run, leap, backflip, climb and slide through starships, deserts, twisted forests and frozen wastes... and I havn't even gotten around to exploring every map. If you've ever thought, "Sheeeooot, this gun is sweet, but I wish it shot explosive bullets", then you are in for a treat. The weapon modifications available for the large and ever growing collection of weapons ensures that no two players weapons are identicle, and that you can always refit your weapons for any situation. Need fire? slap it on and jump into the mission. Need blazing electric death and explsoins? You're covered with the weapon mod system used in Warframe. Over all, an excellent game that's constantly getting better.... AND the developers just GIVE it away. Yes... it is FREE. Free awesome and space ninja goodness... seriously, who gives away a game this great? Get it now, before these fine people are hauled away to the nearest funny farm.

review: You either love or hate this game. Me, I ended up uninstalling it, but it's not bad, actually quite good compared to others, and worth a try to anyone, plus it's free. In short, the game has so many things it does right, yet so many things it does wrong, at least in my opinion. You might enjoy the combat, the variety of mission types, the possiblities of all those weapons and warframes, and the (now) streamlined HUD/interface, along with endless replayiblity and decent netcode, with the game's amazing optimization and graphics topping it off. Or, you could be annoyed by the excessive grindiness, the monotony of missions, the (at times) brutal unfairness of the enemies, the awful parkour and melee, among other things. I more commonly encountered the latter, the reason why I uninstalled the game, but to be honest, like I said, the game has some pretty awesome things about it. I believe a lot of people exaggerate the bad points - the stuff I mentioned is bad, but not that bad. I ended up very mixed about this game, somewhat actually in between. I would recommend just giving this game a try, seeing if, whether to you, the good things surpass the bad, or vice versa. After all, it's free - what have you got to lose?

game-hours: 500.1
review: So, uh, Warframe. Where to start. Basically the trailer shows you as a kinda ninja robot thingy who kills whole groups of enemies using unique powers - that's half-true. In Warframe, most of ths stuff is actually gun play. It's third-person, which means you get to stare over your own shoulder a lot, but it's FAST - ie. stupidly fast physics-defying (as in, not even theoretical physics-defying) fights where you say 'hey, I want to kill that boxheaded robotic guy over there. Do I a) slide along the floor, spin around and slice him into two pieces at the waist LIKE A BOSS, or b) shoot at him? Which one is faster? Did I hear a)?' Crazy trick stunts aside, there's a variety of weapons (although I have to complain that primary weapons are ALWAYS stronger than their secondary counterparts), and the thing that makes this game unique: Warframes. Warframes being that robotic suit of armour which lets you do really absurd stuff, like pull whole groups off ledges to laand at your feet and get finished off by that great big reaper you just happen to be carrying. Or go so crazy that all the enemies in a large radius around you get confused and start attacking each other. Or shed your skin, or hit the ground so hard everything around you goes slowmo, or maybe even just bog-standard turn invisible. There are warframes to fit most playstyles - support, tank, glasscannon - and all with unique ability sets, but none of them are biased towards a set of weapons. You don't get a sniper frame. You get a whole load of frames, whether fast, light and high-damaging, or slow but resilient, and you can lump whatever weapon you like on it. One good example is the primary healing/support frame, with her ability that directs all damage taken to nearby enemies while reducing damage done to herself, and slap a manually-detonated 5-shot grenade launcher on it. You can even get a compound bow/railgun with a high Critical chance, put it on the Warframe with an ability that highlights weakspots on enemies and massively amplifies damage to that point, and then run riot in a Survival mission where you need to kill LOADS of enemies to keep your oxygen supplies up. All in all, this game is fast (if update-intensive), and well worth a try.

game-hours: 337.8
review: Warframe provides an easy to learn, third person shooter with some minor roleplaying abilities. The game excels at providing quick missions to pass the time, or longer missions with a squad to level and grab new gear. The game centers around Tenno, an elite group of warriors. These warriors are masters with several types of weapons, such as assault rifles, shotguns, lasers, or poison blob launchers. However, it can also be effectively played with the melee weapons in the game; they range from large axes and hammers, to dual wielded daggers and specialty items. Overall, the game is quite an enjoyable experience. The main drawback is the time it takes to build items. A new "Warframe", which is similar to classes in other games, will generally take ~3.5 days to build, unless Platinum is spent on it (the purchaseable in-game currency). With patience, and plenty of weapons, there are many bad guys to exterminate while waiting.

review: Having played this game for a few hours, I think I can safely say, 'This game rocks!' The combat is smooth and the controls are easy. whether you are sniping, healing, or tanking, all equipment is tailored to it's purpose with serious forethought and planning to it's ultimate function. There are balance issues, but not many, and when you play single, co-op, or PvP, you can always find the gun, or sword, or rocket launcher of your choice doing it's job with workman-like capability. Since this is an AI driven game, (the PvP is limited, unfortunately) you do find yourself piling up alot of enemy corpses. Thankfully there are plenty of maps, and plenty of varied objectives to attain, making the combat fresh enough to keep you at it for at least 30 hours, (if not more). So get some guys, get a dojo, and get in the fight! You won't regret it. - BMO (I travel space and Ninja  that I find there...)
