game-hours: 74.8
review: NOTE: Don't let my low game time fool you, I played this game in the very early stages of closed Beta, and have probably played a couple hundred hours before it came to steam. Need proof? If you were to see my in-game inventory, I have two weapons that were given exclusively to closed Beta testers. I like to skip the wordiness and go straight to the pros and cons, which will tell any reader what they need to know right away. So here you go: Pros: -EXCELLENT gameplay. I have not found melee combat that is this fast fast paced and action style in any other mmo game. And heck, if I want to shoot stuff, I can switch to my rifle or sidearm, which leads to my next point... -TONS of weapon variety -A large variety of obtainable characters with unique skills -Great character progression can be found in the game's deep modding and level up system -Some pretty nifty asthetic items from the cash shop if you are willing to pay $$$ -VERY nice graphics -A growing 'map' variety -A growing variety of playable mission types -(sometimes) interesting boss fights (see cons) -An awesome clan(guild) system with the best modular clan dojo (ie guild hall) system I have ever seen implemented -Practical matchmaking/social system -Fairly frequent updates with great content and almost always game mechanics updates/additions -This game expands and gets better with EVERY update Cons: -Can get very grindy and repetitive after a while -Cash shop currency is a little on the expensive side compared to other games -Missions can feel somewhat linear -(For some people) Time gated crafting -If you play in an online party and are looking for a fun, challenging boss fight, prepare to be disappointed (a large majority of the time): You will often get connected with much higher level players who are grinding for rare materials and will kill the boss in about 2 hits (on the other hand if you want to craft that awesome sword but arent strong enough to beat said boss, this could be considered a pro) Note: I have yet to play the newest update, but it looks like the devs have yet again crafted another unique game mode that makes this game even better. Update: I've now played a couple hours in the Archwing update. It adds new quests and an entirely new gamemode to be unlocked. It also adds new factions that you can join and earn sweet rewards by gaining reputation with them. Once again very impressed by the diversity the devs have managed to bring to this game
game-hours: 437.9
review: Let me just start with a brief summary for those who don't have time for a wall of words: The game is marred with frustrating deaths, interesting AI, and a questionable free-to-play model, but, it can be played both as a single player and coop experience and thanks to a good starting package for just downloading the game, it's well worth a try. Now for the meat: When I saw that this game was free to play, I assumed it was an MMO of sorts - surprisingly, it's a cooperative 3rd person shooter  la Borderlands, or even sometimes feels like a micro MMO (seems contradictory in name) like Destiny. Fortunately, for those with social awkwardness or whatever social disorder you have like myself, you can set matchmaking to "solo" and you get to play all by yourself! Huge points to the devs for adding that, but, this comes as a double edged sword. Firstly, this solo mode means going into some missions - even ones you have clearly outleveled - feeling like the odds are stacked against you tremendously - especially in the "domination" styled missions where boss mobs and tons of trash mobs are taking capture points left and right and you are the only one trying to juggle capturing the points while trying not to die - and boy can dying feel SOOOOO painful and frustrating in this game due to it's free to play model (which, I will cover in a minute) Secondly, the solo mode promotes people, like myself, wanting to play alone, and with how the game is set up with over 200+ missions, each of them their own individual instances, finding a group for some of the pettier missions is near impossible, and I think the solo mode only encourages other players to only do public match making when they arrive at a far-too-difficult of a mission for them to handle. Let me tell you, it was the most depressing realization I had when I clicked "public matchmaking" and waited for about 10 minutes to do a single mission which would take 10-15 minutes to complete. I pressed shift-tab to invite friends and saw my only 2 friends on Steam, both offline. A single tear rolled down my cheek. Starting the game out you'll get to pick your own free items to play with; 1 of 3 warframes (let's consider warframes champions like in Dota or LoL) you get to pick 1 of 3 weapons for each slot; 1 primary weapon, 1 secondary weapon, and 1 melee weapon. The options are fairly good at the beginning, too. I grabbed the bow and have been finding it the most useful (to me) out of some of the bought weapons. There is no hub world, in fact there is no free-to-explore mode. As mentioned above, the whole game is done through missions, each their very own instance. During these instances, the level design is very nice and old school, where there is a clear defined path to the goal, but there are many alternate routes and secrets to discover if you go off the beaten trail. On the other hand, there are about 15 or so non-story related missions per planet that take roughly 10 - 20 minutes to complete, and every single mission on the planet uses the same tile-set, meaning by the end of completing a planet, you are down right SICK of seeing the same scenery over, and over again. It does get boring after about an hour of gameplay, to me, due to how samey it can get. The AI are not the worse I have ever seen, and in fact they are fairly reasonable, they just tend to do quircky things sometimes. When I haven't been detected yet, I have seen them walk in a single spot, spinning around in circles. They also seem to prioritize cover over EVERYTHING ELSE. I have literally been chasing a guy down half way across a large open room because he was rushing to get to cover. Sometimes, they fall in love with their cover so much they like to just stay there - which is probably the most annoying quirk, but isn't too much of a problem. Now, the one we have all been waiting for: THE FREE TO PLAY MODEL Boy, this is a tough one to crack. While on one hand it seems pretty fair. You can't buy power as even pieces you can spend hard earned, cold hard cash on are locked by an experience wall, requiring you to have played a certain amount before even being able to spend the money on it. Most weapons and warframes can be bought as a blue print using in game currency. The blueprint is then used to craft the item through in game materials and a little bit of in game currency, but, honestly, in my opinion, I think the game is still asking a lot for you to pay in game currency just to get the blue print and again to have to craft the item (let's not forget the grinding for crafting materials too). To me, it almost seems way easier to spend my cash on the item rather than grind out for this stuff - especially because there is no in game map (as far as I am aware) that points you where to find some of these materials, and one of my pet peeves with games is when a dev expects you to look up a wiki on this kind of thing. This information really should be within the game. I am appreciative of all the various aesthetic items you can get; from different colours you can unlock, to vanity items for your warframe, or even vanity for your weapons, I love it! I am a huge sucker for this kind of thing, but things get irksome with the pricing. I don't know if I have ever seen such an expensive free-to-play model. You have warframes costing 250-350 Platnium, weapons costing 100-250 plat, and vanity items costing 50 - 100 Plat, And of course you can't ever convert your hard earned cash to exactly the equivelent amount you need for the transaction, nope! You can only buy plat in $5 for 75, $10 for 170, $20 for 370, $50 for 100, $100 for 2100, and TWO-HUNDRED DOLLARS for 4300. Before long you'll find this game can easily, VERY VERY easily cost more than a brand new game on launch! Then there is the matter of revives, which is probably the WORST free-to-play SIN I have ever seen in a free-to-play game. Revives in game cost cash. Yes, you read that correctly, revives cost real money. Granted, the revives only cost 3 plat per revive, which is fairly trivial amount, but like I said, you can only buy in $5, $10, ect incriments, which means when you run out of revives and plat, you have to drop another $5. Yes, TECHNICALLY you DO NOT NEED REVIVES. If you die with no revives, you simply fail the mission. But, man, did they make this the most punishing way to fail a mission. "Oh you died! Hold on 15 seconds.....Okay, now we are going to load....okay, now here you are back on your ship. Oh? You wanted to retry that mission again? Well just open up the map, select the planet, scroll to the mission, select the mission, wait for the 5 second count down, load the mission, watch the intro to the mission again, and now you are good to go try it again!" I don't think I have ever play a game that has made death so aggrivatingly painful before, and couple that with poor feedback when you are close to dying, I have had NUMEROUS deaths where I didn't even see it coming, one minute, I am full health, full shield, next I'm plastered across the floor. What happened? Why isn't there some sort of an alert when my health is low? There is no visual indication that you health is low other than the very tiny health bar at the top right. Then when you die, you can either decide to spend one of your revives, or just forfeit the match, both options are so incredibly painful to choose. To conclude; the best thing I can say is give it a try, especially if you have some friends, but be careful if you play solo.
game-hours: 70.9
review: Very fun game, once you figure it out. It has a learning curve, but it isnt too bad. The game is just very different from most other games I have played. The best way to learn how to properly fit your Warframe with mods and equipment is to check out YouTube and the Wiki. Those are your bestfriends. I started playing earlier this week and didnt have a clue what I was doing. I just knew that I had this Warframe, a primary, secondary, and a melee weapon and a planet with some places to go. I followed the "tutorial" (which is really pathetic) and ended up back in my spaceship wondering, "Ok, now what the eff do I do?". Talking in the chat is basically useless, most people (from my experience) ignore you and the others just say you are noob for asking questions. Thats when I turned to YouTube and the wiki. If it wasnt for them, I would have quit after the "tutorial". The game is pretty fun, overall. You do missions solo or you can team up with up to 3 friends or 3 random players. The Warframes range from Melee to Tanks to Support (Hell yeah, Im talking about Trinity). There are many weapons and items in the game and companions/sentinels, and every single thing in the game that I have saw so far can be earned in game without paying a cent. You can pay to speed this up by just buying what you need, but why, when you can do a small bit of farming and get it yourself? Or you can make a few high lvl friends and have them drag you around for a while (Go go gadget Rhino Prime). If you enjoy RPGs/Shooters, then you should give this a try. Its free, so why not?

game-hours: 303.2
review: Warframe is a fun romp with friends. You play as the Tenno, a sort of space-samurai-ninja-wizard-gunslinger-warrior that is reintroduced to a galaxy at war after years of slumber. You fight three different races: the Grineer, a genetically engineered, augmented race of humans from Earth; the Corpus, a federation of trade interests with the focus on profit and advanced technology; and the Infested, an amalgamation of races that are infested with a pathogen akin to the Flood or any zombie/infestation archetype. It plays as an action third person shooter. It's good fun once you put some hours into it. Starts off weaker, but as you get into the meat of the game, unlock a weapon or two, and a week later get a warframe or two, it's good fun. But only with friends. This game is a slog if you're going solo. A moderately enjoyable shooter. With friends, it's an enjoyable crazy shooter/slasher. The biggest hurdle in this game is time. You need time for everything. Crafting components for weapons, creating warframes, mining for crafting supplies, it all takes time. Platinum, the premium currency, propels everything along in a quick fashion. Platinum, however, is not cheap. If you enjoy this game, put in $20 or so. Only buy things you need to buy. Don't buy weapons or warframes. Only use the platinum for affinity (experience) boosters and advanced components like forma or gear like orokin catalysts/reactors. View this game not as a purely free game, but a low-cost game. $20 or so will make this game extremely enjoyable, especially if you have friends. A definite recommend if you have some samurai-friends to help you slay some space baddies.

review: Though it has its bugs and glitches, this game is incredible. I've always liked ninja-introduced games, and this is one has proved its self to me. Pros 1. game-hours: 130.1
review: Warframe is an extremely addicting game that allows the use of futuristic weaponry to obliterate all of those who stand in your way. For a free to play, this game allows you get equiptment that you might usually need to spend real money on. The game also includes a vast amount of customization from what weapons you use, how they look and how well they preform in combat. The bosses all have unique characteristics about them and the weapons and warframes to choose from makes it quite difficult to find someome who has the same loadout as you. Playing by yourself or cooperating with others gives you 2 different approaches to the game and only experiencing both will give you the best view. The (somewhat) interactive maps, skills and randomly generated maps (I believe) increase the epicness of this game. Although this is a good game, the maps can sometimes be quite repetitive and dont have many unique aspects to them and the mobs you face tend to be as well. The bosses you face, however, are quite different in how they fight and what their weaknesses are. The gameplay can be similar to many mob grinding games, killing enemies, collecting data and sabotaging key points while levering up your equiptment. You can explore the maps and find materials and resources needed to build newer and more exciting things. As you kill your enemies, they sometimes drop these tablets called mods. These mods can upgrade ur equiptment by increasing damage, reload speed, fire rate ect or can apply new effects like frost, fire or electric damage. As the level of your equiptment rises, the more upgrades you can apply to them. Mods can also be fused together with others to make your starting mod stronger at the cost of a higher energy cost. You can also combind unwanted mods together to create different mods you may want. Overall, this game is one of the best free to play games I have ever seen a high level of excitement and customization options making me come back for more every time. It is a very well thought out and addicting game that exceeds all my expectations for free to play and pay to play games.

game-hours: 262.6
review: Fantastic game that will last you hundreds of hours. At the time of writing I have about 130 hours in this game. I am no where near completed with it. The devs release new content constantly. Not just new maps or new enemies, but entire new game modes and features. They listen to the community and are very active in it (for example they often host streams on twitch in which they show off new stuff, discuss warframe, and give away prizes. they also recently did an AMA on reddit). Business model: The premium currency is called platinum. platinum is used to purchase items from the in game store, speed up a number of processes, or it can be used as a trading currency between players. The game is not pay to win. IIRC some of the best stuff can't even be purchased, it has to be unlocked. If you spend money on this game you are buying convenience and/or cosmetics. A large number of the cosmetics can be unlocked in game. Gameplay: Ninjas, in space. You run up walls, throw knives, swing swords, and defy laws of physics-- like a ninja. But you also shoot guns, visit all the planets in the solar system, and utilize different exoskeletal frames with special abilities. The environments are varied and rich, and each level randomly generates. There is a nice attention to detail: Enemies being cut in half by your massive sword, corpses being pinned to walls by your bow, and baddies fizzling on the floor after you zapped them to death. It makes you feel badass. There is also a lot of customization. every piece of equipment can be modified in look and stats to fit your prefference. As you use a weapon more, it unlocks more potential to be upgraded. Graphics: Great. The art style is amazing. The particle effects from weapons and abilities make combat extremely pleasing to watch. The lighting in the environments is brigth enough to see what you are doing, but it isn't a flat ugly light. This is the sort of game that becomes more enjoyable the more you play it.

game-hours: 1018.2
review: Warframe is a free to play game where player take on the role of Tenno, legendary warriors of old that wears suits that were called Warframe. This game offers more than just any normal third-person shooter game, it includes free-running (AKA parkour), special abilities, stealth capabilities, weapon modifications, warframe customizations and many more. Gameplay: Simple and easy to learn the basics but hard to master. Like i said, this game introduces parkour skills which will require the player to be more mindful of their surroundings, which includes anything that the player can interact with or makes use of in taking advantage of the battle of 1-4 warframes vurses many. For example, the player is able to sprint, slide, jump, handspring backwards or even rolling to the side so that it will be harder for the enemies to hit and easier for the player to manuever around and take the golden opportunity to kill. There are many styles to play this game. There are the spam the ability user so that the enemies wont get the upper hand, stealth ninjas (LIKE A BOSS) through a mission without being seen or tripping the alarm, rushing through the mission without having to engage the enemy or even "RAMBO" the mission. Aside from the action, this game particularly impresses me with the customizations of weapon or warframe modules (mods). This is a more tricky part of the game as it requires the player to research or find out more about in the wiki. Whatever modules the player put in, plays a part in the players overall playstyle. Did i ever mention about different factions? These factions have different types of AI, though some are similar but it requires the player to think on their feet as difficulties may vary based on the player's playstyle. Thus, it is easy to learn but hard to master. Crafting/Market: In Warframe, their in-game currency are called credits and there is also another in-game currency called platinum where player choose to trade real money to platinums having the players access to items that are sold in the in-game market. Though it may look like it is pay to win but it is in fact not, as this game requires the skill and knowledge of the player to progress through the game smoothly. And most of the items that you can get in the market can be crafted by the player, provided the player has enough resources and also the blueprint to build that particular item . Drops: This game is infamous for its not that stable RNG that somehow prevents the players to get the particular resources in that mission. Thus, born the art of grinding in warframe and everything else just becomes boring. Tutorial: Unlike other games, never skip the tutorial as this helps the player to understand the game more, and hopefully the player can progress the game smoothly without having to quit after the first 3 hours of playing and still not understand of how the entire game works. Overall: This game is ok but there is rooms for improvement such as the stealth system and tutorials and drop rates so it is better for new player to stick to the game because of smooth progress in the game. Due to this game is still under beta phase, there will be changes in the near future, either for balancing or testing out some items or events.

review: Warframe is... an ok game. I wouldn't go as far as to say "It's a good game" or "It's better than Red Faction Armageddon with the download corrupted and a Zip bomb inside the download". (If you don't know what a zip file bomb is, Google it) anyway... So you play as a robotic alien... robot called a "Warframe" you have to complete missions on different planets with a wide range of people from around your set area. All the levels look like blatant rip offs of the previous level the only difference is that the colour has gone from dark green to dark blue. You can customise your Warframe, well, to an extent. At first you can only customise your Warframe's colour which doesn't make any difference seeing as you only start off with 5 colours of the rainbow that even Van Gogh wouldn't touch. You get upgrades for your weapons (though I can't tell the difference). The final verdict: I'd rate this game a 4/10 due to the repetitive levels, tedious plot and the god awful character customisation system. Where it says "Do you recommend this game", Steam should have a third option from 'Yes' and 'No' it should be labelled 'Meh'.

game-hours: 317.4
review: As someone who's played a lot of the game (225 Hours as of when I'm writing this), I can say it's overall a pretty good game, and it's all but boring. It is, however, fairly repititive in its play, and you have to either A) Get used to a lot of grinding and waiting, or B) Spend money to get things quickly and the way you want them. It is pay-to-win in a few senses, but everything you can get by spending real money, you can get by waiting for in-game time-limited, occasional alerts, which give the same things out. As far as grinding, it's like every other game with an RNG that tends to hate or love certain players. It has a fairly balanced player market, in which you can sell these *rare* items you get from the RNG to other players for Platinum, the credits you spend actual money for. So, in a sense, spend time on this game and you can convert it into practical real money. Over all, this game is pretty well-done, especially as far as graphics go, and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes MMOs in general, even though the themes and genre may not please others, along with the lack of lore. Either way, it's a solid game.

game-hours: 559.3
review: OLD REVIEW of APR 2013: Team or solo based sci-fi third person shooter, quite fun! NEW REVIEW of SEPT 2014: Be wary, as Perfect World Entertainment has their gritty claws on the title and I fear this game would become even more grindier than it is now. NEWER REVIEW of OCT 2014: It is an OK game, good for wasting a couple hours of co-op fun but there is one glaring flaw with this game is the lack of new map content. Seeing the same map chunks used in levels will get tiresome and tedious, especially when grinding to get those rare resources you need to make a new frame or weapon. Build time for weapons and frames are unacceptable, do you really want to wait 12 hours for your new weapon or 36 hours to play with your new frame? I sure don't. Also the UI as of Update 14 is intrusive, clunky and screams console friendly. Your ship's AI is annoying but thankfully you can mute him. Some rank tests are obnoxious, particularly if you are no good with such skill. I am still stuck at rank 8 because I am god awful at mandatory stealth and refuse to rank up. However, I do like the weapon and enemy designs of the factions as well as the lore and history injected into them, which can be read in-game via the Codex. The game has a lot of potential, but it needs more map content, a lot more to keep somebody who loves procedural generation in video games.

game-hours: 38.6
review: Yet another hack-and-slash RPG. Unoriginal, yet somehow fresh. Warframe combines standard shooting with hack-and-slash gameplay for a familiar, yet new experience. The basics are simple: you have your suit, your sword, and your guns. Now go kill stuff. Mindless yet attention-keeping, while at the same time testing your ability to adapt to a new situation. The game is riddled with environmental hazards and enemies of increasing strength. From the hideous Grineer to the scavenger race Corpus, you will never have a dull moment. That is... until the FPS starts to tank. For some reason, this game has horrible FPS issues, to the point that some have nicknamed it "Warframe-rate-drop." The devs are continuously figuring ways to make the experience less of a pain, however. I would at least pick it up, if you like hack-and-slash games. Don't worry about lag, as you don't have to play online. You can go it alone, or go with up to three buddies, or if you're feeling adventurous, three completely-random-people-you-found-in-chat. Have fun!
game-hours: 8.8

game-hours: 456.7
review: Awesome
game-hours: 439.3
review: After one of my favorite games shut down and was nowhere to be found in English ever again, I went on a hunt for another free-to-play game that was 1, graphically pleasing, 2, NOT pay-to-play or pay-to-keep-playing, 3, not repetitive, and 4, worth playing. I found this gem of a game a bit before it went on steam and adored it. This was over a year ago, and this game is still one of my top ten. Why it's a good game! Look at those GRAPHICS. For a free-to-play game? They're good. Also, sometimes you can get a really awkward Grineer ragdoll when you pin it to the wall with an arrow or something. Anything you want to get, you can buy, yes, but you can also get EVERYTHING without spending a dime. Takes a while longer, but you'll get it! It's constantly evolving. The devs work hard for each update. If I get bored, all I need to do is wait for the next update to liven up the game. The voice of the players is heard pretty well. I made a complaint about a planet being out of whack, and I got a response within half an hour. I like that. WALL-RUNNING?!?!?!?! SPACE-NINJA?!?!?!?!? SPECIAL ABILITIES?!?!?!? I like cool stuff. There are clans and stuff. People are generally nice. I have yet to find a reason to describe the community as hostile, besides the usual trolls. Why you might not like it! It starts to feel like grinding sometimes. A little. But gaming involves time investment, so it's up to you whether or not to take a break and come back later to a less tedious task like farming materials or straining for that next rank. Can't really think of much else. It's all minor stuff. Typical hazards of gaming, y'know. So yeah. Try it. If you don't like it, move on, if you do, move into the game and enjoy it. Pew pew.

review: Great game, really and truly. The gameplay is great, the graphics are top notch, the lighting is very interesting as well. the fluidity of the combat, from the gunplay to the sword play is very nice. There are also unique ways of getting around the maps: wallrunning, sliding, super-jumping, ziplining, etc. Once you play the game for a while you start to get the hang of it and learn the tips and tricks, it really is alot of fun. This game isn't without flaws however. The crafting system is a bit tedious, sometimes taking hours to compile all the materials required for something. Gaining money/experience also takes a sufficient amount of time. All in all, this game is very fun, very entertaining, and can keep you locked in for a while. BEWARE: your pinky finger will want to fall off from holding ctrl for so long...

review: The concept art design is top notch. This is the main reason I recommend this game. I believe it is done by the same artist that did the design for Pacific Rim, Don't be Afraid of the Dark, and Borderlands 1's alien weapons -- Keith Thompson. The weapons and warframe feel very unique, blending organic and mechanical feels together. Almost like Giger's works. Gameplay is grinding heavy but kinda fun. The system has a lot of depth, like the damage 2.0 system, which allows some theory crafting. Gunplay is OK, animation is OK. Overall 5/10. Mediocre but there is nothing else like it on the market (other than Mass Effect 3 multiplayer which I refuse to pay for to Bioware).

review: Sci-Fi and Ninjas are a good combo. :)
game-hours: 83.6
review: One of the more unique games I've played in recent memory: Loot grinding space ninja co-op RPG shooter. Going from planet to planet, clearing out all the zones and getting good loot, and upgrading said loot, is some of the very fun. Think 'Borderlands' but with a mission list on a solar map, good if you just want to do one match at a time or hunker down for a long night of gaming. This game can be a bit difficult to figure out at times, the movement and melee feel odd at first and many of the RPG mechanics have a sizable learning curve, but once I figured them out I found it very enjoyable and rewarding to play. The free to play model works well for this game, putting money into the game is more a way of saving time than becoming overpowered. Having said that I've put over $100 in to this game (counting the PS4 version as well). I haven't done much soloing in the game but it is an option if you prefer, however I find the co-op mechanics very unobtrusive and as long as you stay within an appropriate level range you won't have any trouble with other players. That's beside the point that the co-op is an intrinsic part of the game and more importantly is quite fun. A very fun and addictive co-op RPG shooter.

game-hours: 79.9
review: Although I havent played much, this is quite a fantastic game. I would highly recommend this game to any one. Warframe is not an easy game and will piss you off everynow and then, but I always find myself playing again and again. Very addicting. Pros -outstanding graphics -gameplay -amount of levels -smart AI -the player movenment is smooth -free running -single player is great -multiplayer is much more intense and very fun -power up for person/guns/melee -big selection of guns to buy -the ablity to fuse multiples of one card together to make one better card -you can switch what side the gun in on your body (perfect for people who use the left hand for the mouse) -FREE GAME -LOTS OF ATTENTION TO DETAIL If you play close attention to your surroundings you can see the ever so slightly things that aren't super important for gaming, but it amazing me that the developers have done the little things, and that they have made this a free game. Incredible. Cons -You cant free run down/up angled slopes -using your melee weapon takes a lot of practice to actually be good at it -some bugs -levels can be excrusiating and long -having to pay actual money for platnium -ranking can be hard, but isnt awful -TRANSMUTING CARDS IS A BIG NO NO -I think level difficulties increase a littke to fast -only 12 different objectives -a fps option would be nice but kind of ruins the point of the melee weapon. Overall this game is great and its very easy to put TONS AND TONS of time into. This is easily recomended to anyone who loves a challenging shooter.

game-hours: 644.9
review: Warframe is a fun, F2P which tens of thousands of people enjoy very much. To me, Warframe is a great game! First of all, let's talk about the background info. Warframe is a third person game, which is comfortable to my liking circle, and there is a crosshair so it's not SO hard to aim in third person. There are weapon slots, which is good. And the variety of weapons are AMAZING. Bows, to assault rifles, to Corpus/Grineer rifles, to sniper rifles, to crossbows, to laser pistols, and many other weapons including melee. Melee is also amazing. I recommend this game, no doubt! More details here. Warframe's settings has a variety of choices, which is great for people with a weak computer, and also the HUD is very nicely set out in a neat and not all over the place setout. There is a global chat menu, with different sections such as the trading section, recruiting section and most of all, there are clans! Clans are a group of people, and the max member capacity is 1000, AKA Moon Clan. Yes, when clans reach a specific number of members, they will be known as a different clan. Such as my bosses clan Raindogs which is a moon clan. Clans have there own personal building, but we call them Dojos. Varieties of buildings are built in the dojo's, such as hallways, barracks's, weapon labs, and the newly updated lab, Warframe Research Lab! You can research and begin projects in the labs, but this feature requires resources. Well, I can't tell you anymore! It'll be a fun killer! Play this game yourself and you won't regret that you made an account!

game-hours: 459.0
review: I spotted this game shortly before it came along on steam, and considered trying it out. I never got around to it, until it ended up on the front page of the Steam store. The game is built on randomly generated levels, and allows a huge amount of customization for your playstyle. Like running around wacking things? Like teleporting around the battlefield? Like picking off your enemies from afar? This game is for you. If you've got a few minutes, just download it and give it a shot. It's easy to get into, and gives a lot of gameplay. The only downside I've found, if you can call it one, is that not all of the movements and special skills/attacks are described in the tutorial. I personally find this gives the player some things to experiment with, and grows the experience of working on getting some skill in the game. It's free. It'll run playably on my Centrino 2 processor laptop. It's less than two (2) gigabytes, and it's about god damn space ninjas. Why the hell have you NOT tryed it out yet?
game-hours: 854.0
review: I've been a player in this game for about a year now, since its closed beta. Long story short: Monster Hunter with guns and space ninjas. Definitely a very fun game. It's currently in open beta and is constantly being worked and improved upon. There's alot of content in the form of Warframes (characters) and weaponry. Its lore is extremely interesting, but isn't fully implemented as of yet. For the most part, this game is all about "dungeon" running and gathering loot to make stronger/more interesting weapons/warframes. It can be a bit mindless at times, and it's greatly based on "RNG", thus if you're having a very hard time finding a particular item you want, it's best to just do something else for awhile - don't get overly frustrated. This game is one of the rare few F2P games that is NOT pay2win. You can craft every single weapon/warframe available without paying for it, and Digital Extremes specifically made warframe and weapon cash prices high to keep too many people from outright buying all their equipment. All cosmetics, however, are pretty cheap. The community is a mixed bag. Forum-wise....well, Digital Extremes is known for being extremely welcoming to the community. They talk and listen, and feel like human beings. This sadly is a double-edged sword. While some of us greatly enjoy this sort of interactivity with the devs, many forum goers take it for granted. The forums are almost always constantly filled with threads complaining about -everything- and people being overly impatient for a particular update. Recently, there was an outcry about a Flak cannon styled gun. When it was implemented, it was accidentally given Rifle ammo. Rifle ammo's capacity is over 500. Digital Extremes quickly fixed this by switching it to what it should have been: Shotgun ammo, which its capacity is 120. People cried about it, even though this gun is a -flak cannon- that does very high damage and shoots like a shotgun. It can even be charged to do even more damage. Complaints like this are always going on in that forum. I highly suggest only checking the forums for update and event threads. To add: Digital Extremes, as stated, is pretty connected to the community. Weekly dev gameplay livestreams, weekly updates, and bi-weekly livestream Q&A's. That's right: Every single week has some sort of update, and they put in quite a few patchfixes every week as well. I highly recommend this game. Just don't let the forums fool you, and don't get overly aggravated with the RNG.
game-hours: 102.8

game-hours: 370.7
review: I have been playing for 2 weeks now and so far have 216 hours in, I cant stop playing this game. It is a fast paced 3rd person shooter with decent graphics and great gameplay. The movements can awkward at times and the melee feels a bit sluggish but other than that I have no complaints. You build and research your own weapons from materials and blueprints you find through out your journey. You can also build sentinals, new warframes, equipment or take on a master challenge like me of building your own Dojo. The game has a great and helpful player base that is seemingly always willing to answer questions to the best of their capacity. It has a pay to save time system rather than pay to win, in other words if u can buy it, you can farm it. It should be noted however that the best items are earned and can not be purchased. This game has tons of content to always offer you a new challenge and hours fun gameplay while you grind out and learn new tricks to survive. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys shooters and grinding/farming games. If you decide to give it a play I'm always looking for new friends to run with so send me a msg, gamertag Dreoyast.

game-hours: 29.6
review: While the game has it share of problems (slow to start, absolutely no indication on what to do/how to proceed or even a simple explanation of many of the game's various mechanics). If you stick with it past those few tough hours. Warframe begins to open up and with it fun (the reason we ultimately play videogames). Warframe offers a few variations on the standard kill stuff approach, but ultimately repitition will still set in. This is mostly due to the limited environments and enemy types. However do not let those words steer you away from Warframe. At it's core, Warframe is the poster boy for Amazing in small dosages. Logging in and killing enemies with other random players might not sound fun; but I assure you it is very much so. The amazing thing that keeps you coming back is the crafting and leveling system. You run into games with people with different warframes and amazing weapons completely dominating the enemy, and that in turn makes you want to acquire new weapons and increase your warframe's power. Warframe is one of the few F2P games that gets it right. Every single thing that is available for purchase can be found as drop items within the game; how much time you put into Warframe has a direct effect on how much gear and items you'll get out of it for your character.

review: My opinion of Warframe is biased towards how I find enjoyment (I like Grinding in games, no matter how trivial or boring). The gameplay is enjoyable, fun to parkour though there wasn't many places that used it until Update 9. The weapons and Warframes themselves are quite varied, although serious investment is needed to get the top tier equipment. As of now, the game is still in Beta but despite the bugs it's a highly decent Free to Play game. Nearly everything in the game you can aquire without any payment, it just takes time. So how much you're willing to spend is how much time you save with the game. You do need a lot of time though, some drops are very low and get lower if you're a collecter of items like me. Overall; if you have a lot of time, this is a great game to spend it, especially with friends. If you want to have some money free, you can wait for a log-in reward of a Platinum discount (Ingame premium currency) and buy some gear. Otherwise, if you just want to have fun for a while with little investment, start as an Excaliber and Slash Dash your way to victory one Grineer squad at a time.

game-hours: 217.9
review: I was in this game for beta, so I'm not sure how the standard player feels about this game, but the steps it's taken all the way up were satisfying and interesting every step that I could play in. while the original mod setup was fun, the trading card aspect makes it a more social kind of feel. Missions are randomly generated around common tileset, positive or negative, it's a feature that it is well suited to. Tenno (the player's class essentially) are an ancient warrior race in organic-looking powered armor, fighting a crumbling military structure and an intergalactic corporation... it's actually an okay overarching theme to the third person shooter market. While the "four revives" thing sounds terrible, if you're playing online there will be tons of squads. Teamwork is vital to solid gameplay, so lone wolves may need to spend a little time slumming it before finding a solid loadout. Overall, I like this game, and definitely plan on playing it more. Solid combat with simple controls at its core with a visually interesting thematic for the rest of the game. some sets are a little repetitive, but the sheer combinations of setpieces they're putting together is staggering, and they're always improving. Play it or don't, I've said my piece on it, Enjoy.

review: Can honestly feel pretty addicting sometimes. They fixed the issue of feeling like you never had enough money (by letting you earn lots of money in randomly spawned events). Progression can feel slow at times, which can be aleviated with an injection of cash, but damn near everything can be aquired through game play alone (if incredibly difficult due to randomness and availability of certain random items) The most frustrating part is how long new warframes take to aquire. You have to farm/buy 4 different blueprints that take 12 hours (three of them can be crafted simultaniously) and then you need to combine those three parts in a 3 DAY (physical days that is) for your warframe to complete. And even then a free account is only given two slots for warframes at any given time. This is odd as there's ample slots for weapons, but not even enough to let you experiment a bit. But don't let my nagging fool you, it really is a fun game for the most part. Definately worth the "free" cost if you're willing to invest the time. Plus, you get to be a friggen gun toting

game-hours: 57.1
review: Interesting F2P game about being a space-ninja called a Tenno. The gameplay reminds me of Mass Effect 3's multiplayer where you run around 3rd person camera and shoot stuff while using four powers based on your class. Your class and weapons can all be modded with cards that you pick up by killing enemies, but you also need to level your gear to gain points to use to equip the mods. The crafting system takes extensive real-time (12 hours for most pieces of gear and 72 hours to craft a new Warframe which are the different classes.) I enjoyed the game, but I don't like the restrictions on F2P characters. You are limited to only having 2 Warframes unless you pay real money to unlock additional frames. Perhaps this is fair, but the only other option is to sell the warframe you spent so much time leveling in order to try out a new one. Do you get a lot of money for selling your old friend? No, you don't. If you decide that you actually liked the older frame more you have to gather materials and wait 72 hours to recraft and then relevel it. Not fun.

game-hours: 422.9
review: best game ever must buy
game-hours: 1785.5
review: When it comes to F2P MMOs, they usually fall into one of these categories: Great Game, Terrible Community. Bad Game, Great Community. Pay2Win. Warframe, however, is the future of a third-person shooter genre of MMOs. First off, Pay2Win is non-existant. Nothing in WF (outside of a few purely-cosmetic items) is cash only. Infact, often times it's better to simply spend a few hours farming mats for a weapon/warframe rather than to pay cash to instantly get it, although the cash versions come with their own slot and supercharged. (And with the trading system, if you're willing to farm some high-demand mods or items, you can actually trade them for platinum to other players, eliminating any 'need' for purchasing period.) The gameplay is great. No frame plays or feels like the rest, even if they're of the same 'class'. Every frame's powers are unique and different, with obvious uses and plenty of not-so-obvious ways to use them to those who like being creative. The co-op aspect not only makes the game both more challenging and more fun, it actually rewards you more for playing with friends with things such as more enemies to slay, increased loot drops due to more enemies (no loots here, all loot and items can be picked up by all players in the mission), increased credit reward upon certain missions, and much more. You'll often begin missions in "stealth" mode, with enemies unalerted and usually low count (with a few exceptions). How you complete the mission is your choice. Do you embrace your inner ninja, silently waiting in a corner for a passing patrol to slice them up without anyone the wiser, or do you charge in head first headshotting everything and only looking forward to the assault teams coming for you? There is no wrong choice fellow Tenno; only your choice. But if you're a solo player, no fear. Warframe has a "Solo" mode that lets you play by your self. Especially useful if you don't want to be rushed, or want to practice on your own with a new toy. Also, being in solo will let you actually pause the game, for those of you who don't think ahead when you're pounding down those next 3 redbulls, or in my case, mountain dews. Be aware this is only when your game is set to Solo, playing in online or even private/invite only, well you better just hold it or find a safe spot to AFK. The game revolves around you, the Tenno race. As awesome acrobatic ninjas who use guns AND swords (best of both worlds right?), you're fighting against the Grineer, a sort clone-trooper space-nazi race intent on taking over the solar system. Aside from them is the Corpus, the robotic tech-based race who are only looking for the best 'business partners', and the Infested, a virus plague of mutations and creatures who would look like child of the Flood and Zerg. Your job? Keep the balance and fight the Grineer, and cleanse any Infested, and remind the Corpus not to cross you. The weaponry you'll use ranges widly. From your typical assault rifle, to the mighty bow and arrow (with a few hi-tech modifications), to explosive goo and plenty of just as unusual options in between. Melee ranges anywhere from dual swords, 2handed weapons, to a boomerang that sends your enemies flying and you to the floor laughing. There is no 'preset' anything. Wanna bring a shotgun and a pistol-shotgun? Go ahead. Want a high-caliber long range pistol to keep your sniper rifle company? Have at it. Want to be the standard AR and sidearm guy? Not a problem. No weapon is truely overpowered or useless. Admittedly, some weapons "are" more effective, wether all around or in specific situations or certain enemy types, but these weapons take either a lot of materials, or a lot of work to unlock (and all of these 'better' weapons cannot be bought from cash), so you always feel like what you worked for was worth it. But from the high powered Ogris to the basic Braton, it comes down to you on how effective your weapons are. The mod system. This is more or less your 'skill tree'. Each weapon and frame has 'mod slots' to be used to augment and alter abilities. Anything from elemental damages, to increased dmg vs specific factions, more ammo, split-bullets, reload speed, you can essentially alter everything (stats as well as appearance, via colors or skins) on your weapon except for making it look like food. And with a dev team like Digital Extremes, I could actually see skins like those coming. Warframe mods more consist of making your skills more power, reach further, cost less, to making your warframe a walking wall of immortal. The beauty of it: It's always changeable. Need some Fire to fight the infested but you were just using Electric to shock some sense into corpus? Simply go into your weapons mods via Upgrade option and swap it out. Nothing locks in, no need for resets, no worry. Experiment my hopeful future Tenno brethren; your possibilities are limited only by what you can dream up. Now, you may have read other reviews that say Warframe is "repetitive". Well, I could point fingers and say "So is every other MMO and almost every game out there", which I would be majority correct in saying so. But yes, it's true...But the difference is you won't 'feel' the repititon in warframe. Even if you run the same mission over and over, there's always variables. You could go from a 1 difficulty to a 5 difficulty (which affects enemy spawn in both stealth and alert modes), there could be enviornmental hazards, you could end up going through a completely different route within the same tileset and not even know it. Even without that, the gameplay itself is not boring to the point you get tired of playing. It 'is' repetitive, but it's fun to the point you don't even think about it. Wether you sit there never moving just popping heads off, or you run around like a banshee out of hell spraying a million bullets to hit one guy, the game will support you and let you enjoy yourself however you like. And no matter what you're always accomplishing something, wether it's getting exp for your frame (As you level up each weapon and frame, earning Mastery points which tracks how much of WF you've done. Leveling weapons and frames increases the amount of Mod space they have) or farming materials, it's always very easy to accomplish multiple tasks in one mission. In this sense Warframe gives you freedom not too often seen in many MMOs. Outside of the actual game itself, credit must be given. The dev team, Digital Extremes, is a godsend to the MMO world. These guys are not only hilarious (as well as silly), but they make you feel like WF is part of your world. Their "intercepted" messages throughout sites like Youtube and Facebook to promote events and such make you feel as if WF is happening in real time. And the events on Warframe are beyond great. Each event often brings a whole new game-changing aspect, as well as often ferociously tough new enemies to the table. A Warframe event is something you will more than likely find yourself dropping all other games for until your part is done, Tenno. Even without major events, Warframe has built-in "mini" events in the form of Alert missions. These temporary missions, which occur every 20 minutes or so lasting up to a max of an hour or two, usually involve harder enemies (usually different from the norm of that planet) and increased credit rewards, as well as sometimes giving a special item or weapon blueprint. There's also Invasions, which is one faction invading another's territory, and you decide who you support, each with different rewards and consequences. All in all, DE has made a gem of a game. I could honestly continue, but I've reached the text limit for writing a review. I'll leave off with this. PvP exists, but it is purely for sport. There is no bragging rights or rewards for it of any kind. Warframe intends to be a good-community excellent-quality PvE Co-op Shooter. I guarantee you won't be dissapointed. Happy Hunting.

Look up where you should go to level up ur weapons, because if you dont know exactly what youre doing, the game can seem a lot more grind-ey than it really is. review: Warframe is a great F2P 3rd person shooter, after the tutorial you get a choice out of 3 warframes. Loki which has great support and is the fastest warframe, Excalibur which has powerful offense skills, and Mag which has amazing magnetics powers. All of which can be unlocked over time for free by killing the specific boss that drops their parts. It has a very indepth customization and sort of a rock paper scissors with the new damage formula. Grinner are weak to puncture, Corpus are weak to Impact, Infested are weak to slashing. To make this game really great you need to have friends to play with, pugs are doable but if you have 3 friends in differnt warframes with differnt equipment sets you feel really badass as you rip through enemy forces effortlessly. This kind of game you ether love or you hate, and since it is F2P why not give it a couple of hours to decide its well worth it.

game-hours: 523.2
review: Warframe is set in a universe where the solar system is locked in unending conflict between the Tenno, the Corpus, and the Grineer, while the Infestation threat looms over all three. You can carry out a number of different mission types to collect materials, credits, blueprints, and simply prove your skills while culling the unending threat. Warframe is a game about farming at it's core. You collect materials to make more weapons, Warframes, and companions, eventually switching to new ones while customizing abilities and stats to suit your play-style. And while the game is in essence about farming, the combat, power, and movement systems allow one to create a very entertaining spectacle of flashing steel and lead. Run on a wall, jump off, spin like a helicopter, and decapitate a Grineer soldier, then top off the display by landing into a graceful slide followed immediately by another instantaneous guillotine slash from your weapon. Learning to carry out movement combinations and power uses all while using firearms and blades of all sort is what makes this game really enjoyable. But, you might eventually get tired of the farming and look for a different experience.

game-hours: 241.3
review: Warframe is a different kind of free to play game. Instead of barraging you with ads, or forcing you to buy things you dont want, it completely keeps the aspect of a regular month-to-month or one time pay type of game. While some could fight and say its , "pay to win", I beg to differ. While you can use platinum, the games currency for real money to game transactions to purchase already made weapons or new characters, you're not limited to having to use your money. Instead you create the items, making the game that much better, thus the games fun lies within the aspect of creating and gathering materials for items and trying to be the fastest or the strongest Tenno the solar system has ever seen. Anything you can buy, you can create. It may take a few hours of fighting but then where would the fun in the game be then? In summary, warframe is a new twist on the "F2P" game industry, by one single characteristic that makes Warframe collect most likely the most revenue of any free to play and that is they do NOT force you to purchase items. No one likes being forced into anything , especially not a game, and this game, one where the devs listen intentively to the players, patch things accordingly, and make the game all around enjoyable by not making you pay for a monthly subscription or limiting your activites by not paying, derserves more respect than it can ever obtain. Plus: ******* space ninjas. 11/10

game-hours: 30.2
review: Warframe, a third-person shooter, where you can equip your Warframe with numerous weapons and mods, this seems to be the main theme of the game, bring balance to the world with your weapons and upgrades you can unlock. However, there is a very long grind that players have to go through before they can unlock these weapons. Unless, of course, you pay for the weapons and upgrades in Platinum, the currency players can buy with real money. Free players can expect to spend over 8 hours trying to gather components that are required to build weapons. However since there is no 'Try-Before You Buy' option, many players will feel like they have wasted time and effort finding those components when they find that their amazing new weapon, Isn't their kind of weapon. After the grind the game can get incredibly intense, but the road to that stage is quite difficult. The game was made for 4 Player Co-Op. It's very team based and harder levels will require lots of teamwork. This can be a pain when your friends don't want to play the game, or they're at a lower level than you. The public multiplayer can be a pain, most players will try to help you, but a lot of them are just playing for themselves and don't care about their team mates. Overall Warframe is a fun game, but a very repetetive one. The harder levels are a pain without friends, and sometimes you will find yourself logging in daily just for the login bonus, hoping it will be 'Morphics' or some other helpful object. I, personally, give this game a 6.5/10. Good, but the seemingly endless grind, repetetive gameplay, and sometimes annoying voice acting of the lotus, subtract from the gameplay. Improvements are needed, but the game is still fun as it is.

game-hours: 343.2
review: The odd and unique art style can initially be a turn off, but once you try the gameplay it is fun and engaging. It's a fluid and fast paced third person shooter with some neat melee, parkour, and stealth gimmicks. It's great for playing with friends and offers some nice variety in ways to play. But there are some negative aspects to it as well, first and foremost is the huge emphasis on grinding, everything has to be leveled up, characters, pets, and weapons - AND after applying upgrades, must be leveled up again. Grinding is the only way to acquire parts for crafting new items without spending real money, and crafting takes a considerable amount of real world time (days usually) to encourage spending money again. Three enemy types, and a limited amount of tilesets that make the randomly generated levels also do not help when you find yourself doing the same thing over and over just for some self imposed quest for slightly better gear. It is fun, but I found that it generally overstays it welcome and becomes more and more of a chore as you progress.

review: I haven't played for very long, but I like what I see. Impressive visuals, perhaps a bit cluttered. Exessive motion blur makes you seem that much faster and adds a different, but cool feel to movement. Items are not easily obtained, but most can be earned without real money. If you do decide to pay, it's a lot of cash for not many credits. My biggest (one of very few) issue is that the Warframes (classes) are gender-specific and do not have boy/girl models. Overall, a fun game that's definitely worth a try. Use it as a nice change of scenery or make it your newest ethusiast obession.

game-hours: 5.2
review: What can I say about Warframe? Well, as you can see I have like three hours on it, so many of the features have not yet been touched. Also, what I can say is I am not really a hard-core gamer. I mean I used to be. But now I got married and a job and everything and I just don't have time like I used to to play video games. So this is coming from... a moderate gamer with some programming experience. First of all, graphics-wise, I think that the graphics are pretty amazing. The game always manages to catch you in poses and shots that just look great, and the DOF that is in the game only assists in that. I am not running a super high end computer, but it also supports it quite well, meaning that their memory consumption is done quite well; another game of that capacity would have me lagging horribly. I guess that is necessary though, seeing as it was made for PS4 as well. Their particle systems are amazing too, I mean blowing up a crate and wow, the explosion looks fantastic! Secondly, the controls are the standard controls; no surprises here. In fact, as a 3rd person shooter, there weren't too many surprises, I mean it has standard AI, standard physics, etc. So what stands out from other games that I have seen? Well first of all, I DO like the customizability of the characters, and their super powers are pretty cool. I love how you can level your character and then based on your level you pick up what is called 'mods' that you equip to the weapon/'tenno'. Also, what I love is that sometimes, just sometimes I am not in the mood to play with some random person, and you have massive control over that. In fact, you can just solo if you want. And speaking of levels, there are upwards of 250 levels in the game! Now the bad: First of all, this game is still in development and in some ways you can really tell. This is mixed because you know that if there is a problem it will shortly be fixed, and updates are constantly happening. But I am an amateur 3d designer/programmer and sometimes I run into things that make me groan and hope that they fix it soon, and to be fair, these are small things like no enemies on the mini-map, and the containers need to be worked on. One big hitch for me was that I had to dig around to find out how to customize items. The tutorial didn't really offer anything to help me along the way, and everything (from a beginners standpoint) is so expensive that I know that there will be a huge grind to get anything done. Lastly, it seems largely as a 'pay to win' sort of game. Or rather, I suspect that if you pay cash, you probably won't be required to grind like the rest of us. But in this, I sort of understand, I mean it's not really a PvP game, nor is it charging me anything to play, so in the end it isn't really hurting me. In the end, I give Warframe 8/10 for great graphics, playability, and overall sheer size of the game.

review: A fun third-person co-op shooter. Great quality despite being free to play and on beta. Best played with friends. In-game purchases via micro (or macro) transactions is possible, but more as a convinience rather than as a way to get otherwise unattainable weapons, of which some of the best are only available through crafting and active participation in the community (joining clans etc.) All-in-all a very fun game to play, with lots of options and flexibility. And if you're skeptical, just get some friends, download the game for free, and give it a try, a'right?

game-hours: 18.9
review: An exciting 3rd person shooter with easy to use controls. Although there is a backstory to it, there isn't much plot based action. The gunplay can be a bit slow and needs getting used to if it's your first time playing but after a few missions it'll feel natural. As you start of the choices of weapons are scarce and when you want to buy them, you often need micro transactions to add more "premium" currency to your account so that you can buy them. The graphics are fancy and colourful even in space, controls easy to use and simple, gameplay is wonderfully smooth but can get repetitive. Overall a great game that earns it's place as 3rd on the most popular F2P section.
game-hours: 76.4
review: Awsome Game, I hope I have friend from Indonesia and play together :)
game-hours: 1.5
review: What this game does have is upgradable characters, good looking skills, models, textures and runs smoothly. The camera can bug out once in a while I've noticed (nothing major) but is otherwise very good. However, I find it lacks variety, and while it was fun for a while, it did become repetitive and fairly boring. For me it was too much of a grind, even though it honestly isn't that bad. Finding specific materials might get on your nerves though. It does have a slight pay2win element, but is much more fair than other games where you can buy resources. Still, don't spend ANY money on this game unless you really enjoy it. This game is still something I'd recommend you try though, in case you like 3rd person brawler/shooter with cooperative gameplay, though can be played solo if wanted. It is free to play, so there's is no investment to be made. However, I'll say this again, don't spend money on this game unless you really like it and will keep playing.

game-hours: 736.2
review: I will open this game with the fact that everything in this game takes one of two things: patience or money. Almost everything in this game can be earned for free if you are luck enough to find it or see the alert mission in the hour it is up. People say this game is pay to win. Paying is a definate advantage, but it isn't everything. If you don't mind working for your success, this game may be for you. Warframe is a third-person shooter based on high mobility combat and a high variety of weapons and abilities. From invincibility to massive anti-matter explosions, this game may have everything wanted in a primarily cooperative shooter. You play as a Tenno, effectively a space ninja set out to maintain the balance of our galaxy in the distant future. You start from the center (Mercury) and move outword while gaining power and money. Everything from your warframe (your ninja suit of armor that gives you four abilities) to your weapons upgrade by killing enemies and completing missions. At the time of this post, I have logged almost 300 hours into this game. I have tried loads of weapons and watched as the developers release patch after patch improving this game as it is still in beta. The enemies are challenging and weapons are very dependent on farming credits and mods to improve them. If you want a game that has one of the best communities in a free to play games that I have seen, the variety in this game will not let you down.

review: The Game got an interface redo which is targeted at the Playstation 4 players who total out at about 20% of the playerbase. This redo made the game unplayable by inducing motion sickness, hiding vital options somewhere 4-6 klicks deep which you have to access over and over again, removing the starmap for some sort of planet spin wheel including a mission spin wheel, implementing senseless color codes, hiding important info behind your character model, removing the option to change your loadout quickly before a mission launches, screwing with the mod interface so that you have to memorize dozens if not hundreds of your mods by name now. game-hours: 1963.0
review: I'm rank 13. I have over 1100 hours on this game. I am a Grand Master and I support this game with all my heart. - This game is a dungeon-crawler and a farm fest. This is, both, a pro and a con. I like dungeon crawlers, and I like gathering resources. I love acquiring new items and better gear. Some people hate dungeon crawlers and dislike grinding. I don't blame them. Things have gotten, over the entire time I've been here, easier to acquire and build. A lot of things changed, and a lot of things got put into the game to make the experience unique from any other game I've played. I love the visuals - the art, and I love the way some of the weapons feel, look, and sound. Warframe is completely free to play. Any gear you can buy with real money can be earned in-game. And end-game weapons cannot be bought with real cash- You have to work for the good . Pay-walls? Pay to win? Pay-walls. No. None. All the content in the game is free, all the items are free. You just have to spend game-time grinding for materials to build that fancy new weapon or warframe. However, you are limited in slots to store your gear! Weapons and warframes take space, and you start with a limited amount. Buying spaces is 12 plat for 2 weapon slots, 20 for 1 warframe slot. It's convenience, not necessity. Every mission, every rank, every warframe and weapon can all be earned. The exception is limited-time, event, or removed gear. Pay to win? Yeah. No. Pay-to-save-time is the motto. You want shiny new gear right now? Buy it. Don't have the money? Earn it. And if you're rank 1 with a credit card and think you can buy the Hek, one of the strongest shotguns in Warframe? Pfft. Think again, it's Exp locked at rank 4. You have to PLAY the game to buy a good weapon. Whether you wanted to pay for it or earn it. Also, how can you pay to win if it's not really a PVP game? Oh? Dueling? Jokes on you; You can buy a shiny weapon and warframe, but you can't rank them up without gameplay.

game-hours: 118.1
review: wow what to say about warframe.... well, i dont usuaslly like free to plays because of the hole pay to win mechanic which just makes the game feel cheap and like a scam really... where as with warframe you dont need to pay anything if you dont want to, although it does subject you to a substantial amount of grinding. Which leads me to my next topic weapons and armour/ warframes: now unless you want to buy these weappons and warframes off the bat with real money you have to buy the blueprint with ingame currency and then grind away untill you get all the components to craft it in the forge, now although that sounds well enough you also after purchasing the blueprint and gathering all the components you have to wait 12+ hours for the item to be built. if you do not want to wait you will have to use your own money. with the warframes its a little more complicated and time consuming... you buy the blueprint but instaed of finding the components and start the build.. you have to find the individual blueprints to the warframe Eg. helmet, systems and chassis. once you have one or all of these you can gather the components and start building the helmet or systems but you have to wait 12+ hours.. upon completing these you can finally build the frame.. but, you have to wait 24 hours with a large amount of ingame currancy depending on the frame. Now if this were any other game i would say screw that... but you dont really need to upgrade your equipment for a long while, long enough to get a feel for the game and enjoy the gameplay.. which for the better part very fun.. your basically space ninjas. enough said. you do pretty much anything that a ninja does running up and along walls sprinting and sliding at the same time as doing an attack with your melee weapon wihich give the game a fast paced feel and like you and your friends are like blade weilding whirlwinds of death.... so you will find most enemies wont really be much of a challenge until you get to the bosses, which for the most part are well thought out. each planet has a different boss and everytime you defeat the boss you get a new peice to a warframe. now each boss has different tactics, attacks, and weak points making them a challenge everytime you play.. the graghics arent anything special but there are more than a few moments where you will be like ahhh thats pretty.... they are in a whole pretty good, just above the standered. the maps are getting better when the game first came out all the maps looked pretty much the same... but now there have been numorous amount of new maps for all differnt game types and worlds, some look pretty average and some look quite good, note that you will not always be in a space ship there are some planets that are habitable and so allow you to walk on the surface. Eg. earth overall the game is very well done and you do not have to pay a dime, unless your ready to do a unmeasurble amount of grinding.. this game is one of the good ones and there is so much more than i couldnt just fit in this review so why not just go and find out for yourself.... ITS FREE TO PLAY

game-hours: 1.6
review: Amazing game here. It's primairly aimed at people who like collecting loot as the gameplay, while fast paced and very fun, is a little repetitive after a while. It's got a real slow start to it, but once you get into the meat of the game and have a couple warframes to switch between things really get rolling. It's completely playable without ever having to give over any money, but if you get the discount as your sign-in bonus you should go ahead and throw some money their way. It's a great game and spending just $5 with the 75% discount can get you a new color palette to use for customization, and some extra slots to keep more warframes and weapons. Don't bother buying weapons or warframes with platinum unless you're really impatient or just have lots of money to throw around though as everything can be unlocked for free with enough effort put into the game, and playing them is kind of the point of games anyway. Overall you have no reason to not give this game a shot if you play shooters, which these days basically means everyone should at least try this game. I mean, it's free to play, looks great, is a blast to play, and isn't going to nag you 24/7 to throw hundreds of dollars at it.

game-hours: 97.7
review: One of the best co-operative games out there, hands down. There is a noticable lack of progress as you start off in the game with your first Warframe but as you start to expand the Tenno campaign against the Grineer, Corpus and Infested (the funnest of the three to fight), you will find that upgrades become easier and easier to get. The collection of mods, weapons, blueprints, rare materials is truely addicting. The downside? The lopsided micro-transactions. Do not let the slow-going at the start fool you into sinking money into this necessarily. Nearly everything can be collected through gameplay, alerts, operations, etc. Patience perseveres in this. As for me, I sunk some cash into this because I wanted to support the developer of the game. They've really crafted a fantastic product here that is easy to jump into but also has the depth that hardcore players crave. Unconditional Recommendation!

game-hours: 417.3
review: Warframe is an excellent game, and it's free! You are a murderous cybernetic power suit space ninja dude going around slaughtering various evil factions to help bring balance to the Origin solar system. The combat in the game is satisfying, offering high diversity of loadout choices with so many different weapons and mods that can drastically change the way you use them. The movement is top notch, with a well implemented parkour system (sometimes it can be a bit wonky, but that's mostly just funny) that makes the game very high mobility in a refreshing way. The story is not really yet developed, though the placeholders for one are definitely in place. Warframe is a constantly evolving game, and will have something quite different basically each few months that you're playing! The sooner you get in on this, the better!

game-hours: 186.3
review: I started playing warframe during open beta back in 2013. It was fun back then but the UI was confusing and gameplay became repetitive very quickly. Fast forward to late 2014....I jumped in to see how things had changed as was BLOWN AWAY at the updates DE made to the game. The onboarding process is 100% better for new players. The UI, while not perfect, is far easier to understand. The gameplay can still be a bit repetitive but thanks to the additional variety of missions/environments/enemies/bosses it is a lot of fun to jump into for a random 1-2 hour session. In addition, I can't think of any F2P games with combat mechanics as well polished as Warframe. Its console-tight and responsive with an awesome variety of unique weapons and skills to master. Plus, the game encourages experimentation with different warframes and weapons rather forcing players to pick a "favorite" loadout to advance with. My advice to anyone who likes the concept of badass space ninja combat - check it out and put in at least a few hours. Ideally, join a clan on Steam to help you get through some of the early missions and quickly answer your inevitable questions (i.e. What's a forma? What's the deal with leveling gear vs mastery levels? What is prime gear and how do I get it? etc). Warframe is a DEEP game and there are definitely more advanced concepts that DE does not hold your hand through. This is actually good news though...if you are a new player, the basic mechanics are straightforward. Once you decide to invest more time in the game, the depth and mystery around certain aspects is what makes you come back for more. My final point around the F2P model - yes, this game is F2P which means there is a level of "grinding" for gear and levels. However, the journey of this particular grind is what makes this game standout from other F2P titles. Running around shooting,slicing,and dicing enemies in all kinds of unique ways is not a bad system to grind through. Plus, the structure of the co-op system tends to foster more cooperative player groups vs griefer d-bags. This is also the first F2P game I have spent real money on. For me, this was a huge milestone and illustrates that value I place on the overall experience ;)

review: Run around go "whooosh" and slice some er's up! but for real I recoment this game, I sat down with it at around 7 in the morning and played 3 or 4 minssions (notincluding the tutorial/start of the game mission. and I thought it was taking no time at all then I see its 4 hours later and I was having fun. Like I played a Volt class/ character and loved it and then had it taken away from me. Yes beging characters are only 75 moneys credits but so far the game has given me 50 to start off with and no more. this chose isn't a huge thing but it isn't small. The fact that it give you a tease while annoying truely a good selling point tbh. Because I am more then tempted to spend just 5 bucks to be able to get some cool character or just get the volt like I orginally wanted,. THE PROS? well The game looks beatiful, Tons of graphical settings, amazing story, ing great gameplay! SO MUCH VARIETY and then Difficulty. So yeah them me thoughts. get it

game-hours: 141.2
review: Warframe is a great game. Great action, great abilities and weapons, and great graphics. I will admit, the game can be a bit confusing at the beginning, but once you learn the controls and learn how your abilities work, it becomes really fun and addictive. That said, though they are minute, this game does have a few flaws. .. This game can easily be a 'Pay to Win' game. Let me clarify for those who have never played this game. you CAN pay for your equipment, and not have to work for the materials & blueprints, and wait for the build time. This does not mean that your new gun/warframe is extremely overpowered. you still have to rank it up and acquire the mods for the equipment. The last flaw i find is this game can get a bit repetitive. you really do not fight any players unless you go to the conclaves. In basic gameplay, you can fight alongside other players, who may be more powerful and experienced than you. This means you are running the same few types of missions and enemies over and over... All of this can be looked over because of the sheer fact that this is a Beta, and still a Work in Progress. What has been said is only to notify those curious of what this game has to offer. Though i've listed negative things about the game, It offers so much more positive features. It is a free to play game, meaning they need to get money some how. They have preserved Player choice, giving players a lot of customizability in terms of warframes, abilities, mods, and color schemes, all adding to player choice in gameplay and aesthetic choice. For those curious, give this game a chance. It may look odd at first, but this game can offer a lot in terms of playability.

review: Are you interested in quick paced, rpg, 3rd person, zombie, ninja, robot shooters?
