There are tons of weapons, warframes, and mods to use, the sounds and graphics are stunning and the story well.. I really didn't care for since I just wanted to kill stuff. Negatives: Gets really and I mean really grindy, why? well... the main goal in this game is just to rank up your mastery which requires you to craft everything and lvl them up fully. Which makes it really repetitive so you may want to farm with your friends so you can keep on doing so. I got addicted whenever I made a new frame, sentinel, or weapon wanting me to max it out making it more powerful with w/e mods I decided to place which is satisfying. It's well worth trying but is it worth staying? Well... go in and find out on what you think.

game-hours: 84.9
review: Very much a grinding game, but in the third person style. Before I get deeper into anything I'd like to say that this is a good time passer, as defense and survival missions (endless until you want to leave) can take an hour (plus) depending on your group. All of the weapons (except a few that were for founders only) are all available in game, purchasable with the credits you earn fighting or by their platinum (Real money). Using in game currency you have to purchase the blueprints through the store (They don't cost platinum) then you have to grind for the materials. And I mean grind, look at what is available where before you purchase, because it'll take you a while to get to the next location and time to farm the materials in that sector, then it takes 12 hours (Yes, realtime) to complete it, then you have to level it up to add mods. Basically rinse and repeat that cycle of buying, farming, building, and you have Warframe. Some people hate games like this (Usually myself), but given it's allotted me the ability to kill an hour here, an hour there, it works for what it is.

game-hours: 393.1
review: I started playing Warframe since Janurary of this year. Warframe feels like a combination of Dead Space, Mass Effect, and more. Warframe is a 4 player Co-op type game and there's no PVP just only PVE. Warframe has at least 8 different game modes, multiple types of enemies like soldiers, zombies and more. Each character has their own unique "powers" to help your teammates to complete the missions, you can also recoor your character to any color you want. Warframe also has pets called "Sentinels" which allows to have a pet that fights for you. For example, it can regain your health, shields, and turning you invisible for temporary amount of time. I only mention about half of the "awesome" things are in this game and if you want to know more about this game. I think you know what to do! That right! Download the game and try it out! PS. Message me if you need any assistance! I will be glad to help anyone stranger or friends.

game-hours: 70.8
review: The game is great, beautiful graphics, fast paced action. The downside is its free to play, so its cash shop controlled, meaning if you got a lot of rea l life cash you can get anything you want early on... so expect to be left in the dust often in group runs until youve played for a long long time and built up your mods, people who payed cash for all their stuff will be at a massive advantage. I played for months without getting a single gold orokin catalyst which doubles the amount of mods you can equip to a weapon, or your suit, or anything. Still a fun as hell game, cuz you can play solo or online. Getting groups together with people you actually know is shoddy at best, and takes alot of screwing around with the channels. For the longest time my friend and i couldnt even play together because it kept saying i was offline to him, and vice-versa. Guild halls are almost cash shop reliant... like the orokin gold catalysts....that  never drops in a run....so you pretty much gotta spend real money on it to build a guild hall...and why would you even want to build one? Not sure havent seen any actual reason for it yet other than aesthetic purpose.

review: The gameplay itself is fun as hell, but the over all interface of the game is probably the main reason more people don't play this. It's confusing how to set up your character or even really how to get into missions or what order to do them in. Clicking the wrong thing can have you doing the same novice mission over and over, or throw you in a game way above your level (for you to get slaughtered). Communication in game can be lacking as well, and so can direction. Over all the game is fun and amusing, but doesn't really have much long term playability. I put yes on recommend because it's worth checking out, but without a revamp I don't see it ever getting overly popular.

review: Quite an awesome game with a great idea. Had a lot of fun playing and i'd play it non-stop if my pc could really take it. Not sure if anything has changed recently requirement-wise, but, Warframe needs a pretty strong pc if you hate lag spikes and really look to the graphics a bit more than what the game has to offer in other perspectives. It's a really well put together game and it's continuously updated and enhanced. Goes perfect for a gaming weekend with your friends and you can actually employ, test and perfect group tactics as well as solo; many missions require a stealthier aproach which is a pretty nice touch seeing as most MMOs require you to smash everything you see in sight. The only problem for me was the fact that, eventually, it becomes repetitive, many users being forced to take on lesser level missions in order to grow. Aside from that, when people ask me what games have i played recently and what do i recommend, Warframe is one of them.

game-hours: 0.5
review: It doesn't look like I've played a lot, but I've put about 10 hours into it on PS4. Honestly, that's still not a lot when it comes to this game. Oh yes, there's a lot of content for Warframe. 10 hours will get you nowhere. It's pretty much just enough to make an educated impression. So what did I get out of it? Warframe is not for everyone. It wasn't for me, either. That doesn't mean it's bad, far from it. The game just absolutely hates showing the player why it's good. The basic mechanics give so much agency to the players, allowing them to bounce off walls and slide through packs of enemies, slashing and shooting the entire way. But it doesn't tell you how to pull off the most advanced moves or what's actually useful. The world map lets players fight through incredibly varied missions and locales throughout the solar system. But good luck getting there with the unintuitive and vague map. The F2P mechanics, while grindy, allow free players to fully use the incredibly deep crafting and loot system from the very start. But it doesn't explain how to use the alarmingly complex crafting system. When I say alarmingly complex, I mean that blueprints must be bought or found so you can grind the crafting materials so you can pay credits to craft the weapon so you can wait 24 hours to get your new, unleveled weapon. None of that is explained. Not even the part where some weapons and items need other weapons or items as crafting materials, which also require blueprints for crafting. To close, the bad outweighed the good for me, but it's free. Try it for yourself. You may just enjoy the third-person-loot-based-space -ninja-simulator genre.

game-hours: 4.5
review: Graphics, combat and the whole conception is really good for a free to play game.
game-hours: 33.1
review: Where do I begin. This is honestly one of the best f2p games out there right now. It's a really great sci-fi thrid-person-shooter mmo/dungeon crawler, and I honestly find it fun. I'll split this review into a few sections to help you decision making. System Requirments: I can play this on integrated graphics and a fairly high end processor on medium settings with 60-80 fps.The levels are really beautiful, too. Honestly you don't need to worry about this aspect. Gamplay: The game is really really fun to play - especiallyt with the awesome melee mechanic. You have a primary, secondary, and melee weapon (which, as I said earlier, is tons of fun to just swing around) and you have the abilities of your Warframe (sort of like the class you play as). There are maybe 20-ish Warframes in the game. It isn't hard to get one, though I've put quite some time into the game and have only just got my first non-starter Warframe. You start with a choice of one from three warframes - and you can always get the starters you missed later on. The game isn't very pay2winsy too. Sure, you can get almost every weapon (and every cool one) without dropping a cent. Sure, it wil take a lot longer to craft/buy the blueprints and then get resources. But still it's worth it. And playing with your friends makes this 100x better. Overall, if you don't have this yet, I'd really encourage you to get it.

game-hours: 328.7
review: Have you ever been asked "What's cooler, pirates or ninjas?" Which answer did you pick? Well you're wrong. The answer is actually secret answer number 3, "Magical cyborg ninjas in space". After playing the game for about a month i'd say i have a reasonable amount of knowledge for a review. It's worth noting however that THIS GAME IS IN BETA, though a very polished beta. I've seen a lot of people complaining that all levels look the same, well that's because it's in Beta. The devs are slowly releasing new tilesets for each planet, but for now you have to deal with Venus being snowy and Mars not being red. I think it's a bit ridiculous that sites such have Gamespot have given negative criticism towards the game because of the fact it's all similar. It's stil in beta ffs. But i digress. Is the game a grind? Yes. The main objective is really grinding to unlock weapons and new Warframes (that's characters) and level up your mastery (that's your, uhh...well, level). It's an incredibly fun grind though, the gameplay is slick and intense and all the weapons and Warframes are so different to one another you feel a great sense of discovery when you try a new one. Another thing that eases the grind is the great amount of character customisation. It's so incredibly in depth that you'll be experimenting endlessly with different perks (or mods as they're called). I won't go into how the modding system works, the games free so why not find out for yourself. Microtransactions aren't at all necessary unless you want to customise your characters looks. I'd say if you find a Warframe that you really like and use a lot then why not spend a few quid making him look like a badass. The game deserves your money.

There is no sneaking around with these ninjas, but do not let this get you down. The game looks amazing, plays awesome, and is a great game if you are looking for something to play COOP. I give this game an 8/10

game-hours: 40.3
review: Pretty great free to play game only I'd say hurt by how much grinding you need to proceed unless you buy the in-game currency. Really interesting gameplay mechanics make what would be a mediocre shooter deep and engaging. Not only does every weapon feel different, you have different Warframes(armor), each having a unique ability such as fire and magnetism. You even customize yours differently with different cards or "mods" enemies drop on the map or getting on missions. You can make a heavy hitting swordsman or super quick thunder user. The art direction was weird at first, but once used to it the graphics and style are pretty fitting for the game. Gameplay is that of a fast paced third person shooter, but with abilities such as fire, wall running, swords, basically anything that makes a ninja bad . On the plus is 4 players can be on a mission so playing with a buddy is pretty fun. You can solo this game if you want, but its definitely reccomended with other people as the later mission can get difficult. Over all I would for sure reccomend this game to some buddies. It's FREE so TRY IT!

game-hours: 201.8
review: All the fun of running through hordes of enemies and chopping them to literal bits, while having card-collecting system to fill your cravings of being a unique snowflake. You'll have a ball when you're splitting alien bodies vertically with your electrified, burning, somehow ice-encased fists, sword, staff, bow or even a boomerang, mate! It's free to play, but if you're playing with friends who've put a few bucks in while you're still in the dirt farming potatoes, you'll notice (especially in the beginning) a big difference in power. While pretty much every weapon, excluding starters, in the game is viable, there is a one-time permanant upgrade system involving potatoes; each weapon can be upgraded to double its kickass capacity. You can craft potatoes, though they require a somewhat rare blueprint that is consumed each time you make one. So you'd probably be lucky to make a few potatoes a week. You can also buy them for 20 plat, you start with 50 and can buy more. In the long run, it isn't worth it to buy potatoes, you'll /eventually/ have more than enough from just playing. It's totally worth it to put in a few bucks so you can buy some potatoes, but on the flipside, if you just buy every weapon and warframe you want, you won't have any goals. There aren't a ton of things in the shop I'm actually compelled to buy, since I'd rather work toward and earn it in-game! Something's wrong. I didn't mean to write such a long review. It's the :Grineer:
